div.p: The Wall-Flower. As it grew out of the Stone-Chamber belonging to the Metropolitan Prion of LONDON CALLED NEWGATE. BEING A HISTORY which is Partly true, Partly Romantick, Morally Divine. WHEREBY A Marriage between Reality and Fancy is olemnized by Divinity.
Written by THOMAS BAYLY, D. D. whilt he was a Prioner there.

q.l: Omne tulit punctum &c.
He the bet of all doth write,
That mingleth profit with delight.

div.p: LONDON. Printed by J. G. and are to be Sold by Peter Parker at the Leg and Star over againt the Royal Exchange in Cornhill, 1679.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: I Alwaies thought it poible, that a Man might find uch a Libertie within a Prion, as to the Prioner might eem an Enlargement beyond the extent of Aire: So that the Iron-Grates thereof may be no more terrible (as Barres from Freedomes) then the Streakes and Lineaments which the Sun drawes (by the Penills of his Beames) over the face of Water (and their Shaddowes) eeme Confinements to the Fihes in the Deep: And under what Retraint can that Body be, whoe Soule hath an Enlargement within her elfe? Whilt I was thus Endeavouring to make the Place no Prion to my elfe, and labouring to weeten my Sufferings with Contemplations upon the Caues of my Afflictions, whereby I found my elf (like Noah's Arke) but raied o many Degrees towards Heaven by thoe Waters of Affliction; but Behold! after that I had thus fallen under the Lah of an Incened Power, my Innocence received uch a Wipe over the face by an Unknown hand, and by a Pretender to that Side from whence I leat expected any uch Stripes, that it amazed Me on the udden, and doubtlee had troubled me not a little, had there not been more Simplicity than Error in the Accuation. For,
A Fellow without a Name (having Collected all HIS late MAJESTIES Works into one Volume) et an Advertiement to the Reader before the Booke, that charged Mee

list.item: 1. With Wronging the late KING very much.
2. With Preumption (being but an Obcure Peron) to undertake uch a Buinee.
3. With Relating a thing o Broken and Imperfect.
4. With Compoing most of it my elfe.
5. With Publihing it divers yeares after the Conference.
6. With its Non-Agreement in Matter and Stile with His MAJESTIES other Works, and making His MAJESTY Contradict Himelfe (as Hind. Pap. 5. Compared with my Pamphlet, pag. 116.)

div.p: Now, I hall deire the Courteous Reader to give Me leave to take this Opportunity to wipe this Cuckow's pittle (fall'n upon my other Writings) off with my Gilliflower.

1. As to the firt Article; If to loe a Thouand Pounds per Annum for His Majeties ake; If to loe Blood and Liberty in His Quarrell; If to vindicate His Majeties Caue and Workes, by Writing in their Defence, and uffering uch an Imprionment for thoe Vindications, be to wrong His Majety, then I am guilty of that Crime: Otherwie, I know not how I hould deerve uch an Asperion: Except the Particulars alledged againt Me were as true as I hall eaily render them to any indifferent Reader Fale and Ridiculous.

2. As to the Second; Although I can lay claime to no Illustriounee in my Family; yet (I thinke) I have enough that will defend Me from Disparagement, or my Peron from uch Obcurity as the Namelee Gentleman would blind me with, if I onely ay, I came into the World upon an Account that peakes Me the Sonne of a Peere of this Realme, and that my Mother was a Knights Daughter, and of an Antient Family.

The Father of Him who Publihed the Dicoure that troubles the Wape o much, was ufficiently knowne, both in the King's Court and the Emperiall City; and by His Writings generally taken notice of, not onely by his Native Countrey-men, but by more Kingdomes than His Soveraigne Master had Scepters over. And this Obcure Peron (his Sonne) had the luck to be Thrice in Print, and the Pree never
yet Printed any Disparagement to His Pen, nor wate to His Paper before ever he Publihed that Controverie.

Neither doth the Publiher thereof thinke the Authour of that Advertiement either a Courtier, or a Soldier, or a Scholler, or a Gentleman, or a Friend, or an Enemy to the King: But He imagineth the Fellow to be one of His late Majeties Uptart Friends, that knew no longer how to be His Enemy. So that the Obcurity may not o properly belong to him, who hath et downe his Degree, Name, and Dignity to his Pamphlet, as it may to his Accuer, who taxes a Peron that had all Three, and hath none himelfe. Which Pamphlet and which Peron is already knowne to other Nations and Languages beides his owne, and in his owne to have o much notice taken of him by the Higher Powers, as to be thought worthy of Iron-Grates for the Royall Caue; and therefore altogether undeerving uch an Asperion by any pretended Royallit.

3. He aith my Relation was broken and Imperfect; Who doubts it? I have acknowledged as much my elfe in my Epitle: It could not be otherwie; I have related it as it was: I intended it not as a Monument of His late Majeties Abilities (whereby it hould be thought worthy of taking place with the ret of His Admired Works) but as an Argument of His Contancy in His Religion and Sincerity, in reiting a trong Temptation; and I mut tell this Nicholas-Nemo that it is conceived (by better Judgments than his owne) That His Majeties Anwers (o upon the udden) to thoe Objections (as broken and as imperfect as he makes the Relation of them to be) argued more Acutenee of Wit, and Soundnee of Judgment, than any thing that ever he did upon mature deliberation.
3. His Third Objection, is, That I compoed mot of it my elfe—

Truely, I compos'd it all: So did he the King's Workes, but he was not the Author of any of them: No more was I either of any of His Majeties Anwers, or the Marquee's Objections, Beides what I owne my elfe.

4. He aith, I publihed this Conference divers yeares after the Conference. Indeed it mut be divers yeares after the Conference, becaue it was not the ame, but could not be many yeares, becaue it was but Three, nor many months after I had Liberty o to doe: Which being agreed by both Parties to be kept Private, I could not Publih, till after both their Deaths, as appears in my Preamble to the Conference.

5. The next thing wherewith the Fellow taxeth me, is, That my Relation was broken and Imperfect. I have acknowledged it, I have confeed in my Epitle, that it had received ome Tainture by running through my Quill. I intended no Monument Royall; Onely, a Vindication from thoe Asperions that were laid upon His late Majety, viz: That He was a Papit in His Heart, and could no way better Vindicate His Majety from that Asperion, then by Publihing His Reitance to o trong Temptations.

6. Next, He aith, It Agrees not with his Stile, and that I bring in the KING contradicting Himelfe, as may appeare (He aith) by His Papers againt Hinderon, and the quoted place of my Pamphlet: and how is that? viz: In His Majeties Paper againt Hinderon, the late King pleads the Church to be the Judge of the Scriptures; and there I bring the King holding the Scriptures to be their own Interpreters. But was there ever uch a Sir Jarvis Simple knowne as this Fellow makes himelf? Either he never Read the Controverie (and o takes it up upon trut) or ele he remembers, or knows not what he reads: for otherwie he might have taken notice that I own'd that Paper (which he makes to Contradict the King's to Hinderon) as my owne, and not the King's; otherwie then as He approved of what I writ: for, he might have remembred, that I writ how that the King commanded Me to view the Marquee's Paper before I brought it to Him, and to give Him my Opinion of it, wch I did in writing; wch Paper His Majety approved of, as a ufficient Anwer, and o ent it to the Marquee: and that I aid in my Epitle to the Reader,
That I writ onely what the KING pake, and that I Trancribed or Publihed none of His Writings. And if I had aerted that Paper to have been an Emanation from His Pen, it had not been a Contradiction to what He wrote to Hinderon. For, Hinderon urging upon His Majety the Private Interpretation as the Proper Judge of the Scriptures, His Majety might very well hold out unto him the Authority and Expoition of the Church as a more Competent Judge then that which the Scripture it elfe peaks againt; Which was an Argument good enough againt him: And when the Marquee preed His Majesty with the Churches being Judge of Scripture, His Majety might have recoure unto the Scripture, and yet there might be no Contradiction at all: But as a Fellow in a Fooles Goat may have the Priviledge to tand in the King's preence amongt Wie and worthy Men; o, this Advertiment may not be amie, before the King's Workes.

If this be the Reward of Loyalty (like a Blind-Beare) to be whipt on both ides, and lah'd by every hand: Or like a Matiffe to be ridde by uch a Jack an. Ape and boxt on both Eares, I will have nothing to doe henceforward with State-Affaires; LOVE hall be my Theame, which is the Spirit of God and Soule of the World, which (like Archimedes his Needle) drawes all things to it elfe: Love-Paions are the Hinges whereon depend the Two Leafes of that one Doore of Entrance into Eternall Life, the Law and the Prophets: the Two Heavenly Poles of the Doctrine of Salvation are the Love of God and that of our Neighbour. Love is that wherewith the Sonne of God being lifted up upon the Croe, promied, that He would draw all Men unto Him: All other Graces put together doe but cant the Cup; but Love is the fulfilling of the Law. It is the Tree whoe Fruit is never withered, or blated; And the Root from whence the Flowers of all good Workes and good Deires doe pring. Love compoes Bookes of Holy-Scripture, and drawes Lineaments of Beauty over the everall Pages. Now come forth thou black and ullen Spirit that carpet at my Writings, and ee of what Fraternity thou art of, whilt thou commet o neer that onely Property of the Devill and Damned Spirits, [Not to Love] 'I, but Momus will aske me, What kind of Love is this, of which you treat? I anwer him, That there is but one Love in the world, but there are Diverities of Objects, [the Love of God, the Love of Women, the Love of Money.] The Love of any thing is but one and the ame thing, though it be different in the Subject whereon it workes: Amor, Dilectio, Charitas, Zelus, are but o many Branches of that Immaculate Tree of Life guarded by Angels, and a Sword whoe Temper was of Holy flames of Preervation, whilt the Tree of Knowledge parted with her Fruit to infull hands, and whoe Armes received the Embracements, and entertained the Windings and turnings of the ubtile Beat: whoe Branches as it bare Knowledge of Good and Evill, o, an Excreency (contrary to its owne Nature) grew out of its owne Body, which was Death.

Doe we not ee God and his Creatures oftentimes Corrivalls for the ame young Mans Heart? We ee Heaven and Earth Competitors for the ame Roome and Lodging in the heart of Man: and the Holy Ghot adviing Man how he may gaine Poeion of the heavenly Manion by laying up Treaure there, that there may his Heart be alo.

What hould I ay more? The World, the Fleh, and the Devill are but o many Defendents to the joint Plaintiffs of the Bleed Trinity, both contending to whom the Heart of Man hall properly belong, and when the Scales are even, Love is the weight of the Hearts Ballance, cauing it to Propend that way whereoever it lyes. The Compae hath many Points whereto its Needle may becken and make its offer, but there is but one that is Elegible, whereby it may find ret, and leave its Trepidation, and that's the North: So there are many Circumferences, whereby the Affections of Mens hearts are carried further off from one another, by how much the more they forake their Fountaine-head; yet there is but one Center, the place of ret and unity, where all thee may fully meet, and that is God; which God is
Love; and Love thus rightly plac'd, is the main prop and principall Stay and Support of Chritian Religion, and Center of Perfection.

Wherefore (my Friendly Reader) be not froward, nor o ill Compoed in your Gravity, as to condemne the Innocence of my Narrations, as Culpable of your imaginary Crimes; The Canticles mut not be blotted out of the Scriptures, to pleae every Peevih and Croe-grain'd Dipoition. Will you refue all that Divinity of Our Saviour, which he folded up in Parables? Will you despie the Heavenly Manna, becaue it was gathered into Aegyptian Baquets? Think not this a Vain Story, becaue my Flower lookes upon you with an Amorous Complexion: for, thoe Illicite Paions which agilate the Minds of Infamous Lovers, my Hitory cries downe: It is that vertuous and honet Love, which like o many Sparkes of the Divine, have fram'd themelves into a fiery Charriot, able to extoll an Elias up to Heaven. The Holy Writ compares God the Father to a Husbandman: His Sonne [Chrit Jeus] to the Heire of his Farme: the Holy Ghot to a Sower of good Seed: The Word of God, to the Seed it elf, [Corne:] The Church to a Field: The Devils, to Crowes: Hard-Hearts, to Stony-Ground. Nay, Chrit compares himelf to a Thiefe in the Night. What if I hould compare the Almighty to Medina Coeli; The Second Peron of the Deity to Periia, Bertaldo; To his Humanity, Aminda; To the Third Peron of the Bleed Trinity, Holy Ghot, Comforter, or Angel-Guardian, Maximanus; To the Devil, Lorenzo and Amaria; To Soul & Body, Berontus & Amaria; To a Convictor between preferment & humility, Hortenius & Pippea, to patterns of true patience & piety; Thoron, to carnall delights, vanquihed by the documents of chatity; Maximanus his Secretary, to the Devils Servants; & Bonella, to uch as fall away from vertue? Do you not think but thee Comparions are as well warrantable, as uefull for a Christian Exercie? If you find the Pearl, let it not be valued by the invalidity of the Shell, nor his Orientall Lutre prejudiced by the depicablenee of its out-ide: Value not thee Jewells by their Cabinet; A fine Cabinet may have Counterfeits, whilt Natures Treaures lie encloed in that which is good for nothing but to be cat away. Thinke you not but that the Rich and inetimable Jewells of Divine Love may be Compriz'd within thee pure and undefiled Living Chets, as well as in a Coach-mans Box? Or Truth may not become my Parables, as well as a Coblers Mouth?—Leave Carping Zoilus! If I prevaile upon a Child to take ome neceary Medicament in the Pappe of an Apple, have I not done well, when Perwaions of Widome will nothing worke upon him? Is Vertue of lee worth, for being Muffled up in an Uncouth habit? Or Beauty blemih'd by the Modet Covert of a Vaile? Surely not! Nor more my Flower, of lee worth, or Beauty, becaue 'twas et, and prung up, within the Barren-Confines of a Prion, and Lives haded from Vulgar-Eyes, by the ilken Curtaine of Conceipt: For although it wanted the Vivifying Raies of the Sunne, either to haten or trengthen its growth; yet abounded it with that Excellent Temper of Heate and Moiture, which (uually) Heaven betowes on her Favorites, to weeten the bitter Pills of their Affliction. Take it as it is, and though it want of its hop'd-for-Perfection, impute it to the Generall ditemperature of thee Criticall times, not the wilfull Neglect, or Naturall Indipoition of him, who continues

closer.signed: Yours, in all Chritian and Civill Obervances, THO: BAYLY.

div.head: HERBA PARIETIS: OR, THE VVALL-FLOVVER. As it grew out of the STONE-CHAMBER belonging to the Metropolitan Prion of LONDON called NEWGATE.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: Rome beieged and taken by the Goths. Bertaldo and Honoria, Nephew and Neece unto the Emperour Honorius, fly everally into Africa, where Lorenzo, won by her Princely Comportment, treats her honourably, and afterwards marries her. Bertaldo finds out his iter Honoria. His gallant behaviour at the Prince his Court.

div.p: AT the time when Romes foundation was 1164. years tanding, and after he had been governed by an Emperour 25. years, under the name of Honorius; It happened, that Alaricke, King of the Goths, infeted Romes Territories with a better Army then good Caue, having no pretence for what he did, but the daily promptings of a bad Genius: For when Iidorus the Hermite (a man of great authority amongt the Religious, and of highet etimation with the Vulgar, exemplary both in life and converation) met with this Enthuiatick Tyrant, and diwaded him from drinking the blood of Innocents, whilt there was not the leat thirt, occaioned by excitation of any heat that was between them; he was anwered by the ame Alaricke, that there was a man that came daily to him, and would not let him ret, but unceantly perwaded him to march to Rome, detroy her Inhabitants, and rae her walls, whom he could not in any way reit: Which o atonihed the poore Hermite, that he departed from him, with thee (onely) words in his mouth, Vereor, heu vereor.

Two yeeres the Capitoll ecchoed to the Gottih Drummes, before it anwered to the word Yeeld: Which when Necesity had once taught it how to peak o trange a language, amongt the mierable, Honoria,
Romes glory, and her Sexes wonder, (having lot her aged Grandfather under the walls of Rome, and two younger brothers, Nephews to the Emperour, who having not trength enough to fight againt the Enemie, wanted not Piety in attempting to bring their father off, but were both mowed downe by the ame Sithe, which knew no difference betweene the tallet Bent, and the mot tender Flowers) followes Bertaldo her elder brother, who was fled before through a ea (which though tormy, yet) lee raging then the Tyrants fury: thus foraking the Calabrian for the Carthaginian hore; where like the Sunne (appearing to a heathen people) he found many Adorers, amongt the ret, Lorenzo, Prince of Carthage, and all the Territories round about, who requited the captivity of her beauty with captivating her Peron: which he performing with a paion more impulive then that of Love, attended with Civility, he thus pake unto him:
SIR,

I am nothing, more or lee, then a leafe which is falne from the tree that made Lawrels for the Roman Emperours; and tot by a wind that hath blown me upon your coat: I perceive you are a man of ome authority in thee parts; exercie that power, which may make you worthy of renowne: (and not in ullying a vertue, which belongs to Princes, which is, to defend and relieve the ditreed, and chiefly, Ladies in ditree; the true point of Maculine Nobility.) Sir, you hould take me by the Minds Intellect, and not thus hold a Lady by the writ, overcome a Romane Dame by the Soules Dialect. I have a Mind as much above your reach, as is your tate above my miery. You may force fleh and blood, but no more enjoy me, then if you hould commit a Rape upon Repentance; and what pleaure can you take in the fruition, when you hall find me as cold to your deires, as is a Corps that's new digg'd up out of its grave. Sir, I dare tell you thus much, Though my locks are gray'd with hoary frosts, and my garments blaucht throughout with thee favours of the Ship; and though thee eyes, within mine head, vie Controveries with the hooes upon my feet, which hould be filled with the altet waters; that there is a greater Partition between you, and Honour, then all the water that the Earth's Globe hath received into its boome, hath made a eparation betwixt me, and Rome: if you intend, that, which I feare, as little, as you hall find Contentment in the proecution.

Lorenzo having before let goe his hold, now begins to let fall his courage; and (as if he had been Planet-strucken by ome She-contellated Deitie) to aske her pardon, and to aure her, that he was not o low in her condition, as he was high in his Reolves, to perform all acts of grace and favour in her behalfe, that hould eeme mot agreeable to her owne liking, calling to witnee all that was acred, that he rendred himelfe at her dipoall, as true a Convert, as the greatet friend on earth, had caue to boat a merit. Honoria joy'd with the good uccee of her own (o well betowed) language, bids him be contant in his reolution, and be happy. Whereupon he
dicovers himelfe a Prince of all the Territories round about, and cauing his mot umptuous Chariot to be ent for, he eats her in it, and kneeling at the lowet tep, he begs the favour of his admittance: he bends both her body, and dicoure, to lay hold upon all the Civilities that might helpe him up; applauding the exuberance of o great humanity, hewed to a peron, who ate there, as a meere object of his clemencie. The commanded hate, which the Charioteere oone made, to the Royall Palace (together with the many Quetions and Anwers which the King and Queene of Love made to one another) hortned the way, that brought them to o glorious a tructure, as if one of Jupiters birds had built his net in the Sun; which dazled the eyes of its beholders.

The Palace was eated on the ide of a hill, whereby though there were many buildings, yet not any one obcur'd the ret, but all like o many yearly children of a right Architectit, tood in o many everal degrees one above another. Before the houe there glided a oft treame, miling upon the flowery Bankes, whoe depth rather received Bargemen then Navigators. All along which River there was a fruitfull Valley, that yeelded a mot pleaant propect, which a man might eaily behold without loing his owne eyes. Above the Palace, a Hill, almot compaed the Seate, in forme of a Moone Creant, opening to receive the benefit of the pleaing Zephirs, and a Grove betweene, anwerable to the hape and manner of the Hill. Adjoyning whereunto, in proportion, was a goodly Orchard, and next unto the Houe, a faire Garden, whoe Platt was contrived upon uch a hanging Levell, whoe proclivitie was o inenible, that you might walke upwards upon plaine ground, and downe againe, without decent. Upon the midt whereof, was a liberall Fountaine, which was no lee ervient to the Grotts for Water-works, then to the Houe for ue. No tunnells of any Chimney were to be eene above the houe, but the Chimneys of every Square were o contrived all back to back, that they ent up their conveyance o cloe drawne up together, that over o many everall places of the Palace, there was nothing more to be een then o many tripartited walls, with Benches for to it upon, either opening to the Sunne, or affording hade, from what part of the Firmament oever the Sunne hould cat his Beames, as favours, or perecutions. Upon the ide of every wall, there attended the Suns motion, Dials, that took contant notes of all the progree. At the corner of each wall, were Pendents, and in the midt, higher then all the ret, a larger Pendent, having the Princes Armes cut through, whoe thorough light made the Chardge Sables, and the Field, Azure, or Skie-colour; erving as well for ornament as ue. Neither was the Contrivement lee beneficiall, repecting the three walls heltridge from the foure winds. The comming up to the Palace, was over a faire River, and along a two-arched tately Bridge, between which and the Palace, was a tately Launt, five hundred and fifty paces, with a double row of trees on both ides; in each double row a Footwalk,
wherein three might goe abreat; and in the middle a faire gravell rie for the Chariot and the Hore; which led through a faire Parke, no lee enamell'd with tore of Deere, then hadowed with the goodliet trees; which brought you to a Building, whoe contrivements were all onnes and daughters of Uniformity and Beauty.

The Prince (having hewed her all that is decribed, and having brought her with all his Attendant Lords and Ladies to the top of the Palace) tells her (before them all) that all that he had eene within thoe walls, and all that her eyes beheld without, hould be hers, upon no other condition, but that he hould be his.
Honoria (perceiving that he was now put to act the two parts both of Modety and Dicretion) anwered him in thee words:
WORTHY SIR,

In my weake opinion, you doe not deale o kindly with me, as if you would have me live: You cannot be ignorant of the danger that is in taking a poore hunger-tarv'd wretch, and tempting her owne appetite to be her ruine, in etting before her o many dihes, and plentifull varieties. I have beene fed with orrow a long time, and have had no moiture wherewith I might quench my thirting after comfort, but my owne teares; and now you cram me with delights: what can be expected, but that I hould oone urfet with the joyes wherewith you fill a heart that is too narrow to containe the moitie of your bounty and goodnee? I ee here in your preence, choice of faire and honourable Ladies, daughters to Felicity, and right heires to Happinee: Tell me but which you like, and my needle hall worke her uch a wedding garment, as it may be Carthage never aw the like; and this is all the favour I hall beg, or thinke my elfe worthy of.—
She (eeing him tand amazed) urged him farther with thee words (o modetly poken) I pray Sir, let it be o, it may be I may be thought worthy for to wait upon her.

No, (aid the Prince) they hall all attend on thee, and thinke themelves no more or lee happy then according to the degrees of favour that thou halt ranke them in, and their merits, at thy hands, hall purchae estimation. For (by all that's acred) before the morrowes Sunne hall reach to its Meridian, thou halt be mine. Doe not you tand o much upon refuall, let you make us thinke, that you Romanes have an art beyond us, to make your elves more acceptable by crowning your Perfections with Humility. Come, let's goe, and what thou hat not een, that hall be thine; Ile hew thee farther.—Whereupon leading her by the arme, he delighted himelfe (in uppoing how much he delighted her) in hewing her all his Rarities and Treaures.

All his attendants (epecially they of the Female Sexe) were not (as yet) more affected with envie of her happinee, then they were pleaed with the humble manner of her behaviour, untill their econd thoughts had placed their envies right againt her: contruing that
Modetie, as a piece of cunning, to attract Honour (the more) by flying it; and to draw his love more and more towards her, by eeming to refue it. This night, the honourable women, by commandement from the Prince, attended Honoria; who the next day, as their Princee, was to command their attendance. Which day being come, the time of that day allotted for the olemnization of o great a Marriage was at hand: when they were both made one, with the greatet pompe and ceremony that could be devied, which I leave to your owne imaginations to upply the place of a decription. But one thing I mut not omit, becaue it was o ominous to that, which after happened: For at the ame time whilt the Priet was joyning the Hands of thoe whoe Hearts were one already, Blood guht from his notrils, and at once tain'd the two maine preervers both of Knowledge and Devotion, the acred Directory, and the Priets lips; and made the very word which enured the Prince his love unto Honoria, Rubrick in the Lyturgie. Which though the tanders by interpreted it as a bad Omen, yet the parties themelves, guarded with Innocence, and Thoughts as noble as their Reolutions towards each other, didain'd to undertand it a preage of evill.

No lee prodigious was that of the Dihes being erv'd up to the Bridall Board with a noie of the Cloud-cleaving thunder of the Almighty, and with Lightnings from the everall windowes croing the meat: Which was not contrued, as a benediction, by thoe who did oberve it; and they who were leat upertitious, were (notwithtanding) omewhat out of countenance to behold uch ad Pottents: which the Princely Bride perceiving, thus pake unto her better part:
MY LORD,

p.hi: Why hould you and I be troubled at thee accidents, eeing it lies within our power to make them nothing? If you hould once peak harh to me, that thunder would be terrible in mine eares; neither can I feare the blating of any Lightning, but what may (unhappily) have its procedure from your eyes; and when I deerve either, may I meet with both. The Priets blood dropt not upon our hands, but upon his booke; whilt thee are pure and innocent, we need not feare. Though the blood fell upon the Letter, it did not fall upon the meaning that was between us. Be you but contant to thee vowes which you have made, and it hall not lie within the power of Fate to work our prejudice.

div.p: My deare Honoria, (reply'd the Prince) I am glad that thee things have happened thus, ince they have given thee occaion to make Supertition uch a foole. Look, my Deare, it cleares up already, thy breath hath rais'd the Siege that had o cloe begirt the incloed fires, that allied forth in thunder; and thy miles have already dipell'd the Clouds that ate on every countenance. Come, let us it downe, and better our Commons with exceedings both of mirth and jollity.—

It happened (whilt thee affaires were in agitation) that Bertaldo
Brother to Honoria, and Nephew to the Emperour Honorius, ometimes Governour of Cilicia, (a man of admirable Prowee, and much Gallantry) one who had expreed it ufficiently againt the Goths, (having laine with his owne hands Amboyolus, Brother to Alarick, King of the Goths) ecaped the Gottih Inquiition, and conceal'd himelfe for ome time heretofore in that Country) came to heare of the good fortune which his iter met withall by flying from o ad a fate, (where finding her fixed amongt the highet Contellations of that Firmament, and hearing that there were Juts and Tournaments to be performed in the after-noone in honour of the day) he engaged a rich Jewel, which he had brought over with him, and lipt himelfe into the mot compleat Armour that the time would give him leave, and mounted himelfe upon the bravet hore that money could buy. When the Prince and Princee were eated, with all the Lords and Ladies of the Court, he entred the Lits amongt the other Tilters (diguis'd as the ret were) who therefore could not wonder at any other trangenee, but that their number hould exceed by one, they knew not who, and come amongt them, they knew not how: wherefore he was oone accoted by the Herauld, who demanded of him what he was, and upon what Accompt he entred the Lits: to whom Bertaldo gave this Anwer:

Sir, I am a Stranger, that eek renowne in Forraigne parts, and oppotunity offers me a purchae at your hands: I require my Match if if he be to be found amongst the Carthaginians. Amongt the Carthaginians? (aid the Herauld) that you hall oone find. And o left him, declaring to the ret, the contents, of what had paed betweene him and the trange Knight: the newes of o bold a Challenge was oon brought into the eares of the highet Spectators, who fraught with wonder, ummon'd all their intellectualls; out of which they choe a Committee of Divining thoughts to make enquiries who it hould be, but could not draw up a report: the Combatants didaining, that uch a bold expotulation hould proceed from a tranger, to the diparagement of the Carthaginian Chivalry, if not chatied for his preumption: they all trove who hould undertake him firt: and not agreeing otherwie, they all reolved to cat Lots to whoe turn the Enterprize hould fall; but the Prince fearing that the Lot might fall to the mot unskilfull, and weaket, to undertake o high a piece of Confidence; and o the glory of the Carthaginians might happen to be ecliped, commanded Codruball, Captain of his Guard, a man of highet eminence and eteeme in all that Country, and one that never had been foil'd in point of Chivalry, to undertake the Challenger, which was obeyed, and thus performed.

Codruball mounted upon a Milk-white Steed, having a ilver Mane, that reacht (curling) downe to his knees, with his Launce in his hand, and Sword by his ide, in gilded Armour, enters the Lits,
(his hore out-noiing all the Trumpets with his neighings) and prepares himelfe for the Encounter, againt whom was brought Bertaldo upon a bright Bay, with black Spots over all his body, and a white Star in his Fore-head, having a goodly Mane mingled with black and brown Haires: Drake-neckt, moue-ear'd, full-ey'd, and open notrils, pawing with one Foot upon the ground, and pricking up his Eares, as if he delighted rather to hear, then mar the muick of the Trumpets: Blowing, as if he tomackt the delay, and waving his body up and downe, as if idlenee were a greater burden to him then action: All which ignes of goodnee in his Hore put Bertaldo in good hopes, that he hould make his words good, which he promied to his late Mater in his behalf: who hearing his late Mater peak by way of commendation of his Hore, (he was then elling to Bertaldo) viz. That he was a Lambe in the Stable, and a Peacock upon the Road; anwered, that he would teach him how to be a Lyon in the Field.

Thus all in Armour ilver'd ore, with a mourning Ribbond a croe his Armour; and a black plume of Feathers in his Helmet, with a Launce in his hand, and Sword by his ide: He ate his Hore in uch a comely poture, that his Princely Siter could not but think of him, who was the Man he thought of, her own Brother: the ignall was thrown down on the ruh, like lightning upon one another; and he that was never worted in all his life, was now unhors'd upon the firt Encounter: Which Codruball, not knowing how to brook, requeted that he might run againe, and trie his fortune once more; which being againt the Lawes of Chivalry for him that was Unhors'd to trie a econd Combate, was denyed it by the Herauld: and his fellow Tilters (hoping to re-gaine immortall Honour, by repairing that mi-fortune with a better) tickled o much againt him, that he (corning nothing more then that the glory of vindicating the Carthaginian honour hould fall to anothers hare) therewith was o outed of all moderation and reaon, both at once, (by a trong paion that too often had been his enemie) that he truck at one of them, and the other foure vindicated the firt: o that they all five fell upon him. Which Bertaldo perceiving, takes part with his Antagonit; by whoe aitance, Codruball held long play with all the five, and two of them were dimounted, and ore wounded in the face, and between the joynts of their armour, and both of them, by the brave Bertaldo; whoe word at the lat breaking, he took one of their hores by one of the cheeks of the bit, whoe hore being tender mouth'd, rear'd o up an end, that it gave occaion for a leer trength, then what Bertaldo had, to throw hore and man backward over and over: Whereupon the Prince threw down his Warder, commanding his Guard to part them, which was done accordingly. But Codruball by this time having turned his Envie againt Bertaldo into Admiration, and his Choller into Complement, thus pake unto him:
SIR,

p.hi: You have expreed a great deale of Gallantry, both againt me, and on my behalfe. Let me be o happy as to know your name, let you make me beleeve ome Deity hath fought this day in Armour.

div.p: Bertaldo about to reply, uing the ame reverence which Honoria had oberv'd him for to hew on Horeback unto the Romane Emperour, whilt he thankt him (upon his returne) from ome good ervice, cryed out, It is my Brother, my deare Brother, deare Bertaldo, I know it is he.

Whereat the Prince atonihed, ends for them all to come before him; who having uncaed, were preented to the Royall Paire as the true intruments of valour; But no Muique affected the Royall Princee eare o much, as when he heard her Brother peak, whom he preented to the Prince, her Husband, who acknowledged himelfe much honoured with his relation to a man of o great Gallantry; offering him to be no lee then what he would be, that lay within the power of his Dominions to make him o; wherefore he bad him freely to peak his minde, or to take ome further time for his demands.

p.U: oone reply'd, Great Prince, there needs no long time to be given me to requet that at your hands, which of all other things I mot deire.

div.p: Speak it then, (aid Lorenzo) and upon the word of a Prince it hall be granted preently.
Then Sir, (aid Bertaldo) I deire nothing more then that you would love my Siter.

At which words, the Prince ruhes into his armes, and embracing him, told him, That he had requeted nothing, for greater love then that he bare already towards his Siter, he could not hew: But this he had gained by o great an expreion of his love to her, that he could love him no lee with all his oule, then her with all his heart. And eeing his modetie would not make knowne unto him any farther deires, he was contented (for his merits ake) to be the hardet Student, untill he had found out wayes to make him happy. With uch love-expreions between thee two Worthies, as alo betweene Bertaldo and Codruball, the Prince and Princee, Honoria, and her brother, with variety of delights and patimes, Muick and Dancings, the ret of the Day, and the borrowed part of the Night, that the maine happinee could afford to lend their expectations, eemed too mall a contribution to atisfie the deires of thoe who now began to wax ad with thinking how their happinee mut end, with a beginning of that felicity whereof they were no harers, but o far forth as they could make it theirs by fancy: The time being come, that the Queen of Beauty mut be taken by the Miniters to the throne of Love, out of the hand of her beloved, where he might be placed by his ide; he taking her leave with a reverend, yet Prinely behaviour, and went before that he might be come to, rather then come at man:
where he was no ooner laid in her bed, but all the Honourable women fell in love with her, (except Amaria, a faire Lady, whoe quality we hall defer to mention till the lat: It hall uffice for the preent, that he was one who formerly conceived hopes of having ome aurance of the Prince's love, who ate at the beds feet, behind the Curtaine, with her face from the bed, weeping) and with no leer enibilities of delight, then as if their owne imaginations had metamorphoed them all to men, tanding on both ides the bed, holding Tapers in their hands, and gazing upon that lovely object, whoe o many faces cat one o out of countenance, that he made ignes with her hand that they hould be gone; and then recollecting her elfe, as fearing that they might judge the dimiion a making hate for her Husbands approach, her bluhes forc'd a paage o powerfully into her countenance, that he was faine to attempt a uppresion with both her hands: And let any of the red hould lip an apparance through her white fingers, he throwes the heet over her head, o that their eyes forooke their object, as objects vanih from the eye-ight, when the light is gone.

Word being brought, that the Prince thought their Ceremonies too tedious, they ighed forth their extaies with uch a trong gale of wind, whoe breath well'd each contrary Curtaine, as if by thoe full ailes they had been tranported to themelves againe; and o left her: Onely Amaria tay'd behind, unmied, and unregarded, until uch time, that the Prince with all his Nobles entred the Chamber, who entertained him with this ad Prologue to the Play:
SIR,

p.hi: Had you no other way to
p.U: tep into your Nuptiall bed, but by treading upon a heart, that o much lov'd and honour'd you? to abue a beliefe, that once thought you could not erre? What delight is this you take, to raie with one hand, and detroy with t'other? to fill one creature o full of joy with an unexpected fruition, and trangle another in the-midt of all her hopes? Sir, you did not well: There is that within you, and there be thoe without you, that will not tick to tell you o: and with that he flung out of the Chamber, in the greatet didaine, both to her Soveraigne, and her bad fortune, that could be imagined.

div.p: Bertaldo, who loved a pirit, (howoever qualified) was mightily taken with her, (whoe comportment it eemes well uted with his humour) wherefore he thus pake unto the Prince:
SIR,
You were once pleaed to bid me aske and have; now I onely aske, that I may have this Lady, or at leat your approbation and asitance.
To whom the Prince returned this quick Reply:
My deare Bertaldo, I will not onely grant thee this, but aure thee, were I a woman my elfe, thou houldt have me.
Whereat the Princely Bride raiing her elfe up a little in her bed, aid,

p.hi:
My Lord, I pray tell me truly, have you promis'd the Lady marriage,
that eem'd to be o much perplext through ome uncontancie on your behalfe?

div.p: To whom the Prince made anwer,

p.hi: Upon my word I never promis'd her any uch thing, and I know he's more noble then to ay I did.

div.p: Oh Sir, (aid the Princee) I beg that I might heare her but acknowledge what you ay, before you come betweene thee heets, or ele I hall never enjoy you nor my elfe: For I protet before all that's good, that I had rather embrace a heartlee, then a faithlee man: And as oone hall Steele strike fire without a Flint, as either of us can enjoy Felicity, where both have not kept touch with mutuall Loyaltie.
The Prince proteted againe by Heaven, he never did promie that he would marry her.
Then aid the Princee, Did not you tell her that you loved her? tell me truly; and o made her beleeve too much? Did you never give her any Rings or Favours?
The Prince confeed that he had done all that.

Whereat the Princee as over-enible of the ad condition that the poore Lady was in, gently wiping the teares that were even ready to overflow their bankes, told him that he had done too much, to doe no more; and that he feared, that was not all.

Whereat the Prince, deeply wounded with her orrow, told the Princee, that he would have her ent for, and would engage her honour in tetification of that truth which he had aid; and for the wrong which he conceived that he had done the Lady, in telling her, in a generall way, he loved her: or in betowing ome particular favours upon her, he would make her this amends:

Here is Bertaldo, (aid the Prince) as much in love with her, as ever he was with me; a man every way deerving her affection, with tronger pleas of merit, then I my elfe can boat of; (onely he's not a Prince.) And rather then thou houldt build a dicontent on uch foundations, he hall be Prince of Carthage, and I will be Bertaldo: And (aid the Princee) I will be Amaria, and he hall be Honoria. Let her be ent for.—

Whereupon the Prince commanded two of his Noblemen to go and tell Amaria that her company was much deired, who all this while had hid her elfe in a place where he both aw and heard all that had been aid, or done: And being overcome with the Princee goodnee, thinking her elfe by this time ufficiently revenged, in finding Honoria (already) a partaker with her, in her affliction, and o enible of her owne and hers, he anwered that enibility with a deepe ene of both their willingnee to give her o full a atisfaction, for o mall a fault, as was neither a reall wrong, nor a compleat injury: but epecially by reaon of thoe parkles of fire which Bertaldo's words had kindled in her breat, which began (already) to mother under that vat load of fuell which former love had prepared for o high an inflamation. In he
comes of herelf, before he was either lookt for by them, or found by their Ambaadours, upon whoe approach, the Prince thus pake unto her:

Madam, As you have relation unto Honour, be a friend to Jutice; and let no pasion prejudice the truth, that onely mut confee I often aid I lov'd you, and that I gave you pledges of my love, I have acknowledged it; but that thoe pledges might not have been given as well unto a thing call'd Man, as unto you as Woman, (eeing I never promied you Marriage, or gave them you in any uch conideration) I ee no reaon.
To which Amaria thus reply'd,
SIR,

It eemes I did not undertand your dialect, nor the language of your gifts: I must confee, I thought, that (being a woman) profesing love to uch a one, (and I never quetioned any other but what was honourable) had no other ignification, but what it eemes you never meant: and your gifts, no otherwie, then o many pledges of that love: But I am contented to be mitaken; my griefs are now epitomiz'd to this mall Volume. I am orry I am not a Man, (as you took me to be) for then would I love Honoria better then your elfe, and o be even with you. Wherefore be ever happy, Honoria, in his love, and if my contentment may contribute any thing to that accomplihment, you have it freely: Imbrace him, as the Ivie doth the tree, murmur together like two Turtle-doves, and kie as cloe as Cockles meet, I envie not your happinee.

Bertaldo fir'd with this brave carriage, tells Amaria that he is the greatet Conquerour in the world, thus to rout her paions, and overcome her elfe, (not knowing the meanes whereby he got the victory) and that if he could love a man under the degree of a Prince, he might find happinee to crowne her deires, beides that which Princes weare upon their heads.
Amaria made quick reply, aying,

p.hi: A Woman was not taken out of the
p.U: cull of Man, whereby he hould o much affect that ornament; but out of his ide, that he might it neare his heart: Where if he were once duly eated, he ought to think her elfe ufficiently crown'd with hearts content.

div.p: Come, Amaria, (aid the Prince) behold the Prince of Chivalrie, and the onne of Mars: ole Executor to all the goods in the Temple, of honour and of vertue, heire to Fortune, and one to whom Fame hath aign'd over her right; a man to whom the world owes more then it's able to pay: Love him, and be as happy as thou wilt.
Which words the Princee econded with thee:

Love him, and you hall not loe your firt love; For Lorenzo being my elfe, and I yours, Bertaldo and Amaria hall o agree in a third peron, that foure hall be happy all at once. Love me, aid Bertaldo, and I will teach Love it elfe new delights that it never dreamt of, and make it ahamed of its old wayes, as if they were out of fahion.

As to you, Sir, (aid Amaria, applying her elfe to the Prince)
you have decribed a gallant man: And I hall no otherwie anwer your Encomium of him, then with Beliefe: And your words (to the Princee) with no lee repect, then in laying them to a heart that truly honours you: And in requitall of your good opinions of me, I will anwer the repect with an act of the greatet contentment to you both, that either of you can imagine; in taking my leave of you, and keeping you no longer out of Paradie. And as to you, Bertaldo, I hall commit you to the greatet happinee, when I leave you to your elfe: And o Good night, and Happinee to you all.

Bertaldo, as if his oule were making an ecape, hatened after her, with o much repect to her, as hewed but little to the Prince and Princee, (who notwithtanding, were bet pleaed with the manner of his departure) and overtakes her, before he had got halfe way to her Chamber, and waiting upon her to the doore, he kis'd her hand, calling it his Altar: her elfe, his Shrine: the place, his Chappell: and (making a low obeiance) that his Adoration, he dimis'd him onely with this aurance of her favour towards him, that in her owne nature he was enclin'd to mercy, and hoped he hould not put him to too many prayers: And o they parted.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: The diturbance that the Prince and Princee had in their ret the firt night. The pittifull Lamentations that Amynda her Genius made to the Prince. The Invaion of the Moores. The hard hift that Periia made to enjoy the deired company of Bertaldo.

div.p: THe married couple had no ooner falne into thoe weet lumbers, (in one anothers armes) in the Cradle, wherein Hymeneus ues to rock his paires, but a Heart-penetrating voice gives muick to their eares, (whoe tops were obs, and aire was ighes) unbound their enes, which were fatned in a True-loves knot, and diturb'd them in that oft repoe, they both litned to the Lamentation, and at the firt, they both concluded, that Amaria had come back againe, and privily conveyed her elfe into the roome, purpoely to cat o owre a auce into their dih. At lat, they asked Who it was? and bade her peake, aying, that they thought he had gone away fully atisfied.

I (replyed the Voice) am the ad genius of now poore and mierable Amynda, whoe oule hovers in the aire betweene Damacus and Jerualem, and has no rest, by reaon I was accearie to an act of high injutice. I was ometime a ervant to the High-borne Princee Cosbia, who was delivered of two onnes, one of them being a faire and goodly Child, the other eem'd to be not o well favour'd with naturall endowments. The best favoured was the younget, the lee the elder, whom he caued to be accounted as her younget onne; and us, to keep her counell, which we did accordingly: o that Berontus the right heire, was all along eteemed to be the younger brother, who (as if his divining oule could not be contented with a leer degree of Fortune, then that which the God of Nature had already given him) eekes better in the worlds widenee, while he was yet a Stripling, and Jacomius (the younger) was bred up to all the good qualities that education could afford him, and is unjutly likely to inherit that vat Etate which his Father left him, beide the Dukedome that was to decend unto him after the death of his Great Uncle, (if your mercie towards my ditreed condition, and love to Jutice, doe not help to et things right) acquainting him with the names, and places of the women, and their habitations, that were at the Labour of this great Lady; he implores his aitance for pitty ake, promiing him faithfully, that if he would doe this good worke for her, he hould never want her aitance to give him the bet intelligence for his good, or the avoidance of any evill that hould befall him.

As much as Wonder and Amazement would give him leave, he promied faithfully to effect what he deir'd; the voice was heard no more, after thee her lat words, What you have promied, look you doe
performe: Which words were no ooner out of his mouth, but they could heare a melodious Harmony, as the Muick of the Sphaeres in comparion therewith would eeme but jarring; and o (as if it went farther and farther off, till it went o far, as pat their hearing) they were permitted to their former weetnee of repoe. When as the Prince perceiving how Sleep (that dull thiefe) began to teale upon him, fearing that he might obliterate thoe penall notions out of his Memorandum, tarts upright in his bed, Honoria claping him by the middle, and asking him, What would my Love? He anwers her, Sweee heart, the Blood, the Thunder, and the Lightning, that the Priets Booke, the Eares, and Eyes of all that were obervers of thoe Prodigies, bid me be circumpect, and omit no opportunities, that may make Fate her elfe runne back with all her Monsters in her armes. Whereupon he tept out of his bed, and onely cloathing himelfe with his Night-gowne, he opened his doore, where the Guard, which watcht in the Gallery, were o amaz'd, that it was a long time before his commands could be obey'd. At the lat, they lighted his Candle at the Lamp. Which done, he retires into his Chamber, and commits all the particulars to writing, that had been told him by his late informer. Which having done, he betakes himelfe to his former place of ret, but found little there: For, carce had Whyes, and Whithers, and What aylt thou's, with troakings, and expotulations, brought him into the ame predicament he was in before, but the Alarum bell rung as if the wooden wheele had ounded mettle. The Guard without cryes, Arme, Arme, Arme, Codruball bounces at the doore, and cryes, Sir, pray open your doore, I mut peake with you: The Prince tarts up, the Princes puls him down again, crying aloud, Ah! This was Amarias doings, gaule was under her lips, whiles he pake o fair; and apes hid themelves under the leaves of her pretences, and now ting us ere we be aware. The Prince forcing his own liberty, leaps out of his bed, takes his Javelin in his hand, and in his hirt, opens the doore, and quetions the diturbance. Codruball with ubmie behaviour acquaints him, that intelligence was brought to the Court that the Moores had warm'd on his Dominion, and that the Vultrians had revolted to them, and let them in. The Prince asked him if the Moores were at the gates? His Lieutenant Codruball anwered, No. But they were within 60. miles, That's ix dayes march (aid the Prince) I hope I may have one nights ret, and to morrow I am a ervant to my Country-men. Codruball, here's my Seal, iue forth what Warrants you hall think mot it to et the Country in a poture of defence, and to morrow I will be in the head of the mot reolute party.

He had no ooner aid thee words, but in comes Amaria, with one Petition in her hand, and another in her mouth: The firt was, that Bertaldo might have a competent Command in this Deigne: The econd, that he might not. The firt, he aid, he was bound to performe in point of Honour and Engagement. The econd,
he humbly begg'd, as a fond lover, and preervatrix of o great a Worthy. Then aid the Princee, Let me be in a capacity of being a Petitioner too, and beg the favour in his behalfe, that it may be thus: That if my Lord goes, he may goe; and if he tayes behind, that he may doe o too. For neither can there be better ue made of his worth, then by preerving you: nor Amaria better merited then by uch a preervation.
Bertaldo (entring the Chamber) cryes out, Excellently well aid my dearet Siter, thy motion is honourable, and thy words are reaon.

Then aid the Prince, Bertaldo he hall goe, and o will I: Codruball, you hall be our Lieutenant, Hanno our Major, and you Bertaldo in this Expedition hall act my Part, and I Bertaldo's. I have two uites of Armour that are both the ame, and hall make us both one, one apparance hall cat the ame colour over both our Hores, our Commands hall trike Unions in the Souldiers eares, and our Cognizance hall be alike, let one oule be not ufficient to enliven o great a body. With thee directions I dimie you, for the preent, till the day gives further order. For by Heaven, were the Black and Tawny Moores now caling the walls of Carthage, and Terrour it elfe making its approach under my very walls, I would not leave this red and white, till Phoebus himelfe hould firt rie out of his Thetis bed, and bluh in my face, to look on my preferment. Great Mars, wreake no vengeante on thy ervants head for this preumption, for thine own ake, who thy elfe o often hat neglected thine owne affaires, to dally with a creature that was mortall, whiles I take pleaure in delights (o lawfull) with a creature that is o divine. Begon, begon I ay.

They had no ooner departed the Roome, but Aminda's Genius having received no further benefit by him, as yet, but hopes of ret by pramie, ings to him at his window a forewarning of his approaching mieries.

q.l: Lut, Contempt, Reproach, and hame,

l.hi: Mean to play the after Game.

q.l: You hall prove as Chat as he;
She as Chat, as Chat may be.
But oh, where Jealouie and Fear
Brings up the Van, leads up the Rear,
Loves main body quite is routed,

l.hi: And her enes all are outed.

q.l: Where love is econded by Scorne,
The Generall leads up the Forlorne.
Shoot a Bird once in the Head,
The Wings will never raie it dead.
Commit not to Wolves keeping, Prince,

l.hi: An Embleme of uch innocence.
I have done you ervice now,
If to follow it, you know how.
I've given you the fates intent,

q.l: As far as my Commiion went.

div.p: The ame voice which Charm'd their eares, lul'd them both aleep, and leep o oone after admonition is not good: for ret invites the body to lie down in her lap, whilt he picks memorialls out of his head. All was thus forgot, Aurora, the Potillion of the morn jets by the window, at whoe heeles the near hores of the Sunne follow the gray with brighter colour: till at lat, Phoebus himelf lookes in at the window; and darting his beames through the crimon Curtaine that was drawn before it, made all the bridall whitenee of the bed look red. Sol, with his anguine complexion glares through that fale medium, upon ome part of the Princes eyes which were not cloed, whilt he lay dreaming that he was then wimming through a tream of Blood, till freh Alarums of the Moores bloody practies awakened him, and fill'd his ears with the relation. They both tarted out of their bed at the contrary ides, like two pieces of a broken Bow falling aunder, when its entirenee was at its full bent.

Thus the after-ports (which the Sonne of Hymeneus would have had) had his further dalliances upereded, like the full-fed Child, that is patted on the hand from playing with his meat. Freh Alarms follow the heeles of one another, and the High-wayes are cour'd along with poting intelligence. The Court, like the firt Chaos, (big with forme) labours by Order (Midwife to Confuion) to produce Method, (the ole life to Action) and at lat brought all to good perfection.

Periia, (a faire Virgin, but of Parentage uppoed to be omewhat diparaging, and a Countrey Lae, but indeed a Lady of highet extract, as hereafter we will mention) happening to have a place upon one of the Scaffolds, (where he beheld the brave comportment of Bertaldo) was o much taken with his behaviour and valour, that he proecuted her deires of glutting her eyes in beholding that face that attracted all the faculties of her maiden-oule, to admiration of that manly figure. From thence he came to wihes, and the next tage was Love. Her humility was uch, (occaioned through ignorance of her owne worth) that he thought it a vaine thing that the Daffedowne-Dilly hould be in love with the Lawrell, and the Primroe with the Palme. She had wit enough to keep her hopes at a due ditance: and was not uch a fool as to be ignorant, that impoibilities would be too hard for her: Wherefore he limits her affections to probabilities, and contents her elfe with competent felicity: which he thought to be enough in concience, if he might be, but in a condition, without controle, dayly to look upon him, which he thus effected.

Having lately call'd into her own hands, a mall portion, allotted her by her (uppoed) Father, She puts her elfe into Pages habit, (in which diguie, whilt he continues, we will mention her hereafter by the name of Philoret; and he mut now be he, till he returns to her againe) and tenders (now) his ervice to Bertaldo. Bertaldo (being
in a condition to entertaine more ervants then he had leaure to find out, was much delighted with o faire an offer, asking his Idolatree many quetions, as How, and Wherefore he deired to erve him, rather then any other? and who had commended him unto his ervice?
Philoret anwered him, that the commendations of his owne worth, had made him ambitious of erving uch a Mater.

Bertaldo told him, that he was now going to the Wars, and the harh uage of a Campe, would oone poile o faire a complexion, and alter the colour of the Roe and Cherry upon his Lips and Cheeks, and turne them into pale and wannee.
Philoret reply'd, Might I but feed upon your leavings, and lie but at your feet, how ever you fare, no uage would be hard.

p.U: troaking his cheeks with both his hands, told him, Thou pretty boy, I will make much of thee, and thou halt never want, be true to me.

div.p: Philoret (over-joy'd) knew not what he did, o that before he was aware, he was going to make him a Curie, which having perform'd halfe way, remembring himelfe, he fell quite downe at his feet, and o converted an Errour (that would oon have been oberved) into the highet obervation. Whereupon Bertaldo helps him up againe, with both his hands; Philoret on his feet, fearing the treaon of his owne bluhes, looks him (with a counterfeited confidence) full in the face, that joy might eem to flourih its red in his face, rather then Mayden-colours. Thus well he acted his part in the firt Scene.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: The Prince of Carthage going to warre, commits the protection of Honoria to Maximanus his onely Favourite, who falls in love with her, but finding himelfe neglected, converts his love into extreame hatred. Plots her ruine. The Battaile with the Moores.

div.p: LOrenzo ready to et forward in his expedition, (attended with all his Heroes) takes Honoria by the hand, and delivers her to Maximanus cutody; aying, that he truted him with the greatet Jewell in the world: Commanding, that neither cot, nor labour, hould be pared to purchae her contentment. Maximanus promied, that he hould never have any caue to complaine. Honoria, whether her divining Soul preaged thoe after evils, or whether ome ecret antipathy in nature, between her and her Guardian, or her unwillingnee that her Lord hould, and he not goe, began to ink down in a ound; but being held up, and recall'd to her elfe againe, he pake thee words:

p.hi: I know what it is to part with a Father and a Brother, but a Husband never bade me farewell before: and to take his leave of me, to be o courly us'd, as the chance of Warre might give him entertainment. I know what it is to bid adieu to uch, and never ee them more: but it was never wont to be thus with me, either this love is of an higher nature, and nearer relation, or ele there is more in it then willingly I would imagine. I pray let me goe with you, I have no minde to tay behind.

div.p:
Alas (reply'd the Prince) what houldt thou doe amongst a company of rude Souldiers? Stay here, and I will reach thee a Lawrel-bough with mine owne hand, and thou halt make a wreath, and give it whom thou wilt; and I will bring thee home an Olive Branch, and thou halt wear it. I but in the mean time (aid Honoria) I had rather you would take away this claw of lead that gripes my heart o ore, and queees out all the gladnee thence. Honoria, (aid the Prince) no mi-fortune can befall me, whilet I am happy in thy love, which nothing can deprive me of, but that which may lead me to a better life: And if thou think'st my death any mi-fortune, I'le repaire the loe of my Peron, with the donation of my Dominion: For here, before all thee Nobles, if I fall, there tands the Queen of Carthage. Whereupon Honoria made her lat Reply: Long may you live to enjoy that, your elfe; and I, you. So they both parted. She was orry that he was gone, he dicontented that he was orrowfull. Bertaldo taking his leave of his Siter, and the ret of the Ladies, bids her make much of her elf, he, him:
That he hould have a care of her Husband: And Amaria prayed Bertaldo that he would not be too ventrous.

The Court (thus) emptyed (almot) of all the Men, Maximanus truts among a Company of Women, like a Major domo of a Seraglio, (though he was more Satyr then Eunuch) yet for ome while he kept on his way, laying hold on all opportunities that might advance him to the Princee favour: which, when he had once ufficiently obtained, he thought he had made a faire progree towards his journeys end, diloyall lut. Good natures are eldome wanting in retalliating good ervices with acknowledgements, and innocence oftentimes engratiates her owne Subjects with too many freedomes.

Maximanus had often ought occaion to give the Princee ome intimation of his meaning; but all his opportunities proved fruitlee to his deires, which were till nipt in the bud, (before he could give them breath) by the chat wind of her words, and Majety of her Countenance: Which was uch, as would have till kept him in the ame tate of innocence, if he had not (as unhappily, as innocently) let fall a word by chance, which (like a park of fire by the often clahings of dicoure, like the triking together of Flint and Steele) lighting upon the black tinder of his halfe-burnt Soul, (once extinguihed, and uppreed already by her chat hand over him) o pread fire (by his additionall breath) that he thought he might (in a very hort time) both touch his match, and light a candle to his hearts deires. And thus it was:

Honoria was much addicted to good Houewifery, epecially in preerving Fruits, and Ditillations; well governing her Houhold, receiving Accompts, &c. Maximanus, as he was very diligent to find out wayes wherein (he thought) he might pleae her, and bet uite with his occaions, and adminiter dicoure proportionable to his deigne. One time amongt the ret, he preents unto her, a rare and exquiite Limner; making it his requet, That the Prince's Gallery might be graced with her Picture, which was wanting: Which if it were truly drawne to the life, would put down all the pictures there. She (as little regarding the motion, as affected with the vanity) was, notwithtanding (by much opportunity) drawne to give her conent (with this provio) that he may have the liberty to chue her owne fancy in it. Maximanus thought, Reaon good; and duty, binding. Whereupon he caueth this rare Artit to draw her Picture holding Cupid between her Legs, his Bow under her Foot, his Quiver upon the ground, with the Arrowes broken, and plucking the feathers out of his Wings, (which lay cattered about the Roome) with this Motto, viz. But a Gooe to a good Huwife. And when it was perfected, he preented it to Maximanus with thee words: Now Maximanus I am at your ervice. Meaning no otherwie, but that (upon thoe termes) he had gratifi'd his deires. He (not reading the Motto) undertood not the conceit. She (not doubting but that he had) explain'd
it no farther. Maximanus (imagining that by Cupid which he held betweene her legs) was Hieroglyphict the love that was betweene her and her husband, whoe bow he trod under her foot, and whoe feathers he threw away, as lighting his departure) thought verily, that he had done this, to let him ee, that now he had (wholly) cat her elfe upon his love and affections. Whereupon he aid but little, becaue the Limner was preent, as if he had been omewhat orry that he had hewed her elfe o comming before a man, that could not but take ome notice of her too much forwardnee. Howoever he was all on fire, which being kept in, burnt the hotter: She ignorant of any, addes more fuell by her enuing dicoure: aying unto him, Come Maximanus, you and I will goe and hang it up in my owne Chamber, bidding him reward the Picture-drawer, and dimie him, which he did accordingly: He carrying the Picture in his hand into her Chamber, and finding no body there, intead of etting it up, he ets it down. And thus the Goat courted the Lamb, and the Nightraven the Dove.

That my love was unexpreable, it might appear by my not peaking: but it eemes my actions pake in a language that your quick apprehenion undertood: But I could wih you had aid nothing, and then you had performed the greatet mater-piece of wit that ere was wrought by ingenuity, and had made a third hand, Limne the Idea of your minde, who never knew your meaning: whereas now I am afraid—

And as he was going on with his peech, he gave him uch a look, that topt his peech, with wallowing downe his Spittle. Asking him, What he meant by that trange language, and inolent kind of behaviour? Maximanus recollecting his pirits, asked Honoria what he meant by that trange Picture, and familiar way of telling him that he was now at his ervice? Adding, moreover, the dimiment of the Artit, and inviting him to her Chamber, able to give a duller apprehenion, then his own, the like encouragement: Withall, acquainting her with his conception of the Mytery. She him, with the true meaning and purport of her Fancy: letting him undertand, that if her familiarity was the occaion of uch contructions, he hould have lee reaon (hereafter) to mitake.

Maximanus reply'd (to o unexpected a cooling Card) Madame, I pray be not offended, you cannot hate me for loving you: nor blame that love that is attracted by uch Magnetick vertue: 'Tis your owne fault to be o Beautifull, and none of mine, to be pasive in my obedience to that power. Truly Madam, I mut needs confee, I doe love you with all my heart, and have mother'd my affection a long time: But now I mut tell you, that you murder me, if you deny.

p.U:
aid the Princee, love is your cene, but when the cene is opened, foul lut appeares, which makes you unworthy of your Princes Favour, or my Company: With what countenance can you look him in the Face, that can be o diloyall to him, or me, of whom you have entertain'd
o vile conceptions? For the Love-ake that my Husband beares unto you (in hopes of your amendment) I will not blab your Baenee or Diloyalty: But I protet, if ever you open your mouth againe in this particular, your Mater hall know into how treacherous hands he hath repos'd o great a Trut: And o farewell.

div.p: Honoria being gone, Maximanus bites the lip, and wears by all the Gods it hall not erve her turne; if faire meanes will not doe it, foule meanes hall, whom we leave hatching his owne Villanies. To treat of the uccees which attended the Prince in his expedition againt the Moores.

Lorenzo (Monteroing the top of an Hill with his Army, beheld the Moors drawn up in Battalia ready to receive him) brooks no delayes, but (thinking himelf as Superiour, to them in Courage and true Gallantry, as he was inferiour to them in number) uncovers the Mountaine head, advances towards them; and makes up to the black-fac'd Monter through diadvantages, breaks through difficulties, and gives them a home Charge, ome of the Moores begin to tagger and runne: Whereat the Generall of the Moores was no more dicouraged then the Husband-man, when he ees the winde blow the Chaffe away from the purer Corne. Codruball, Generall of the Prince his Hore, routes theirs, but performes the execution with too hot a purre: inomuch that the whole Army of the Princes was almot Routed, and the Prince himelfe in very great danger, had not Bertaldo, the Prince his alter ego, well defended his Prototype. For Lorenzo (with his Brigade) charged into the main Body of the Enemie, hewing down all before him, like a fierce wind, that gets into a thick wood, when as the leafe is in the fall; which knowing not its way out againe, whirles about the trees, haking down their leaves, clatterring their boughes one againt another, o bending their branches to the earth, till their rootes came up, and bodies downe. So this onne of Mars (environed within a black cloud of Moores) thunders in the midt of them, and (like lightning) o peirced this black cloud, till there fell howers of bloud. Such was the behaviour of the brave Lorenzo.

Bertaldo having intelligence from Hanno, that the Prince was thus engaged, if he were not lot already; and that the left wing (attempting to di-engage him) were all routed, with his 100. Volunteers which guarded his Peron, and thought no otherwie but that he had been the Prince; rides amongt the heartlee and breathlee Souldiers, crying, Victoria, Victoria! Come and let us make an end of the day, all's our owne: they think him to be the Prince, and that he had made his way through, (and o hrewdly diordered them) all follow him, and his directions. He gives Philaret a trict charge that he hould not loe the ight of him (if it were posible) but be ready at had (with his pare Hore) if need required; and that he hould hew his love unto him in that dayes ervice, and have it ever after. The poor wretch over-joy'd with the apprehenion of uch a reward,
converts his fear of death into hopes of merit: And having at the beginning of the Battell taken a box of Oyntment from a Captive Tawny-Moore (wherewith the Moores ued to make their Faces more black (as more Beautifull) he colours his face as black as jet, imagining (thereby) to performe ome notable piece of ervice that day, in the behalfe of his o much beloved, Bertaldo: who by this time finding the Moores to tand o cloe drawn up, as no ordinary force, or manner of dicipline could break, or enter; drawes up his Men in forme of a wedge, edg'd with his own peronall Valour (it being impoible that uch a one, being backt by two, thoe two by three; three by five, bearing the ame proportion up to the very Rear, whoe greater number till followed the fewer, whilt the better-mettled fewer till made way for the worer temper'd multitude to follow, (like a well-droven wedg) riving the bonds of nature in under) and thoe hearts of Oak, at once, both to complaine and open, till they aw the Prince (with a few urvivers) like Mars himelfe tand Bulwarckt in the midt of o many laughter'd Moores: and Re-intrench'd about with his owne Dead. Where the Prince and Bertaldo congratulating one anothers happinee in both their preervations; both parties tood amaz'd to behold two uns in the ame Firmament: The Princes men were contented to take Bertaldo as a recuing Angell in their Soveraignes hape: and Bertaldo his men were glad to ee two Princes, who not long ago were afraid they had not one.

Thee two men in Mars his livery, eeing the Moors endeavouring to Sally on either hand, reolv'd (equally) to divide their Forces, and Charge them everall wayes. Bertaldo (in proecuting his deigne) had his Hore laine under him upon the firt Charge, which had no ooner brought him to the ground, but up comes Philoret with his pare Hore in his hand, ready to re-etate him in his former poture: He perceiving Philoret black as the night, thought ome Moore had kill'd his pretty Page, and eiz'd his hore, and clad him in his Pages habit: whereupon Bertaldo truck at Philoret, who call'd upon Bertaldo to tay his hand; but the confued noie being o great that he could not hear him, Bertaldo gave him a leight wound upon his neck, whereat (Philoret letting his hore goe out of his hands) to lay hold on that, Bertaldo left proecuting Philorets revenge, by paring the peron whom he perecuted with o blind a zeal: crying out, Black Devill, how couldt thou find in thy heart to detroy o weet a Creature? Philoret was o well pleaed with the kindnee of his language, and o little troubled with the mart of his wounds, that he onely thirted for another opportunity to doe Bertaldo the like ervice at the ame rate, which was preently offer'd him: For

Bertaldo was no ooner mounted, but preently he Charges in amongt the thicket of his Enemies, as if ome wild Bull had runne madding through ome Market-place, treading down all the people
as he ranne along, till topt by Butchers, that taid his coure by knocking of him downe: o fell Bertaldo. Up comes Philoret, and dimounting his hore, trides over him, and with his word in his hand menaces the approaching Enemy. The Moores eeing him Black, took him to be one of their own party; and by his rich apparrell to be of ome extraordinary quality; wherefore they durt not pree upon Bertaldo any further violence, whom Authority had protected: untill the Prince (having quite routed his Adveraries, and hearing Bertaldo to be o engaged) comes in (like a raging Sea back'd by the winds, that had made ome new breach into the Land) which when the fainting pirits of Bertaldoes men once perceived, they reolv'd (like a dying taper) either to contract all their trength, to make one great blaze before they went out, or ele (for hame) to doe their own work themelves, before Lorenzo hould come to their aitance: which they performed o couragiouly, that they made the enemy give the ground that was covered with Bertaldoes wounded body; who being et upon his feet, on the one ide by his friends, on the other by his uppoed enemy, to whom he thought himelfe o much beholding, that he pray'd his Souldiers to ue that pretty little Blackamore well: wondring how he neglected his owne liberty, and hazarded his life to preerve his peron.

Philoret was forthwith carrried out of the Battell, which was oon after ended, and the Moors all totally routed, by the comming back of Codruballs hore, who received orders to follow the execution. They all drew off the field: and when the Prince was well got to his Quarters, and Bertaldoes wounds had been well dres'd, he requited the Princes kinde Viite, with the pleaing Story of the great kindnee that the uppoed Moore had hewed him in his extremity. They both reolved to end for him; and being ent for, they were both inquiitive after the caue of his o great humanity.

Bertaldo (telling Philoret, that to his knowledge he had aved his life, hazarded his owne, and lot his liberty) deiring to know of Philoret, what moved him to all that kindnee? Philoret reply'd, nothing but that I had a mind to ave o brave a Man. But oh (aid Bertaldo) (fetching a deep igh) what hat thou done with that weet-fac'd Youth thou tripp't of thoe cloathes? Philoret anwered, I will bring him to you ere it be long. Why? did you love him? I did (gentle Moor) aid Bertaldo. What hall I give thee for reward of o great a Curteie? The Prince econding Bertaldo, bid him aske what he pleas'd, and he hould have it. Then aid Philoret, I ask at both your hands no other favour but that you would give me for all my ervice, one Baon of faire Water.

They admiring firt, and afterwards commanding it to be ent for; which being brought, they both delivered it to Philoret (till wondring what he meant to doe therewith) who receiving it tep'd aide, and (as if night had been wahed away by the morning dew) breaks upon them with uch red and white, as Aurora paints her
Cheekes withall, after her climing up the Eatern hills. Of which, when they had throughly enform'd themelves, they both trove who hould imbrace him firt; the Prince firt caught him in his Armes, he catches at Bertaldo, who kis'd his Cheekes: And Bertaldoes armes being about his neck, he weepes upon his hands; his merits owing the eedes of love in the field of Mars, his teares reaped no further benefit then of being rewarded in the Act, which was as high as his poor heart durt goe. The Prince perceiving him to weep o fat, lets him goe, fearing that he had hurt him, by embracing him with too hard a kindnee. Bertaldo enjoying a quiet poeion of his o much beloved, takes him in his Armes, and askes him what he ayl'd; he hanging down his armes by his ides, as unworthy of uch an armfull, puts by the true caue by this excue. I weep to think what danger you were in. I (aid Bertaldo) rejoyce that thou wert my preerver; auring him that he had pererved him for himelfe, as the bet Mater that ever any Boy was glad of. And that he would preferre him to his own hearts deire: bidding him ask what he would have for the preent, and he would grant him his requet. Then I deire (aid Philoret) in the firt place, That you would never put me from you. Secondly, that I may ever leep at your foot.
The Prince burting forth into admiration, cryes out, What trange affection is this of a youth towards his Master!

Philoret fearing that he had gone too farre, and that nothing could ooner deprive him of that competent felicity (which he had propoed unto himelfe) then that it hould be known what he was, breaks off all further expotulations with this aurance: That as no promie could be greater then that, o no performance could anwer his deires with more delight.
Bertaldo reply'd, Thou art as much Mater of both, as I am of thee. So Philoret was atisfi'd, Bertaldo pleas'd, the Prince atonihed.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: The Prince purues the Moors into their own Countrey. News is brought to Court of the victory, and of the Prince's leaving his Country. Maximanus purues his lutfull deires. Layes his gins. Amaria's kindnee to Honoria, for which he uffers.

div.p: LIke ome Braggadoio inolent Ruffian, who intended an Affront to a higher Spirit then his own, and that before his Doore: And finding himelfe worted by the Defendant, quits his ground, runs his way; the other after him, chatiing that bold attempt (with reduplicated verberations) on the peron of the Offender, up to the ame doores where his catigation had beginning (through a whole treet of amaz'd Spectators) o Bated was this Moore: o Valiant was this Prince, both in his Owne, and Enemies Country: where we leave him, and returne to our Affaires in Carthage.
The particulars whereof being brought to Carthage, Maximanus entertaines high reolutions of perpetrating his black deigne, which thus he proecutes.

Having from that time forward ought his opportunity of ingling her out, at the lat he found it. At the time when Honoria (all alone) went up to the Garret to remove and order her Quinies, Pomegranats, and other Fruits wherein he delighted; Maximanus comes in with a Dagger in his hand hafted towards her, and pointed to his owne Breat, peaking to her in this language:
