p.hi: I have layne a long time corching in the unquenchable flames of my deires, fir'd by your Beatuty; and you have cat me no cooling water of Conent, but oyle of Denyall to increae, but not to mitigate my torment: Wherefore I am contrain'd to be thus charitable to my elfe. Either be jut in your retribution of affording love, for love, though with an unwilling mercy; or ele be mercifull with this Instrument, in ridding me out of paine, by a mot pleaing Cruelty.

p.U:
carce having patience to hear o much, and having none left to hear any more, She calls him Lutfull Goat, perfidious Man, tempting Devill, unworthy of his Maters favour, and the Trut he had repoed in him. Bids him begon, and coole his inordinate deires with his own ighes; and quench that fire from Hell with tears of his Repentance: for that was all the reliefe he mut expect from her. At which words he turnes the point of his Dagger to her Breat, and tells her, that if he would not, otherwie, that hould make her; and that which
he was forc'd unto was not her own act. And therefore wih'd her not to make any reitance, or call for the leat help, as he loved her owne Lord and Life, and the wellfare of his Dominions, with often inculcations, that if he compell'd him to top her out cryes with that Dagger truck through the lunges that ends them up, he would (afterwards) prove as great a Traytour to her Lord, as he had compell'd him to be a Murderer of her, and have his deires at lat, though it were but between hot and cold, life and death. Honoria laught in his face, and bade him look who tood behind him. And whilt he was turning about, (to ee what ambuh he had laid) he whips by him; and running by the doore, clapp'd it too, which he open'd with uch peed, as men often finde who are mot in hate: But had doubtlee overtaken her running downe the taires that led into the Gallery, or in the long Gallery, before he could have reacht any Company, if her owne Chat peed, and the winde together, had not blow'd off her Veile o directly towards his feet, that he was o entangled therewith, that downe he falls along, upon the ground, whereby he got afely to her Guard of Ladies, but could not peak to them, he was o out of breath: and when he had breath'd ufficiently, he could not peak for laughing.

div.p: In which Interim, Maximanus enters the Preence, who not a little glad to ee her o pleaant, and exceeding glad that he had not aid any thing at all of him to the Ladies, with greatet reverence he requeted her that he might peak but one word in private with her, at the window: he conjecturing his meaning (commanding the Ladies not to tir out of the roome) withdrawes her elfe, where he begs, and prayes her, for goodnee ake, though he had deerved the greatet evill, that he would not peake a word of what had paed betweene them: Proteting before all things acred, that he intended her no harme, but onely to put her to the utmost tryall; which had not the uddennee of her owne wit taught her uch an ecape, he hould not have been unatisfied in that particular; but now the truth of his intentions was wholly at the mercy of her Belief: Promiing her faithfully, that if he would forget, and forgive this midemeanour, he would never open his mouth unto her, in that behalfe, nor ever harbour any uch thoughts within his breat. For if he did not, that would be the way to have them both undone; and if he did, nothing hould preerve her honour more then that Engagement.
Honoria (with a evere Countenance) reply'd,

p.hi: Maximanus, not forfear of any thing wherewith you can threaten me, but for the loves ake my Husband beares unto you, I will pardon you, and never peak of this offence: First provided, that you be as good as your word, in banihing all thoughts of falling into a relape. Secondly, That I may be in a condition never to trust you any more. Wherefore you must give me leave to dimie your attendance upon my Peron, till your Mater returnes, and your uit is granted. I give you leave to make what excue you can for keeping uch a ditance.

p.U: eem'd to be contented, and complaines to her, how that he had broken both his elboes with his fall.

div.p: Honoria burt out into uch a laughter, as quitted claime to the upition which the Ladies had already entertained, of what (indeed) was reall. Yet notwithtanding, aoone as Maximanus had taken his leave of the Princee, Amaria takes the boldnee to be inquiitive after the caue of her being o much out of breath, and his being out of Countenance at his firt entrance into the Roome. Honoria (to make good her promie) told Amaria, that they had been both frighted by a trange kind of noie as they pas'd by the Hobgoblin Chamber, at which they both fell a running; and he making more hate then good peed, came over and over: wherefore he followed her, requeting her for Gods ake, that he would not tell any body of it. And that he had o bruied his Elbowes, that he knew not what to doe.

O Honoria, thou hadt ecaped a great deal of miery if thou hadt granted fewer favours, or been lee punctuall in thy performances. But many a good man (like the tree that affords wedges out of its elfe, whereby its main body is cleft in under) uffers, by conferring too many acts of grace and favour, upon objects that are incompatible with a jut reception.

Maximanus now having his quietus et, diquiets himelfe in finding out wayes to his revenge; and in requiting o much goodnee with the greatet michief. For he gives it out amongt his creatures, that he verily believ'd, that his Mitree was naught: And that he upected her to play fast and looe with no baer a companion then her Gardner, (a poore harmlee wretch, whom he often took along with her into the fields to chue and gather Simples, (being an excellent Herbalit) as well for the ue of her Still, as etting what were likeliet to grow in her owne Garden, (a delight, becomming the tate of Innocence) and that therefore he had dimis'd him of his Attendance upon her Peron, that he might the more freely enjoy her oportunities; but he would oberve her haunts, and he hould beare his hore dah ere it were long, though he betook her elfe to never o many by wayes. Some out of envie, others out of complacence to o great a Favourite, were willing enough to beleeve it, though none could, untill uch time as a foolih mitake (ufficient enough to create a Beliefe, where the mind is willing to receive it) had in ome meaure conform'd them to his vaine imagination, and thus it was.

Hortenius (the Gardner) waiting upon his Mitree to a flowrie banke, whoe bed (at its everall eaons) as well made oft with the often riings of the water, as comforted with the Warming-pan of the Sunne, having a Diana's Grove (like a drawne Curtaine) betweene it and the North-Eat-wind, tanding o commodiouly for the benefit of the Southerne Clime) invited them to earch into Natures boome, where he was likelyet to hide her greatet rarities.

To this very place Maximanus dogs Honoria, and ets Spies over her actions, and there leaves them, (as well hoping that their willingnee
to be deluded, might lay hold on ome occaion to let in error through the back-doore of ome mitake, whereby ome grounds of witneing againt her may be had, as alo that if any uch thing were, they might adde a little to it, make more) and according to his expectation, there hapned this unlucky accident (food to his hunger, and a full draught to his revenge) Hortenius having fill'd his Basket, and he her Apron with the choicet delicates; they were both comparing the fruits of their own indutry, and natures bounty, together; ome mitake of the right name of an Herb (on his part) made the Princee laugh, whereat the uperviors thought them omewhat pleaant: Another mitake there was of the Princee, which caued her to clap her hand upon her breat, as blaming her forgetfulnee, which caued thoe eves-droppers (byas'd with prejudicate opinion) to cry out, Oh what a pasionate expresion was there! How he was fain to pump it from the very bottom of her heart! Which mitake of theirs, the Gardner himelf omewhat improved, when he had made her uch an obeyance, whilt he was craving her pardon for his contradiction; whilt upicion was thus well onward on its way, a mall matter helps it forward to its journies end. For Honoria epying an Earwig ready to creep into Hertenius ear, endeavouring to trike it off with her hand, he trikes it into his Neck; and perceiving it to be there, thrut her fingers into his Coller to take it thence; he laughing all the while at his not knowing what was the matter, and wondring why he gave him uch a whirret under the Ear: Of which, aoone as he had beene informed, in humble manner he makes her a low obeyance, and thankes her for being partiall in his behalfe, in taking one wormes part rather then another.
So, o, (aid the Ambuhcado) here's fine doings indeed, we have even eene enough, it is no marvail that honet Maximanus mut not come neer your Peron, let he pry into your actions.

Some rahly wondred, aying, Who would have thought he had been uch a one! Others et their teeth on edge againt the Gardiner, aying, He deerv'd to be hang'd, and cut as mall as herbs to the pot. All inform'd Maximanus, that they had een them as good as naught together.

He eager to know what, and how, and wherein, and what they had eene, and how it was: They told him, that they had een them court one another extreamly: the words (indeed) they could not hear well, but their actions were too too palpable. Why, what did he do (aid Maximanus?) They made anwer, that he troakt him under the Chin, clapt his Cheeks, thrut her fingers into his Boome, mil'd him in the Face. And how did the Gardiner behave himelf (aid Maximanus?) He (aid they) dopt, and cring'd, and made legges all the while, whilt he anwered his reverence, with her hand patting her Breat.

Which (being o confidently related by o many witnees) had been enough to have made him believe (as it did too many others) that it had been o indeed, but that his owne temptations were ufficient
tryals of their vertue, or that he had preferr'd the Gardner before him, but that he did verily beleeve they invented thoe lies to curry favour with his greatnee. Thus foolih people tanding a great way off, and eeing men and women dance, (hearing not the muick) uppoe them to be all mad.

Strange Reports (like wild-fire) ran up and downe the Court concerning Hortenius and Honoria; ome of them got Amaria by the eares, and held her in atonihment. She, with a friendly Apologie (full of repect) acquaints Honoria with the buinee, who knew no more what to ay to it, then a weaned child knew how to draw up an Anwer to a Charge of the Highet Treaon. But having recollected her elfe a little, he preently cryes out againt Maximanus, aying, Upon her life this was his doings, and forthwith up and told Amaria all that had happened betweene Maximanus and her elfe. Amaria being fully atisfied from what Quarter this wind blew, aid unto Honoria, Oh Honoria, hadt thou been o happy as to have quetioned him for his villanie, before thou hadt been quetioned by him, thou hadt cruht the Cockatrice in the egge: But now, when Falhood hath once made Truth a Defendant, it hath taken away her Tetimonie.

Amaria having further made knowne the particulars to Honoria, as they were related; Honoria then unfolded all the Riddles, and cleared the Mitakes. Amaria over-joy'd that he was o fully intructed to defend Honoria's honour, atisfie the abued multitude, and quetion the Tyrant; She begins to tickle in her behalfe, and undeceive the mi-informed, and talkt of calling Maximanus to account for his villanie.

Now began the feud, Reports joyne iue, Publications are brought forth, and a day of Hearing boldly is required of the Judges. Maximanus fearing that his Evidence would not hold water, without farther proofe, tops the proceedings, till he had got Poitives to his Circumtances, which thus he labours to obtaine: He corrupts Bonella, the Prince's Waiting-woman, with tore of Gold, by the means of his chief Secretary, who alo was to pretend himelfe a Suiter to Bonella; he both credulous, and ambitious, wallowes downe the Treaon, which thus he had agreed to execute: Bonella having told Maximanus (upon his enquirie) that ever ince he was dimis'd his attendance, that Honoria and Amaria lay together in the ame bed, and that every night before they took their ret, they drank a glae or two of Cinamond-water: Whereupon he had direction given her, that when they call'd to her next for any of that water, he hould drop three drops of that receipt (which he had then given her) into one of their Glaes, acquainting her that every drop would cat them into o many houres dead leep: Which when he had done, he hould informe Maximanus of it, and then leave him to act the ret.

Bonella puts this horrid Treaon in execution, the very next night following, and brings word to Maximanus what he had done; who asking her how long it had been ince he had done the feat, and how it
wraught with them? he anwered, Preently, and that they were both aleep before they could get into their bed, o that he was faine to help Amaria to her reting place by main trength, and that halfe an hour had not carce pent its time ince he had perform'd the work. He dimit her for the preent, ent for Hortenius to come before him, as to examine him upon the premies; he anwers according to his innocence, and was dicharg'd with courteous language.

The Secretary (having his leon given him) followes the Gardner out of the chamber, commending him for his honet dealing, and rejoycing that he had come off o well, invites him into his chamber, betowes wine upon him, he (little thinking that he hooke a Devill by the hand, whilt he thought he had caught an Angell by the foot) was over-joy'd to ee himelfe o much made of. At lat he had two drops of the ame ingredient, ditill'd into one of his cups; which having the ame operation, he was privately carryed and laid in the ame bed, betweene Honoria and Amaria: and there they were all three left. Forthwith pretended intelligence was brought, that Hortenius was py'd privily tealing into Honoria her chamber, witnees were call'd, they went directly to Bonella's bed-ide, and demanded the key of her: She with a counterfeited trembling produces what he had but lately given her: They open the doore, enter the chamber, approach the bed, find them all three fat aleep, with Honoria's arme about the Gardners neck. Maximanus cryes, It's pittie to wake them, how weetly they lie! I would my Father had made me a Gardner; what a fine time be has of it! deiring the company to wait their pleaures a while, knowing the time to be at hand, when that omniferous drug (that growes not any where but under the hade of death) would wake them with a vengeance. They all withdraw behind the Footcurtaine of the bed. At lat Honoria and Amaria both awake much at a time, yet neither perceived that they had any body between them. Honoria taking Hortenius to be Amaria, and he the ame to be Honoria, both began to wonder at the light which was in the roome, both their heads began to ake, both complained to one another: Hortenius preently awakes, and finding himelfe between two, asks Where am I? the deceived Innocents hreeking out, cry, What have we here? In which interim, Maximanus and the ret dicover themelves, and cry all with open mouth, Out you foule Adulteree, to Honoria; Out you Bawd, to Amaria; Out you villaine, to Hortenius. Hortenius hee skips out of the bed, ditracted, and amaz'd; Maximanus tells him, that there are his cloathes, and that hee knew well enough where he laid them. Hortenius begins to peak, as well as Amazement would give him leave. Maximanus tops his mouth, with bidding them Carry him away, and telling him, that he hould peak upon the Rack to morrow. Honoria begins to peak, like the gentle wind, when it paes over the heads of weetet flowers, and o delightfully carryes their fragrance into our notrils; o pleaingly would he have breath'd forth her innocence into their
eares, but could not be heard. Amaria began to peak, like the blutring Boreas, but was out-nois'd by thunder and exclamations. Both were commanded to rie out of their beds, and were committed to afe Cutody for that night.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: The mierable uage of Honoria and Amaria. Hortenius rack • , and afterward Bonella ent away to be Murdered. A relation of the particulars ent to Lorenzo.

div.p: THe next morning they were both committed o cloe Prioners (to everall Wards) in a place of the Tower, not farre ditant from the Pallace, and appointed for Malefactors of the highet Rank and Quality. So accommodated, that they could neither eae their minds by Complaints, (not o much as to one another) nor expree their injuries by Arguments.

p.U: et againt them, their eares topt, their mouthes open: yet notwithtanding, the Heavens lowr'd, the Place mourn'd, the Stones wept, the Hollow windes murmur'd, and their Ecchoes anwered to every Groan. And let orrow hould be defective in any part, to compleat all woe, their eares were fill'd with the loud cryes and roarings of poor Hortenius upon the Rack jut under them: who was the more mierably us'd, (they hoping to extort from him a Confeion to their liking out the violence of his torment) each tretch they gave him upon the Rack, made every veine of both their hearts to ake; and their heart-trings were ready to break, as his Limbes grew more and more out of jaynt. So great a ympathy was there in the ame Innocence: As he Roar'd, they Shreekt; as he left off, they were till: nothing could be got from him, but that he was a Martyn to a chat Bed. Still, when they had let him downe, and threatned him with a econd and third Torture, he aid, that he could wih that he had patience enough to endure their Tyranny, that he might not be uch a diturbance to the good Ladyes, but he had honety ufficient not to injure their Reputations, through the violence of any ufferings.

div.p: And in his greatet and lat temptation, in the midt of cruelty, he cry'd aloud, O Honoria pray for me! pray for me good Honoria! Amaria help her! help her Amaria!

Honoria falls upon her knees, and prayes, ries up againe, and tamps with her foot upon the ground, runnes to the doore, and knocks as hard as both her oft hands would give her leave, calls out to ome good body to peak to them to pare him, and inflict what punihment they would on her. Whereupon they all cry'd hame upon the
the tormentors, for which hame ake (at lat) they let goe the Rack.

Hortenius had no ooner his joynts et, and the company dimis'd, but Maximanus enters the Prion all alone, mad with rage: And eeing that no paine could queeze out an acknowledgement, he was reolv'd to trye what the terrour of Death could doe; and therefore he thus pake unto Hortenius, (holding his dagger to his breat.)
Villaine, I am reolv'd to have my will of thee, I know thy innocence as well as thy elfe; if thou preferret the tab that this will give thee, before a prick of Concience, I come to give it thee.
Hortenius bids him trike, againe cryes trike: trike, the third time.
Maximanus thinking with himelfe, that death would not doe o well for his purpoe as acknowledgment, pawes a while; at lat peakes thus unto him:

Come irrah, thou halt be rul'd by me, I will raie thee forth of the Mire, and will eat thee in a place of Honour: I will recompence thy ufferings with the choicet favours that my friendhip can betow upon thee: I will upply thy wants with tore of Riches, I find that thou hat in thee the principles of a true friend: Bend but thy reolutions to my interet, and be my elfe. Away with this thing call'd Honety, o like a feather in a fooles cap: Let your Concience alone, and it will never trouble you; it will never peak if you never examine it; and is nothing ele but the Idea of a fantatick braine: Fear firt begot in men the awefulnee of a Deity: Rouze up good fellow, what ayt thou? Shall thy hore tand in my table, or hall it not?
Hortenius (after ome paue) replyes,

It eemes that I have read better Divinity upon the leaves of Flowers, and Herbs, then you have read in all the folio's of your Books. No Sir, you have a Concience that would peak to you without examining, but you will not hear it; and trouble you too, but that you hide your elfe out of thoe wayes it would direct you, and ecure it as you have done Honoria and Amaria. But conidering with himelfe, how that he might (happily) do them more ervice by preerving his owne life (though with a uppoed villany) rather then (by death) to detroy the chiefet witnee of their innocence, by reall Martyrdome. He was orry that he had gone o farre, and thus he endeavours to re-collect himelf.) And beides, if I hould hearken to your allurements, you your elfe would think me to be the baet fellow in the world, and would ue me accordingly, when you had once wrought your ends upon me. No (aid Maximanus) it is the property of thoe to love the Treaon, and hate Traytor, who are otherwie themelves. Vipers nere ting Vipers, though they gnaw their way through the very bowels of their Dam: the innocent Dove can have rough feet; and of Cruelty it elfe it can be aid no more, then that it hath rough hands. Give me the wiedome of the Serpent, who tops his eares at the voices of thoe Charmers, and
carry ammunition poion with their tings, rather then the nature of thoe illy Doves, and Pigeons, that can fight, and have no gaul. It is as naturall for Thunder-bolts to trike, as 'tis for Mothers to natch their Children from harmes-way. It is onely the contrariety of thy dipoition unto mine, that makes thee obtinate, a foolih fancy, a femall pitty that makes thee thus: It is not my fault, nor thine, to doe uch things as thee, 'tis theirs, to over-load us with what we cannot bear, and then to tand in our way.

What moother then the face of water? what creature runnes a gentler coure then the miling River, as it glides a long with o many pretty dimples in the cheekes of her fair purling treames? But if a tempet rie, what more out-ragious then the Sea? If tormes give orders to Crekes and Rivolets, Brookes and Torrents to charge both flankes of this faire troop of waters, in their march, it wels, and makes the greater hate to di-engage it elf, by cutting through the Van, that it may bear all down before it; o that thee out-rages are not in our nature but by accident.
Hortenius, be at once both Wie and Happy.
What would you have me doe? (reply'd Hortenius.)

I would have thee ay (aid Maximanus) that thou wert Courted by thoe Ladyes to pleaures, whoe temptations were above reitance. None can blame thee, but them; Thou halt erect a happinee upon their Ruines, that hall not lie within the power of fate to hatter. If I tand, thou tand't; If I fall, thou fall't; throwne downe with a winde that hall either hake the Earth, or blow the May Crown from off the Princes Head, with no more then difficulty if a Hat and Feather hould stand in competition with the wind. Then aid Hortenius, Sir, I am at your ervice and dipoall, direct me wayes how I may be uefull to you.
Thus they (eemingly) agreed: Reports ranne over all the Pallace, that Hortenius had confes'd his fault, and accus'd the Ladyes.

The Ladyes hearing of it, were truck with horrour and amazement, look'd up to Heaven, wondring that the Gods took no more care of humane Affaires. Sometimes they could finde in their hearts to turn Atheits, but thoe thoughts were laid aide, with confidence that they hould be vindicated in their Reputations, though not before, yet after death.

Hortenius was highly rewarded, and promoted to high dignities, whoe uddain riing made the wier ort, oon believe, that the Gardner had not rais'd that Mount without the Devils help: All things were carryed clear againt the Ladyes, and Maximanus uppoed by ome to have perform'd the part of a vigilant Scout-mater; by others, of a perfidious Bloud-hound.

Bonella mut now be thought upon, (as mot convenient) that he hould not live; whereupon the Secretrary pretends to run away with her, (having both feather'd their nets ufficiently) to which he was willingly enough enclin'd, & o by the way to murder her, which was
thus far put in execution: He attends her towards the Wood, which when he had far enough entred, tells her what he mut trut to, and what his Commands were. Whereat Bonella wept, and askt him, Will you doe it? Is your love come to this, and your profesion murder? I mut confee I have deerv'd it, for haking hands with uch a Tyrant in o great Villanies: But know, that his 20000 Crownes were none of the allurements that made me to do this foul injury to uch innocent Creatures: but it was your love, and to obtain that which made me thus forgetfull of all goodnee, and am I thus rewarded? Know you not that the Tyrant will not uffer one to live, who is acquainted with his Villany? And doe you think you hall ecape at lat? No, you may have the honour to goe lat to pot. But aure your elfe, he will not leave a man to live within the compae of betraying him with recantation. No! Doe not doe this, though it be jutice in regard of my elfe, yet it is iniquity in repect of you. I have not deerv'd it at your hands, leave off this wicked purpoe, and goe along with me, and thou halt never want. I have ent 600 Crownes beyond the Seas, I have a thouand hid under the ground, that never hall rie out of the Earth if I fall to dut: Thou hat wealth enough of thy own, both together will make up a convenient Fortune to maintain us. Or if thou didt but make me believe thou lov'dt me, to worke this hellih Plot by my meanes; yet let me but live, and I will bequeath that to thee, as a recompence of thy mercy towards me: otherwie, whether I hall find a Grave, or not, that hall lie buried where it is.

The Secretary being omewhat touch'd with thee words, (but epecially being loath to loe o much money which might be had by Craft) tells her, That the truth was, he never intended to Marry her, but for her last requet he would grant it, upon condition that he would acquaint him where her treaure lay: Which, upon many Oathes and Execrations that he would not murder her, but leave her there in the Wood to hift for her elfe, he told him where it was, which, when he had done (for two reaons ake: the firt, That he might be as good as his word. The econd, That if he did not tell him rightly, he might know where to find her.) He caues her to climb up an old hollow Tree, and lets her down into the bottome of it, telling her, That there he mut remain untill uch time as he had found the truth of her relation. And there he left her.

Back goes the Secretary, and gives his Mater an accompt of the buinee, as perform'd according to his injunction, who believes it; and forthwith leads him over a Trap-door, made for ome uch purpoes, who not acquainted with the mode of ordering his teps, falls down a Precipice, and there was hideouly lain, falling down upon harp takes, tuck in the bottome ready to receive him. Whereupon Maximanus gives it out, that his Servant, and Bonella were both fled, being accearies to the foul Adultery, and that upon the Confeion of Hortenius, who takes all upon him, now that he may have all to throw hereafter.

By this time all things were fitted to the Tyrants hand, and obtacles removed out of his way, he thinks it fit to acquaint Lorenzo with the whole ubtance of the tory and ends a ubtile Meenger, whom he truts with the mannagery of this Affaire: And thus he directs his Letter to the Prince.

body.p: MY Loyalty was ever uch, that it could break through the greatet difficulties, and run hazards of the highet nature, wherein it may preerve your Honour, though I fell my elfe by the rie of that. Sir, my Heart trembles, and my Hand hakes, o that you may eaily perceive a difference from my wonted Character: whilt it acquaints you with Newes, as unwelcome to your Eares, as it dropt unwillingly from my Pen. I have ummoned all the faculties of my undertanding to act the part of a Dicreet man in this Affair, wherein I have found much difficulty, but I have overcome it, and preent the buinee to you clear as the Sun. Supitions I valued not, neither did I weigh Circumtances, but when Evidence brought in her two main witnees, Demontration, and Confeion, I thought it time to let your Highnee know how much you were mitaken in the high value you et on uch a Counterfeit, as Honoria has too palpably proved her elfe to be ince your departure: And how much a Bawde to her foul Lut Amaria was. The examinations whereof, under the known Hands and Seales of your mot truty Servants, and Loyall Subjects I have here ent incloed, leaving the ret of the partiticulars to his Narration: And o expecting further orders from your Highnee concerning the forementioned Delinquents: I ret as my Duty bindes,

closer.signed: Your Highnee faithfull Servant, and Loyall Subject, MAXIMANUS.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: The Prince pasing by the Lady Dutchee Cosbia her Houe, ettles the Difference between the two Brothers. A Battell fought with the Moores. Tydings is brought to Lorenzo concerning Honoria. The Prince and Bertaldo are at Variance concerning it. Philoret ent with Intructions. Amynda's Genius bids them take heed.

div.p: WHen as the Carthaginian Drums had beat up a March to the tyr'd Souldiers feet over the Fesian Mountains (and the hrill Trumpet, with his Breath, call'd on the Couragious Troops to follow) fater then the wearied Palferies could anwer to the hot pur of their fierce riders. Lorenzo might behold (in a fair pleaant Valley) a co¯modious place for quartering his Army, (having a pretty Village cloe adjoyning, which, together with the indipoednee of his Army to march any further, invited his Highnee reolution there to ret his Standard) inquiring what great Peronage did own o great happinee to be o well eated. It was anwered, that the Lady Paramount, to all that fruitfull Plaine, and tately Building, her name was Cosbia, who epying an Army to decend the Hils, with Colours flying, as if ome curious Garden had decended the craggy Mountaines, to have given Battell to her et of Tulips. She ent to know the caue, and dive into the meaning of uch an approach.

The Meenger having delivered his Errand, was ent back with this accompt: That it was Lorenzo, Prince of Carthage, who in catigation of the bold Moores attempt upon his Confines, followed the Puruite, and was contrain'd (as his March fell out) to trouble her, and the ret of her good Neighbours with one nights lodging; auring her, that the demeanour both of him, and his, hould be rather like Guets, then Souldiers. The old Lady thought it policy to make a vertue of neceity, and entertain him worthily.

Lorenzo was no ooner entred the Pallace, but he call'd to mind Aminda, her engagement; for he was no ooner invited to ret himelf upon the Couch, by the ide of the old Beldam Cosbia, but he began to ask her how many Sonnes he had? who anwered, Two. The Prince deired to be acquainted with their names: he anwered, If he pleas'd, he might Honour them, and her, with taking notice of their Perons, for they were both either neer, or within the Houe. Lorenzo demanded the cognizance of their Names: She told him, That the one was known by the name of Jacomius, the other of Berontus. The Prince demanded which was the Eldet of the two? The Lady (though omewhat tagger'd) anwer Jacomius; whereat the Prince eemed atisfied, (for the preent) but after a while, the two Brothers entring
the Roome, they had no ooner made their obeyance to the Prince, but the Prince calls to minde the relation that Aminda's Ghot had given him; whereupon he alutes Berontus with a more Princely favour then his younger Brother, whereat the old Lady (concious of her owne injutice) was truck with fear (the ineparable hadow of a guilty Concience) that he had been betray'd; and that the Army had advanced thither to no other purpoe but to vindicate the wrong which her partiallity had cat upon her lawfull Heir, and Eldet onne: yet notwithtanding, he plucks up her pirits, and tells Lorenzo, that he uppoed he was mitaken, for that was her Eldet onne, pointing at Jacomius: The Prince tells her, that he believ'd that neither he, nor he, were mitaken, though he thought to blind the world with uch a falhood, as rendred her unworthy of the Cosbian name. Neither of the two young Princes knew his meaning, Cosbia did; the Prince drew forth his Memorandum, and gave Orders to bring before him uch, and uch, as were inerted in the Paper. They were all brought before him, examined, confeing (in the midt of the Army, as if they had been urrounded by o many Ghotly Fathers) all that had been done, and how (at the unjut commands of the Lady Cosbia) they had hitherto kept her unjut precepts, but now they could not withtand the truth any longer; whereat Berontus raies up himelf a thought higher then he was before, Jacomius knew not what to think on't: Cosbia (as if ome Deity had decended from the Gods, with an Army of Intelligencers) declares the truth: where upon by the Prince his mediation, Cosbia, her willingnee, and the clear evidence that the witnees did give) the two Brothers were agreed. Berontus was to be (thence forward) acknowledged right Heire (as Elder Brother) to the Cosbian Family, and Jacomius was by conent (of all parties) to inherit the Dukedom that was decended by their great Uncle Bomon. Supper-eaon caus'd the Cloath to lay aide all buinee, o that they were at lat enible of no other want but ret.
When time had thus put on her night-cloathes, and the night had brought Lorenzo (thus) to Bed, Aminda, her gratefull Genius, gives Lorenzo thanks and melody, with this Song at his Chamber window.

q.l: With voice of Condenated aire,
With the Thankgiver-part of Prayer.
With a Lute, whoe Back is Cloud,
Its Belly, Air: The windes aloud,

l.hi: Strike the strings (at my Command)

q.l: That's the finger and the hand.
May no Murmuring of the Woods,
No Rowling of the Water-flouds:
No Yelp of Hounds, no Howles of Wolves;
No Brayes of Aes, nor of Bulls
The Roarings may no waters breach,
Nor Crack of Thunder this night reach
Lorenzoes eares; be happy, blet,
Compos'd, and weetly take your ret.

div.p: The Prince (no lee ollac'd with the Muick then the gratitude of Aminda's Ghot) leepes oundly all night long, untill the Morne threw up the Cypree over the face of Day; about which time the Army (like a Main body that rets enlee till it receives Orders from the Soul, how to direct its Feet and Hands) moves upon Lorenzo his approach, and purues the Foe. He had not advanced his Cohorts thirty miles, but he was out-fac'd with an Army of ixty thouand Moores drawne in Battalia, whoe ole Commander was great Tomolin, Emperour of the Abisines, whoe multitudes Lorenzo no more weighes, then man-hood feares to charge through darknee: and therefore thus he animates his Souldiers with an Oration.
Companions in Armes,

YOu ee your Enemies before your faces; if ye turne your backes upon them they are Lyons, Tygers, Vultures, Devils; if ye tand toutly to your Tacklin, they are but Sheep, Hares, Hens, and heartlee. So that it lyes in your power to chue whether you will have them Valiant, or otherwie: Your comportment may be uch, as may make them all Cears, Hectors, Alexanders; and it may be uch as may render them your Slaves, Vaals, Victims, and Trophees of your Renown. Would you this day live, or die? If you would live, the way to life is not to tand in fear of death: and the way to die, is to meet death by flying from it. Honour is your aime, Victory the end, Riches your reward, and a good Caue the ground you fight upon: Fear will be your overthrow, Cowardice your hame, and Confuion will be detruction to you all.

Wherefore let me be your Example, follow my Conduct, oberve but my Directions, and three houres time (well pent) hall crowne all your deires; thrut palmes into your hands; eat joy on every Countenance; ame over your actions; fill your hearts with gladnee, and your pockets with money: For by all that's good, and all that's true, after this day, your never ee Lorenzo more, except a Conquerour.

The Souldiers houted with acclamations of joy, crying, No man cares to live, if Lorenzo dies; and no man feares to die in preervation of his Life and Honour. Forthwith the Signall was given; the Carthaginians flie upon the Moors like a trong tyde, whereon Neptune rides foaming in his rage againt ome black Rock, that receives the violence into its boome: So Charges Lorenzo through the heart of the main Body, and there with his own hands he layes the Standard-bearer. Bertaldo and Berontus eize the Standard; but uch confuion had their fury, and the dayes over-cat already cat upon
them, that the Moors (had by this time) compas'd whom they knew not compaed, and the Carthaginians kept on their way, with uch like confidence, as men ue to fight withall, when they carry all before them, till uch time that they had made their way through the very entrailes of the black-fac'd monter, and found (like phyick) that they had not toucht the vitalls, but onely purg'd through the body of its Patient, leaving it more ound and active then it was before, and themelves divided from themelves.

Whereupon Philoret finding them all at a tand, he betakes him to his old tratagem, blacks his face, and the faces of one hundred more, which were the flower of all the Carthaginian Chivalry, and takes Lorenzo, Bertaldo, Berontus, Codruball, and Hanno, with him along, (as if they had been Prioners) cauing the ret of that party to draw farther off, which (with the thick mits aitance) oon was out of ight, and Orders were ent to the ret of the Army, that as oone as ever they hould hear a rumbling within the guts of the foul Monter, they hould make ruptures into the very bowels of the beat, up to the place where they hould find the Prince to be engaged. Accordingly they act, Philoret brings in his Captives, tells the Moores, that the Carthaginian Army is quite fled, and gone, and that in the puruit he had taken o many men of note, whom he brought for to preent unto the Emperour, that their qualities might be known: whereupon the Moores gave a hout that made the Skies ring: Tomolin having received intelligence of his uppoed happy fortune, ends Commands to bring the Prioners before him, when the Emperour ate upon his Hore guarded with the Quinteence of all the Affrican Nobility, on whom the uppoed Prioners, and the ret, fell like a fierce Storme; at which ame time, the everall parties following their directions, this great Gyant fell to ground, as tab'd to the Heart, and maim'd in all his Limbes; Berontus having laine the Emperour with his own hands. Thus Victory put palmes into thee worthyes hands, but he reerved the Bayes to crown the Virgin Temples.

The day their owne, and now the Country theirs, Lorenzo and Bertaldo both conjoyne to promote the mot deerving Philoret to ome place of Eminence, and Command, amongt the Souldiers, and they voted Philoret at that time Captaine of the Guard to Prince Lorenzo. Philoret amaz'd (with horrour) at the danger of his own merit, thus modetly refues his preferment: I hope I have not deerv'd o ill this day, as that I hould now loe my place; I eteeme no Dignity comparable to my relation to Bertaldo; and when I am turn'd out of his ervice, I hall be uelee for any action. Wherefore as my ambition aimes no higher, o my deires beg this onely favour, that I may be till the ame. Bertaldo was o in love with Philoret, that he thought himelf mierable in the ignorance of wayes to recompence his unexpreable affections towards him, had Philoret but aid he had been a Virgin, Amaria never had been thought on more.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Maximanus his ervant arrives at the Camp with Letters. Lorenzoe's destruction: He falls out with Bertaldo upon it, Berontus aves Bertaldo from danger. Philoret makes both Friends, and is ent to make Enquiry into the buinee. Aminda's Ghot forwarnes him concerning Honoria.

div.p: LOrenzo had no ooner conquer'd the Moores but there aroe a new Warre, and harp conflict within his his boome upon the delivery of the Letters from Maximanus; whoe eyes poted o fat over the Apollogy, to come to the maine ubject of the tory, that (when thoe quick intelligencers had inform'd his injured oul) it let in uch lightning (through its windowes) as too oon laid hold on that combutible materiall, Jealouie: that the houe was all on fire over the head of its inhabitant; then he hates back againe to the Apollogy, and eekes for water in their iines, but meets with Oyle: Sometimes he railes upon Honoria, calling her Perfidious woman; Amaria, Hag; Hortenius Villaine: Teares his hair, tamps upon the ground. Then tanding in a calmer poture, he ayes (to himelf) me thinkes it hould not not be, ure it is imposible. Unfolds the Letter againe, flings it open; then askes (himelf) if it were not o, why hould thee, and thee, certifie thus and thus: Then falls into another fit of raving, in which Bertaldo and Berontus find him, and happen to enter the preence as he was venting his poion'd tomack of this foul language: Bae Woman, foul Adulteree; could he find no body with whom he might ingender, but with a Garden-toad. Whereat Bertaldo askes, what meanes the Prince? What hath rais'd o great a tempet in o fair a mind? Your fair Siter Sir, (aid Lorenzo) How (aid Bertalda) my Siter? Who, Honoria? She's not Honoria (aid Lorenzo) I ay your iter Sir, who is fale, and wicked, vile, and has buried all my Glory in her dihonour.
Then (aid Bertaldo) take truce with your Pasions but a while, and you hall finde your elfe abus'd, and her innocent. I mut deire you to forbear your pasion, and that language.
You mut deire (aid Lorenzo) what? for any thing that I can fear from you? To thy face I peak it, thy Siter is a Whore.
To thy face I peak it (aid Bertaldo that Lorenzo Lyes.

They both drew upon one another, and Berontus layed better hold upon Bertaldo, then Philoret could upon Lorenzo, from whom he foone had di-engaged himelfe; whereby Bertaldo had been much in danger, if Philoret had not with both his armes intangled the feet of him, whoe hands he could not hold. So that the Prince thereby
fell upon the ground, whereat he calling out, the Guard ruhes in, amaz'd to ee o much fury, and no enemy neer.
Lorenzo calls upon them to fall upon Bertaldo. Berontus deires them for to hold their hands, auring them, that the Prince himelfe would give them thanks hereafter, and commend their diobedience.

O (aid Philoret, hanging upon one of his armes) what doe you meane to doe? to put out one of your owne eyes? to cut off your owne right hand? let me who have been fortunate to you in ome mall ervices, be now happy, in doing you the greatet good, in cauing you to be your elfe, which whilt you are, there is no higher Excellence, but now you are not: what have you received, but a Letter? cannot Letters lye? from whom have you received it? from Maximanus, is it not posible he may be fale, and Honoria innocent? you abu'd, and Bertaldoes merit requited with uch an injury, that repentance can never wah the taine out of your honour? heare more, enquire farther into the buinee, upon my life Honoria is true, true to you, and undeerving the leat ill thought.
O (aid Lorenzo) were that but o, I would give the world, if it were all mine.
Berontus replyed, It is time enough to be thus perplext, after that you were aured that this were true.
I am aured (aid Lorenzo) by all thee tetimonies, under the knowne hands of my mot approved Counellors.

Sir, (aid Bertaldo) returne to your elf a little, were this true, none hould be her Executioner but my elfe, thee hands hould teare her limbe from limbe, but I can no more believe it than I can believe imposibilities.
Oh Bertaldo (aid Lorenzo) could I believe o too, I hould thinke my elfe herein more happy than in all my victories.

Sir, (aid Bertaldo) it is but conquering your elfe a little, and I will promie you a glorious victory over thee Enemies both to your hearts eae, and the tranquility of your minde: be Lorenzo once againe, and Bertaldo's yours for ever.
Bertaldo, (aid the Prince) I pray thee forgive me, and I will hope the bet: and turning to the Meenger that brought the Letters, he askt him his opinion, and what his thoughts were of Honoria.

Oh Sir, (replyde the ubtil Curre) it is not for me to have any thoughts, or give my opinion in a buinee o concerning; I was onely entruted with the afe conduct of thoe Letters, to your royall hand, which when I have performed, I have done my office: but I agree with you in my hopes of better atisfaction.
Sir, (aid Philoret) you would do well, as Maximanus hath ent one with Letters to informe, to end another with uch Letters as may make Enquiry, into the caue of thoe emisions.
Bertaldo gave his vote that none was more fit to be employd in that affair than Philoret, whom they had found both active, and ingenious upon all occaions.
Lorenzo agrees with him.

Philoret is dipatch'd, who, by the way, picks many caues of upition, out of the Meenger, entangling him o often in his dicoure, epecially in asking this Quetion, If Hortenius hath acted uch a villanie, and hath confes'd it, how comes he to be o much in favour with Maximanus? and receiving uch an anwer from him, vid: that favour mut not lat, I warrant you hall ee him come to a hamefull death ere it be long. Whereat Philoret demanded of him, What necesity there was in colloguing with uch a Villaine, after uch Witnees produced, and his owne confesion.

Oh (aid the Devils Adjutant Generall) Maximanus knowes well enough what he has to doe. Whereupon Philoret oone gathered, that there was more to be found out upon his arrivall at Court, where we leave him on his journey, and bring Lorenzo to his reting place: where leep had no ooner rockt his enes fat, but Amynda makes him tart with her gratitudes of Song and melody, where he thus begins:

l.hi: To tell you wherefore I am ent,

q.l: Honoria is innocent.
And o is Amaria too,

l.hi: And you must looke now what you doe,

q.l: Sullie not a Princes name,
By too much credulence to fame.

l.hi: Had he been otherwie to thee,

q.l: Thou hadt been pleas'd, he had been free.
But caue he's modet, chate, and wie,

l.hi: They have begun this Enterprie.

q.l: He that is eaie of belief,
Runs downe taires to meet a Thief.
Where jealouie's bed-chamber groome,
Fire's brought into th' Powder roome.
Up goes Husband, Friend, and Wife,
Crowne, and honour, Scepter, life.

div.p: Lorenzo ries in his hirt, and runs up and downe the roome like a mad man, raving on thoe fale Intelligencers, calling Maximanus, Traytour; Honoria, good; vowing to all the Gods, that he will never believe one word againt her; flings into his bed againe, cats his armes abroad, and ighs out this Pallinodium in her jutification, Oh Honoria, Honoria! how much have I injur'd thee! how much hat thou been abus'd by Villaines! I will recompence thy ufferings, with a thouand acknowledgments, and expiate my offence with the flower of my indulgence, ifted from the bran of thoe rude conceptions of thee, which lay too long in common, with my better thoughts: and o he fell into a weet lumber, bound about the head with thee reolves, where we leave him to returne to our affaires in Carthage.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Philoret falls acquainted with Hortenius by whom the villanie is dicovered. Pippea (a little Girle and Daughter to Maximanus his Landeree) teales into the Prion-Chamber where Honoria lay: the whole buinee dicovered, and found out by thoe three.

div.p:
IT happened that Pippea (too gracious a Child for uch a Mother, and too little to be upected for the managing of uch a buinee, as he went through with, (her age not bearing above 12 yeares date) Daughter to Hormunda one of his (both) pitifull and pittilee creatures, and Landree) tole one day into the Princees Chamber (all alone) being taught the way by following her Mother thither, (as he went and came, about her linnen employment) and (having heard the divers mutterings, that were in every month throughout the Court) making many pretty dops, and curtchees, as if he would feigne be poke to; or peake, if he knew how, or where to begin: which the Princee oberving, ask'd her, If her Mother was comming after her? to whom the little Girle, reply'd, No forooth: then (aid Honoria) I warrant thee thou art come to ee how I doe: whereat the little Girle fell a weeping very oarly: The Princee asked her, why he wept? he anwered, to thinke how much you are wrong'd Madame. Poore heart, art thou enible of my Injury (aid Honoria) if thou wert capable of undertanding, then thou wouldt weep indeed. Madame, (aid this pretty heart) I undertand a great deale already, and thereby am the better prepared to undertand the ret; I pray let me know how it is, I will remember what you ay, and if I can, I will help you, for all my Mother; he is gone into the Countrey, and will not come home till night: I knew where he put the key, and no body knowes where I am. The Princee finding her heart much eas'd by this little vent, and her complaints more to purpoe, than when he powred them againt the walls; he up, and told that mall Auditory, all the everall Paages, that were between Maximanus, and her elf, from the very beginning, to the end, (as is before related) and oone perceived (by the Girles earnetnee in litning to her dicoure, greedinee, in hearkning after more, her pertinent quetions, by the way, her letting fall o many howres of teares upon occaions, when the eaon of her dicoure required that moiture) that her language was not ill betow'd, and that the perpicuity of her minde had over-match'd the number of her yeares; wherefore thinking with her elfe what ue he might make of her, in vindicating her elfe from that oule aperion, he ask'd the Girle, And dot thou pitty me? Yes indeed Madam (aid Pippea.) And wouldt thou help me if thou couldt? (aid the Princee.) I with all my
heart (reply'd the pretty thing) if I knew which way. Honoria (who had no other thoughts, but thee; nor policy, (for the preent) but how he might preerve her honour after death, and embalme her memory when he was dead and gone) peakes thus unto that mall epitomy, (wherein all her worldly comforts were compris'd) My pretty weet Heart, if thou wilt doe one thing for me, God will blee thee, and thou halt never want his providence to defend thee from all wickednee. It is this my pretty Maid, Maximanus will certainly murder me one time or other. Whereat Pippea hreek'd aloud. Oh take heed (aid the Princee) omebody will heare you, and then you hall be ure never to ee me any more, and o I hall want my pretty Comforter. Madam, (aid Pippea) will not the ame God blee you alo, and his providence defend you from all wickednee? Blee me (aid Honoria) I hope he will, but defend me, it may be not; becaue it may be his pleaure that I may uffer, and I am contented to act any part that he hall put me to: in the meane time doe thou but act thine and I will pray for thee, and if I hould out-live my miery, thinke how kind thou hat been to me. The Girle ask'd the Princee, What it was he would have her doe? and if it were to be done, he needed not doubt of her good will, aying over and over againe, Madame, Ile doe it. Then aid Honoria, I will write a Letter which the Prince may read, when I am gone into another world, that hall tell him, how true I have been to him, whilt I lived in this: if thou wilt be o true to me, and kinde in this one requet, here is the key of my Cabinet, I pray thee take it, and I will write a Letter and thou halt conveigh it into my Cabinet, and when thou hat done, thou halt bring me the key againe, and I will breake it, and throw it away, and o when Maximanus cannot open it, he will not breake it open, and Lorenzo hall come to ee that, which it may be he may believe when I am dead, whatoever he may otherwie whilt I am alive; wilt thou doe o much for me? Yes, reply'd Pippea, who wept whilt Honoria writ this Letter.

body.p: OF a better fortune then to be abus'd by a perfidious Servant, to the detruction of his faithfull Wife, and ruine to his Honour, calling his name and widome into quetion: When I hall be Honoria in my Grave, and jutified (by the care that the Gods have over Innocents) when I am dead, who living, was not more grieved with all the tormes wherewith the revenging Tyrant vex'd my innocence, then I was troubled whilt I was alive, to think how thy injured Soul will be overwhelm'd with orrow, when the Gods hall bring to light this Horrid Treaon, againt the peace of thy inward tate, as a punihment of your too much forwardnee of belief. Could I have been fale to Lorenzo, it may be I hould not have been thought o, Greatnee would have protected me; but avoiding the act, I fell into the uppoition of Diloyalty, whereby goodnee uffer in my behalfe. Lorenzo, I forgive thee, upon this condition, that thou wilt not over-much afflict thy elfe with too much grief, when thou halt perceive thy Errour:

div.p: The Letter was upercrib'd for Lorenzo, Prince of Carthage: My Honoured Lord.
This Letter Honoria delivered to Pippea, who was as punctuall in her performance, as if her yeares had promis'd much dicretion.

By this time Philoret is come to Court whom (having put on her maiden habit, whereby he might be leat known in being liket her elfe, and the better conceal'd by leaving off her Diguie) we will call by her own name, Periia, who applies her elfe to Corderius (a true friend to Bertaldo, and a great rarity in Court, an nonet man) one who was ufficiently already atisfied of the great wrongs which Honoria had utain'd through the unjut uage of Maximanus? they two (having conferr'd notes together) thought fit, that he hould admit her into his houe as his Maid ervant, whereby he might conceal her elf the better: Thus Periia was diguis'd in the propriety of her own Habit.

Periia Hums about the Court like an indutrious Bee, dwelling longet upon that Flower where mot Honney was to be gather'd; amongt the ret, he finds Hortenius his dicoures (like beds) bet et with flowers of Invitation for her eeking faculty; him he Courts, and miles upon; her, he thinkes as halfe his own: he asketh her the quetion, he takes her ilence for conent. She makes ue of her Servants apprehenion, as a Mater-piece of Policy, telling him, that if he would but anwer her to own question truly, and olve but one doubt really, be hould oon know more of her mind: He vowes performance, and aures olution in any matter that he hould propound.

p.U: oon reply'd, my Quetion is, (as you are a true Lover) whether or no do you think that Honoria is innocent.

div.p: Hortenius fetching a deep igh, anwered, I would you were mine but halfe o ure.

And looking behind him, he told her, that no place was afe for that dicoure, where tones were laid together by the power of Art, nor would he trust Woods and Trees, but as they grew imply, and out of method: For (aid he) when the Square and Line is once drawn over them, I cannot believe, but that (thereby) they are conjur'd into intelligencers; and that their Buildings have pies in every corner. Therefore (Sweetheart) if you be pleas'd to repoe o much confidence in me, as to walke over the Meadowes, and to trut your elfe with a Faith that never blemiht its profeor into a place of Trust, I will tell you (by the way, and in the truty Groves) uch things (concerning the buines, wherein you would o faine be atisfied) as hall not leave you o much as a place for cruple.

Periia glad of this profeion, preently went along with him, where (by the way) Hortenius open'd his breat, and hewed her all the ecrets that were lockt up there, concerning the whole buinee, between Maximanus, and Honoria; himelf, and Maximanus; untill uch time as approaching the Tree where Bonella perihed in the Hollow (by reaon of the Secretaries perihing in the Dungeon.)
Periia (as if her divining Soul had bid her stand) makes a halt, and ayes, Will you tell me then Hortenius, if thee things be true, what can you expect but to be made away at lat, as the ret of his unhappy Instruments have been already? You that Act their part, mut have their Exit.
Truly (aid Hortenius) I look for no other.
Why will you tay here then (aid Periia.)

Hortenius cating his Eyes up towards the top of the Trees, he chanced to pie a Handkerchief, in which (it eemes) Bonella (finding her elf foraken, and buried alive in uch a growing Coffin) had wrought her mind in Needle-work, and bloudy Characters hadowed with Death, which he in her life time (having folded up with a double weight, both of Subtance and Signification) threw up to the place where he could not follow, which catching fat hold upon a Bough, let fall the ame friend that help'd it up, that it might the better hang out Maximanus his Villany, as upon a Signe-pot: And this was the Incription, viz.

body.p: HONORIA IS INNOCENT, I BETRAID HER, SHE AND AMARISSA VVERE CAST INTO A DEAD SLEEP, SO VVAS HORTENSIUS, AND LAID BETWEEN THEM: NOTHING TRUE IN HER ACCUSATION. HERE I VVAS PVT BY MAXIMANUS HIS SECRETARY; AND THIS HOLLOVV TREE CONTAINS A DEAD TESTIMONY OF A SAD TRVTH

div.p:
Hortenius and Periia having both read the Contents, were ufficiently rejoyc'd, and furnihed with ample atisfaction, they (having viewed the dead body) both returned to the place from whence they came, both reolving to be intruments of this dicovery; in order
whereunto they communed (by the way) about the manner of the accomplihment. Periia having brought Hortenius privily to Corderius his houe, he forthwith declares her elf to Hortenius to be Bertaldo his Page, hewing him her Apparel, her Letters of Credence; and calling upon Corderius to witnee (what he thought to be) truth: Hortenius oon quitted his amorous paion, and fell in love with the deigne. Corderius preently hatens them both away, with intructions, & ome other Intelligence (relating to dicoveries) which he himelf had lately found out in Honoria her behalf. So that they were both gone upon a uddaine. Maximanus miing his Engine, and gueing (rightly) that it would oon be employ'd againt himelf: and finding a great many of trange faces, with unwonted behaviours, daily looking upon him, thought it high time for him to look about: wherefore placing a trong Guard of confiding men to look well to the Princee, and keep the ret in aw, he himelfe makes all the peed he could to Moretania (where Lorenzo was) and ends Pot after Hortenius and Philoret (his uppoed Mitree) taking his flight as a matter of no mall conequence; o that they were both eiz'd upon at the Ferry ide (tay'd too long by contrary winds) by the Governour of Molocco, by vertue of Letters ent by Maximanus, charging them with the Highet Treaon, and o were put into afe Cutody, to attend the comming of Maximanus. Philoret then in Prion comforts up Hortenius, and betakes him to his old Stratagem (his Box of Oyntment) blacks his Face, alters his Habit, and o conveighs away his Letters and Intructions, together with himelfe (at noone day) o inviibly, as if he had carryed night about him; and o went unto the Governour himelfe, and preoccupies his undertanding with uch eaonable truthes, as his owne well-furnihed abilities and dexterity could eaily infue into a man who had not been poes'd with prejudice, nor by aed with interet to either party: and o acquainted the Governour with the hard hift that he was faine to make to come to peak with him, before the Tyrant Maximanus hould batter the Jutice of o good a Caue, with the engine of his fale pretences: whereupon he thruts his hand into a Baon of water, (that tood there by accident) and wahes and wipes the diguie from off his face. Whereupon the Governour aid unto him, That he had oberv'd many to have put a Good Face upon a bad Matter, but he never had oberv'd any to put a Bad Face upon a good Caue before. But the newes of Maximanus his arrivall, broke off all further dicoure: the Governour (doing that which he mot deir'd) dimis'd him to his Fellow prioner, promiing, That neither of them hould uffer the leat injury from him, by any meanes that Maximanus hould attempt: And that he would ee them afely brought to Lorenzo. He was no ooner departed the Roome, but Maximanus enters the houe, with uch prepared Invectives, and high Accuations againt Hortenius, that had not Philoret foretal'd his market, it might have very probably betray'd their Innocence
to hard uage. But withall, Maximanus told the Governour, That he could not tay to deire further favour at his hands, then that he would ecure them both till his returne; and then he would make known unto him his further deires concerning them. The Governour glad to hear him ay o, told him. That he would have a peciall care that they hould be forth-comming. So Maximanus poted away towards Lorenzo, whom after three dayes journey, he finds at Motoka, that was the Emperours Palace.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: Maximanus comes to Lorenzo's Court his disimulation, he perwades Lorenzo to go to atisfie his doubt to a Conjurer; whereupon he gives Maximanus Commision to kill Honoria and Amaria: the Governour of Molocco refues to yeild into his hands Hortentius and Periia.

div.p: NEwes being brought to Lorenzo, that Maximanus was arriv'd at Court, all were atonihed at the impudence of the man, who bare himelf high upon the confidence which he had of the Prince his favour towards him: but higher upon the trength of his owne braine, which he thought) tood him at any time, in tead of an Army, to ecure him from all emnity; nor did he a little relie upon his Oratory, able enough (in his owne conceit) to entangle no mall flies, within the fine pun cobweb of his fucetious Language.

Him, the Prince ends for, with much greedinee of deire to ee, as alo with a longing expectation to heare what he would ay of his Honoria: in he comes, Lorenzo receives him with much repect, Bertaldo with grinding teeth, he Bertaldo with great humanity: the Prince ask'd him, How he had left his affaires in Carthage? and what winde had blowne him thither? what was become of his Honoria? commanding an accompt of that particular, in the firt place.

Maximanus with much reverence, and more confidence peaks as followeth: Sir, if you will have me peake in a word, on my oule he's innocent: and I can no more imagine her to be otherwie, than I can uppoe the Sun's clarity, to be guilty of the ame blemihes wherewith the unconstant Moone eems potted. The good opinion I had of her virtue (to me) was uch, that I refus'd intelligence from mine owne eyes, and eares. Why (aid Bertaldo) what did you ee or heare, peake out your full meaning? Worthy Bertaldo, reply'd Maximanus, let not a truth offend you, that proceeds from the mouth of him, who is as great an Admirer of her worth and rare perfection, as if he were her Brother; but yet there were trange reports, tranger evidence, and demontration it elfe, was trangest of all. What demontration? (aid Bertaldo) what reports? and what evidence? why dost thou not tell us what they were?
Good Bertaldo (aid the Prince) forbeare, let him peake his minde. Worthy Bertaldo (aid Maximanus) give me leave to touch this ore, as gently as I may; I doe not tell you, that I believe any thing of all that I have heard, or what was witneed againt her, nor what I aw; but I believe that envy, and malice, have joyn'd iue, in the ame Conpiracy; I believe the Witnees were fale, and that there was more than honet craft us'd to bring thee things about, and that deluion had cat ome fale medium before our optick nerves, when we beheld the (uppoed) vile Hortenius, in the ame Bed, between Honoria and Amaria; of which there are divers Witnees, anwering the former Reports. Whereupon, Bertaldo, with much vehemence, cryes out, Thou Liet, and I'le jutifie it to be a Lie, wert thou a hundred Maximanus's. To whom Maximanus (gently) reply'd, Worthy Bertaldo, you need not, for Maximanus hath (in this buinee) given himelf the Lie oftner by many times; and is ready to write her Accuation fale with no other point but what this word hall willingly enable me a Subcriber to her innocence, with the blood of her Accuers; but how to reconcile the beliefe within me, to my outward enes, I cannot tell, if you'le have me weare he's honet, virtuous, loyall, chate, Ile doe it preently; or if (beyond beliefe) you'le have me ay I know it to be o, Ile ay, and weare that too; yet I have eyes and eares that gave me this intelligence, and yet I could never give them the leat credit. Sir, if he be not true to you, Ile loe my life; and if I have not een all this, with thee ame eyes, I am not Maximanus.

This peech, mingled in the ame headpiece, with o many truths, and falhoods, myterious expreions, and downright language, Riddles and Poitives, o tupified thoe two (of o neare relation as Huband and Brother) that they tood like o many enlee Statuaes, as if both their oules had uffered one ecclipe. Lorenzo firt recovering, as firt outed of himelfe, ask'd Maximanus, If there were not ome Witchcraft in't? or if ome deluion had not beguil'd their enes? Maximanus (as if he had been overjoy'd that the Prince had found it out) return'd this Anwer, that he rejoyced exceedingly, to ee, how the Prince had hit the ame nayle on the head, that he had been hammering at all this while; and if there were not Witchcraft in't, he durt endure all the torments, that the hades of endlee ret, with all their Hags and Furies thereunto belonging could inflict upon thoe Mortals, who wilfully doe fight againt the Gods.

Bertaldo began to be wonderfully pleas'd with this dicoure, Lorenzo (not) to be fully atisfied with his relation, and if Similitude may obtaine Pardon for the Homelinee of the Comparion, I may tell you, that thee two Princes, retir'd themelves, for Solitude, into everall Corners, like thoe inferiour creatures, who having got between their teeth ome huge and mighty bone (though there be never o little meat upon't) yet run away with it into ome corner or other, there privately to gnaw upon that, which hame would not permit them to manage (o) in Publique, and at lat are faine to leave it,
finding their hunger, more exaperated with toyle and labour, than their bellies atisfied with utenance; o fruitlee was their fumbling at this Gordian Knot, whilt Maximanus laughes in his leeve to thinke into what Dumps his omnipotent braine had cat thee Sonnes of the Almighty.
At lat (watching his opportunity) he findes Lorenzo all alone, and much perplex'd, whoe troubled mind he appeaes with a remedy wore then the dieae.

Sir (aid he) what need you vex your oul with thee anxieties? Know you not that there is a Man whom all Affrica admires for his rare Art, and Skill, in repreenting to the inquiitive view of any man (that hath a deire to know) what things have pat between mortall creatures relating to any concernment? Hath not your Victories pread your Glory over the place of his Nativity? And will you make o little ue of your Conquet, as not to lay uch Commands upon him, as will quickly olve all doubts, and et us all to rights, who are thus bewildred in the maze and labyrinth of thee turnings and windings of our retlee thoughts? Honoria deerves that you hould ue the meanes to quit your elfe of thee vaine Jealouies and feares. For on my oule hee is as Chat as ever the hee-turtle dove, can be unto her mate. Though I could not top my Eares, nor hut mine Eyes, againt thoe things which I both aw, and heard: I hould be as glad to be atisfied my elfe, as you; aliis rebus pietatem colas, we mut et orcery and witchcraft together by the eares, if the ervants play the jack, we mut complaine unto the Mater Devill. I had rather be brought into Paradie againe, by his meanes, then to carry uch a Hell within my boome for want of a little haking hands with the Devill. Pardon me Sir, if I venture too boldly in my advice, eeing my love cannot endure to ee you in uch a torme, as is ready to make Shipwrack of all your happinee, and to overwhelme all your glory, in the depresion of the greatet of your contentments. Whereupon Lorenzo tops his further peaking with Embracements; crying over and over againe, Honet Maximanus! how much am I beholding unto thee? Who would have done this for me beides thy elfe? thou hat eas'd me already, let the event be what it will. I hall know the truth, that's omething; nay, that's all: For if he be true, and faithfull to me, my heart's at ret: If he be fale, yet I am atisfied in this, that I cannot wrong her whatoere I doe. Wherefore I will not endure another dayes torment to gaine all Affrica. Prepare your elf to goe along with me, I will be ready this night by ten of the Clock at the Park-gate all alone, there meet me privately; none hall know where we have been, or what we have done.
Then (aid Maximanus) what great matter is't for us to teal our Quietus et, out of the Devils Office?
Thou ayet right Maximanus (aid the Prince) honet, honet Maximanus, how much am I beholding unto thee!

In comes Bertaldo whilt they were in this dicoure, whom Maximanus epying, patches up his dicoure with a piece of a clean
contrary colour, aying: Sir, I would not mitrut that woman to gaine the world; if you doe, you doe your elfe a great deal of wrong. Bertaldo aluted Maximanus very kindly, eeing Lorenzo look o cheerfully, whom he hoped (by this time) to be dipoes'd of that peaking Devill, Jealouie, by ome Exercime that Maximanus had then us'd, all was well, all were merry and joviall, a ine time, if it would hold: But alas, this was but that which we call lightning before death; mirth, before orrow; and laughter, before detruction. The time appointed is already come, wherein Lorenzo and Maximanus were to meet, who both kept touch with one another (as uch meetings eldome faile) they accoted (betimes in the morning at the Caves mouth) this Mandragora (the Devils Corn-cutter) who (when he has you by the foot, can eaily tell you where the hooe wri ••• ) invites them into his Den in this language: Sons of Curioity, why tand ye gazing in the open aire? decend, and atisfie your longings in thoe demands wherein you would be atisfied, and I hall repreent the naked truth before your eyes, re-acted as at firt it was. Now this Tredeskin of all natures ecrets (who muters up his rarities, and draws them up in a Parade, fitting them for ervice) was richly bribed by Maximanus to preent Honoria unto his view, in uch uneemly potures with Hortenius, as might well bereave him o of all his enes, that he might eaily drive him into mot horrid and cruell reolutions againt Honoria.

Forthwith Maximanus leads the innocent Lorenzo by the hand down into the Cave (like the venemous Spider, who once having entangled the harmlee illy Flie within his Web, he drags him into his hole to torment, and there devour him) who having thus wilfully foraken the light, and condecended to thoe deeds of darknes. Apollio, the Devils Engineer, takes a Cuhion in his hand tuffed with Moe, that had been gathered off of dead mens Sculs, and claps it downe into a Chair, whoe eat was oftned with dead mens hair, legg'd and arm'd with dead mens Bones, and covered with their Skinnes: and bids Lorenzo to it downe: Telling him, that now he is come there, he mut doe as the place requires.

Then he falls to his conjuring termes, and circulations, which when he had throughly perform'd, he queezes out of a bottle a glae of water, or juice, that was extracted, and ditill'd out of no other herb, or imple, but that which we (uually) call Jewes-eares; this he bids Lorenzo drink, till telling him, that now he is come there, he mut needs doe as the place requires.

Lorenzo neither knowing what he did, nor yet what farther injunctions might be required at his hands, once wih'd he had not put himelfe under a power wherein he was o ignorant of the danger of the diobedience; the frighted judgment of his brain (that then was ray'd with his own hair, tanding tiffe an end, like ported feathers of ome Porcupine) told him, That now he was gone o farre, it was no widome, and perhaps, no afety to retire. Wherefore he drank it off,
then Apollio takes the milk of the Hienna, which he held out to him in a little cup, whoe materiall was a dry'd and well wrought Toadtool, which this Apollio called Eye-bright Water, willing him to wah his eyes therewith, not forgetting to tell him, That now he was come there, he mut needs doe as the place requir'd. Which he obeys. Thee two Informers thus ufficiently corrupted, they could preently hear a fearfull noie, as that of Waters, falling downe their Precipice; then another like that of Thunder; afterwards a hollow ound, reembling that which men doe ue to hear immediately after Earthquakes: And at lat, a ruling noie like flames of Fire, after they have newly made their eruptions out of their mothers womb. Apollio cryes ilence to the four Elements, and all obey: Forthwith they might hear the language of Court-hips, the macks of Kies, the clapping of Cheeks, and the laughing at Jets: And thee o Acted to the life, that Lorenzo might eaily uppoe them to be Honoria's words & laughter before he aw her. Then he might ee Honoria with Hortenius his Armes about her Neck, and hers about his Middle, entring a loof, and after thoe lacivious potures that were between them, more uncivil then fitting to be expres'd: He beheld Hortenius throwing her downe againt a Flowry bank, committing thoe non dicenda's, which my Pen cannot be guilty of the relation; inomuch that Lorenzo's fancy was o trong, that his imagination thought it o reall, as that he drew his Sword, and would have executed vengeance upon a delinquency that never had a being, but in the Hiennas milk that had wah'd his Eyes, had not Apollio with his black rod forbade the enterprie by a wated prohibition over the Prince his Head. Lorenzo cryes aloud, I have eene enough, and will be reveng'd for what I've eene. Apollio Brandihes his Black Rod againe, and tells him, He mut ee all with patience now he is there, and be as much dipleas'd afterwards as the caue required.

Lorenzo was now vexed that he mut ee more, and have (for the preent) no other ubject (but a Type) to wreak his fury on: In dicontent he flings himelfe downe into the Chaire, in uch diorderly method, that he brake the legs and armes thereof, recovering himelfe from the fall, with bruiing his right hand, which was a good Omen, viz. that at lat he hould break the bones of that deluion wherein he had eated himelf by uch perwaion, and recover himelf by the cruh of Maximanus. Now the cene is altered, and there appeares a faire goodly Chamber, with a Rich Bed, which Lorenzo remembred (well enough) exactly to et forth his owne. Apollio with his Charming intrument drawes open the Curtaines; o that Lorenzo plainly aw Hortenius (between Honoria and Amaria) kiing Honoria and Amaria (with violent hands) natching the kies (head and all) from the embracing Armes of (the as much Beautifull, as abus'd) Honoria; together with ome other Non-credenda's that were not to be believ'd by any, but by uch as had learn'd their Creed out of the Devils Chatechime. Lorenzo having
oberv'd too much by all: Leaves that Hellih darknee for the Heavenly Light; and wears by the true ubtance of that hadow, that he will be everely reveng'd upon that foul Abue, and fair Adultree: aying, That this was Amaria's pightfulnee towards him, to Bawd out her revenge for his uppoed for aking of her, but he would be quit with her. Preently Signing to both their Deaths under his owne Hand, written againt the Shoulder of Maximanus, that was broad enough to bear o great injuries to others, whilt they were o narrow in his owne behalfe, that they were not able to upport the burthen of a Chat deniall.
Thus the lat Act being ended, Lorenzo having poke the Epilogue, Maximanus gives the Plaudite in thee words:

p.hi: As long as there was any favourable posibility of beating back a belief, that forc'd it elf o violently upon me (you know) I did withtand it, but now I mut give way, and applaud your reolution.

div.p: Maximanus (aid Lorenzo) thou art too good, and I too happy in uch a Friend; crown all thy other ervices with thy obedience to this one Command: look that they doe not live longer then the time that thou halt be Riding Pote to Carthage, hall defer the Execution, and that it may be the ooner done, make hate to Hore. O Whores, and hatefull pieces of Woman-kind, I am orry you have but one life apiece to loe. Make hate Maximanus, I pray thee make hate.
Sir (aid Maximanus) what will you doe with Bertaldo? if you doe not make ure of him, you'l finde a Canker in your boome.
Maximanus (aid Lorenzo) be ure I'le pare his Nailes, and knock the teeth out of his Head when firt I meet him.
Maximanus, good Maximanus, (aid Lorenzo) wilt thou make all the hate thou canst, and let me hear from thee as oone as ere thou cant that they are dead.
So they both parted, the one with a laugh in his Sleeve, the other with a flea in his Ear.

Lorenzo returning from his Purgatory, to his Palace, Bertaldo could not be long out of his ight, but alutes him in this language: How fares the Prince? we thought that we had lot you, none could tell what was become of you.
Lorenzo gives him this ullen reply, It may be o, what of that?
Bertaldo asked him, what was become of Maximanus?
Lorenzo told him, that Maximanus was, where Maximanus hould be, about his buinee.

Bertaldo (uppoing that Maximanus (having engroed him to himelf all that time of abence) had put him into this bad humour) told him, That he beleeved that Maximanus had done ill Offices betweene him and his Sister; wihing him to beware how he uffered himelfe to be abus'd by uch an intrument.

As your Siter (aid Lorenzo) who could play the Hypocrite o finely when I was there, and the Whore o cunningly when I was gone. The
truth whereof, ince I aw you last, I have been fully atisfied. You have been fully injur'd (aid Bertaldo) and not atisfied: by him you could not, who was unatisfied himelfe: 'tis he has play'd the Hypocrite, and is the bad Intrument that makes this dicord in the Harmony that hould be between Man and Wife, Friend and Friend. Lorenzo remember how you had once forgot your elfe before, and acknowledg'd your own Errour.
It was an Errour that I acknowledg'd it to be o, (aid Lorenzo) but now my judgement tands on better termes.
No, on worer Grounds, reply'd Bertaldo.
Bertaldo lyes, reply'd the Prince.

Whereat Bertaldo having lot all patience, told him, That neither the Guard of his Peron, nor his Conquering Army, hould any longer confine his Soul from her Enlargement; but that he durt tell him to his face, that he was unworthy of her, and his un-princely behaviour towards her undeerving of the least perfection in her.

Whereat they both drew their Swords upon one another, and began to lay on blowes: Codruball and Hanno tanding by would not uffer it, but lay'd hands upon Bertaldo, perwaions upon Lorenzo, neither prevailing: The Prince his Guard was call'd, and eiz'd upon Bertaldo, who by Command was committed a cloe Prioner. Lorenzo till raving againt Honoria and Amaria, with no mall threatnings againt Bertaldo. The night (comming on) that hould have given him ret, adminiters new matter of diquietnee; for Aminda's (now) angry Genius gives him this Curtain-lecture as a cooling Card to his over-boyling Rage.

q.l: Nor loe of Friends, nor the ped hate
Of Enemies, hall expiate

l.hi: This horrid Act that thou hast done;

q.l: To lay Wife, Mother, and a Sonne

l.hi: Thou knew't not of. O vile intent

q.l: To Murder Three, and all Three innocent!
And Amaria, thy true Friend, and hers:

l.hi: O Cruell, Bloudy, Murderers!

q.l: She uffers Martyrdome for you,
You perecute your Martyr too.
Nourih a Viper, Lick up Gaul;
Through down your Young one, Net and all.
The Moores hall punih this thy Sin,

l.hi: And ad Repentance wound within.

p.U: tarts out of his Bed, and raves about the Roome, tearing his Hair, on whom Aminda betowes this ad farewell:
