q.l: Rave on, but er't be long, you'l runne
Madder, to think what you have done.

div.p: Lorenzo cryes out, Oh ye powers above, and ye below! why doe ye rack me thus? why doe you not agree upon your Principles, and draw me (o but one way) which you will? can no eae helter a minde from being baited thus? or are both powers agreed to play at Foot-ball with a mortall Creature? Then flings into his Bed, kicks away the Cloathes, pulls them on againe; falls from retlee thoughts, into unquiet lumbers: And from thence, into the fearfullet Dreames, out of which he was at lat awakened with a greater Terrour. For Berontus brought Intelligence that the Moores had beaten up the Out-quarters of the Army, appearing like clouds that hung upon the Mountains, where we leave him for a while in his ditracted thoughts of preparation againt o great an Army, to haten after Maximanus, that we may oberve how he propers in his Affaires.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Maximanus is deny'd the Rendition of the two Prioners, Hortenius and Philoret. The Governour ends them both to Lorenzo. Maximanus comming to Carthage, thinking to bring Honoria and Amaria to their Trials, is reited by Corderius. He ends them both to be murdered privately; and the event.

div.p: MAximanus riding pot to the Garrion, where he had left Hortenius and Philoret, in as great hate demands the Prioners of the Governour, who (as hort as he) tells him, that he is none of his Vaall, neither his Maters Subject, and that he would end them to Lorenzo, according to their intructions, and their owne deires. Intructions, aid Maximanus, I pray from whom? I am not bound to tell you (aid the Governour.) Maximanus began to mell a Rat, and thought it high time to looke about him, and to make hate with his Execution, for fear of a Reprieve: nonuited, he departs uddenly for Carthage, and the Governour ends his Wards to Mauritania, and brings them partly on their way, where we leave them, and haten after Maximanus, whom we have now overtaken, within the Walls of Carthage.

He was no ooner there, but he hatens on the Triall, but he is reited by the major part of the Nobility, and epecially by Corderius, who told him plainly, that though he was the Chiefe, yet he was but one, and that there were trange rumours in the Court, that forbade thoe undertakings, till the Prince return'd, requiring the Prioners more Enlargement and better Uage. Maximanus remembring that his Commiion was to kill and lay, (rather than to bring to triall) he reolves to put it in Execution any way, and not to init at all upon the forme; wherefore he prepares two bloody Villaines to carry
thee two Innocents, privily, by night, into the Wood, and there to Murder them: they receive their Wages, and goe about their worke. Honoria and Amaria (not having een one another many a day) now ee themelves both carried (like two heep) unto the laughter; they wept on one another, but were oone parted, and dragg'd away by night into the Wood, (the Moone hining bright) wherein, they were no ooner entred, but one of the Murderers told them that they mut die. With all my heart, when you pleae, reply'd Honoria, but did you know the wrong I uffer, I know you would not doe it for the world; but becaue it is imposible for me, to make you believe otherwie, I will urge you no further. Are you prepar'd? aid one of the Villaines. Alas! aid Honoria, my five months imprionment, hath been nothing ele but a preparation for this end. Why, aid the other (beginning a little to relent) are you innocent? will you take it upon your death? I doe, I will, reply'd Honoria. Harke ye, aid Amaria, o will I, and as ure as ye are Men, o ure are we both innocent, o ure goe I a Virgin to my Grave, o ure is Prince Lorenzo's Bed untain'd and undefiled by the chate Honoria. Maximanus doth all this, becaue he would not yeild to him, in that, for which, he now detroyes us both: you cannot be ignorant of the reports in every mouth, throughout the Court, of a leeping Drinke, that was given us, to keep us fast enough from waking, whilt the innocent Hortenius drunke with the ame brine, hould enlely be laid between us, nor of Bonella and the Secretary (both Agents in the ame deigne) both made away, for feare of telling tales: you cannot be ignorant of Hortenius and Bertaldo's Page, both ent unto Lorenzo, to acquaint him with the buinee, who by this time are farre enough out of Maximanus his clutches; you cannot imagine but that Lorenzo will be hortly here, and oone enform'd of thee particulars; but (then) too late, when we are murder'd by you.

Good Fellowes, let me tell you what you hall doe, I know, that what you doe, you doe for money; follow but my advice, ye hall be rich enough, highly rewarded, and promoted for your ervice, preerve us but for a while, and ay that you have murdered us; have you no friends with whom you may repoe o great a confidence? and if (upon Lorenzo's returne) you doe not finde us cleared and lamented beyond imagination, then come and doe your office; but if you finde it, as I'm ure you hall, what thanks, what praies, what rewards will be thought too great for uch a preervation?

Navigius (one of the Villaines) a Sea-man by profeion, began to thinke it both piety and policy; the other Blood-hound cry'd, Let's doe our worke, we came not here to hear them prate. But heark you, (aid the other to his Fellow) uppoe that all this be true, I aure you there are a great many that doe believe it. Suppoe you are Fool'd, (aid the other) with a Womans tears & language, mut I be o too? True or fale, Ile doe as I was commanded: and forthwith drawes his Sword, and was falling to his worke. Which the other perceiving, drawes too, and bids him hold a little, the two Innocents get behind the Sea-man:
the other wearing, that he would come at them, or he would make his way through Navigius his ides. The Sea-man (partly with choller, partly with pitty, and partly with a kinde of ence of honour, how brave a thing it would be for him to be the Preerver of thoe two Ladyes, and have all the glory to himelfe) undertakes their quarrell, they both fight, and Amaria perceiving that their Friend was likeliet to be worted, he takes off her Scarfe and ruffles it up in a heap, & throws it in the others eyes, whilt the Sea-man runs him through the body, that downe he fell, and dyed immediately. Whereupon the two Ladyes (like two Hens that cluck about their fighting Cock after that he hath got the victory) applaud his Valour, he Amaria's Policy, and tells Honoria, how that he was a Sea-man by his profesion, and that he was Partner of uch a Ship, that rode in uch a Bay, that was not very farre off, and how that the winde tood faire for the Iland of Majorca, and that thither he would carry them, where they hould expect for better fortune. They were ravih'd with joy, for this good newes, calling upon him to make hate, thinking themelves beholding to the Moone who firt gave them light, to be their asitant, and then went downe, as conniving at their departure.

They were both hipt, and under ayle, the ayles carried them upon their wings, to their deired Harbour in the greater Iland of Majorca, but it is impoible for a Darke grey ever to make a True blew, o the Gallantry that was worded into this man, could not but a little favour of the caske wherein it was infus'd, for as he tumbled upon an act of honour, o he tripp'd in his thorow pace to true magnanimity & Gallantry, for he was no ooner landed in the Iland, but he offers up their beauties to ale and protitution, for bae lucre ake: Honoria is oone bought by Thoron, great Commander of the Iland; Amaria perceiving which way he was going, betakes her to the wit that never fail'd her in her extremity, telling her Chapman that if he mut be old he mut obey, and that there was a rich and wealthy man, who was an inhabitant in the Ile Minorca, who was a great Suitor to her formerly for a piece of ome Dihonety, and that he offered her a thouand Crownes for her Virginity; the latter I have till, (aid he) the former is at your commands, if you doe but bring me thither; if you cannot make more of me here, I hope you will thinke it widome to carry me thither. This Gentleman (whom he meant, and whoe name was Castriot) was her owne Unkle, thither he deludes this Ainego to the preervation of her owne Honour, and Honoria's; for he had no ooner brought her thither, but he tells her Unkle the whole tory, who did him no hurt for the good-ake which he had done, and no great good for the evil ake which he intended. Catriot preently writ to Thoron (his great acquaintance and peciall friend) what Civilities he hould ue to a Peron of o great quality as was Honoria, who had not as yet dicovered her Condition unto Thoron (being (craftily) told by Navigius, that if he did reveale her elf, he hould certainly be betray'd into Maximanus his Cutody by Thoron, who two were all one) and yet preerv'd her
elf from his contagion by this tratagem. She pretends her elf to be a Maid, and begs hard, that his pleaure might be upended but for three dayes; the third day being come, he entreats (for modety ake) that he would meet her in the darke; he grants her requet, and all, to obtaine her good will, as well as her elfe; he appointed her the place where he hould goe, which was, to a pacious Roome, where was no light at all; he followes her, who had lipt off her hooes againt his comming, who (entring the Roome) ask'd her where he was? he anwered, here my Lord: he advancing towards the voice, he traveres her ground, and was not to be found; he ask'd her againe, where art thou? he teps aide againe, and aid, I am here, why don't you come? why where, aid Thoron: Here I tell you, aid Honoria: till waving his approach till he had kept him in that poture two long houres, till at lat he was glad that he had found the dore, and hutting her in, he fetches a candle, which he brings with him in his hand, and enters the Roome the econd time, asking her, why he us'd him in that manner? To let you ee (reply'd Honoria) what a vanity it is that you hunt after; Beauty is but skin deep, and that skin you could not tell how to touch without being beholding to o poore an acceary as the light of a Candle: Cotton, and Tallow, are fine ingredients, to be of the Eence of your amorous Pasion; for, you ee without them, you were as farre from laying hands, as eyes upon the object of your delight, which is not o much reall, as it is imaginary; nor is it o much as valuable by imagination neither, but by accident, like glae or ice, that have no lutre in themelves, but by reflection of a econd caue: Alas! this thing which you call Beauty wherewith you men are o tranported, is but differenc'd from Deformity, like the glitring rayes of Steele and Iron, that's till the ame in ubstance, worth, and quality, with that which is but ruty: Alas! what is this inconiderate thing called Beauty? a thing not qualified with o much virtue as are everall tones, alt-water, or rotten wood: Nay, the beautifullet outide of Woman-kind has not thoe priviledges, that nature hath betowed upon the cales of fihes, or the eyes of catts, all thee have their excellencies viibility in the darke, but you could neither ee, nor finde, nor touch, nor take your pleaure, but by ome other meanes, which was neither in your elfe, nor me; wherefore if you will be rightly in love, be not in love with Accidents, but with that ubtance, to which light it elfe is but a hadow. The oule that forakes the Divine love, and gives it to the Creature, is like the illy Chicken, who having lot his parent, followes after the next creature that it meets withall; your love is but miplac'd; Oh! how admirably would you love the Gods? how well betow'd were that affection? yet I wil not deny but that there is a lawfull, and true love proper between Man and Woman; but withall, there is an idoneity in placing that affection, it must not be fixt upon an illicit object, uch a one, as I am to all mankinde, that are affected with the awefulnee of a deity, having vow'd my elfe, a Vetall Virgin: Wherefore make your retreat as honorable as you can, and let your behaviour be uch, to your poore Servant, as becomming the honour of your Ancestory, and a patterne of true piety, and virtue.

Thoron fell from being in love with her peron, to be much affected with the rare perfection of her minde; And as well becomming the imitation of a true Convertite, he gives himelfe to reignation in thoe things, which her divine Reaons had fore-dictated unto him, bidding her henceforward to feare no wore events but what her owne Commands hould lay upon him, and the rest that then were under his Authoritie.

But there happened a very merry paage (occaioned by Thoron's familiarity and o much courting of Honoria) between the aid Thoron and his Wife Armena, who being a Woman of a high Spirit, and one that had formerly got the matery of two Husbands, and had oftentimes bid faire for this, but found that the god Mercury was not to be made of every piece of wood, and that this was of too cros-grain'd a dipoition for all her art and tooles to engraven a imilitude of any of the former out of either of the originalls, for this was a notable man at curbing a woman, howoever the often attemptings hereof had been the occaion not onely of much difference, but oftentimes of ome hard uage towards Armena, which at this time (by reaon of Thoron's dayly addrees and uppoed intimacy with Honoria, together with her didaine and jealouie thereupon) was much aggravated, for he drew upon her elf heapt meaures of his rage and fury, for he was no lee liberall with his tongue in his uneemly language againt her, but his hands were alo omewhat heavy upon her, which he had no ooner perform'd, but he vow'd he would be reveng'd, calling him, Coward and bae Fellow to trike a Woman, telling him, that it is pitty but that there hould be a Law to make it death to any one that hould trike a Woman that had never truck a Man (which words unk the deeper into his cogitation, being o well fatned to the weight of his owne guiltinee) bidding him looke to it, telling him, that if he could not get Men and Women enough to take her part, he would et Dogs upon him but he would be reveng'd, and never would put up o foule and unmanlike an affront upon a Woman of her quality: and forthwith flung out of the roome.

Thoron knowing her high pirit, great friends, and remembring how (mot commonly) he us'd to be as good as her word, believ'd no lee, but fear'd as much; he could wih it undone, but could not tell how to help it: would fain have been friends with her, but knew not how: he cat about, in what manner he might load her vengeance on his back, yet not breake it, 'caue ome trembling in his joynts, but breake no bones; her fury rather inventing ome witty tratagem of revenge, than conulting with any malice that was implacable; he (diving into her Husbands dipoition, and finding it but of omwhat an inferiour alay in point of magnanimity) reolves upon an adventure, no lee anwerable to the fulnee of her atisfaction, than innocent in the proecution thereof, and thus he layes her plot: he ends to Fanor, one in whom he repoed much confidence, and knew to be one whom Thoron had a good opinion of, him he acquaints
with the falling out between her and her Husband, pretends a great deire to be reconcil'd: Fanor was very deirous to performe o good an office between them; he prevents his eeking braine, with what he had prepared out of her own invention, and thus far he acquaints him with her deigne. Fanor (aith he) I thinke I need not tell you of the difference that is between my Lord and I, he abus'd me, and gave him as good as he brought; yet howoever it is not fit that Man and Wife hould continue long at uch a ditance, I believe he would be willing enough to be reconcil'd, but his tomack will not come downe; and I could finde in my heart to kie and be friends, but I cannot abide to eek to him, o that the trife between us two is onely this,

q.l: I tout, and thou tout,
And who hall carry the dirt out?

div.p: Wherefore, honest Fanor, I would have thee doe thus, Invite us both to Supper, and ome others, whoe company thou knowet will be mot pleaing to him, (I will be at all the Charges) and let me have the bet Muick that may be had for money. Here Fanor began to interrupt Armena, aying, Madame, by no meanes, you both have not been o paring in your obligations, nor your benefits o lenderly perform'd in the behalf of your humble Servant, as that he hould not be as willing as able to depoit uch a pledge of gratitude without any uch Indentures. No, no, good Fanor, (aid Armena) it must not be o, I mut have my will, the reaons you hall know hereafter, and the houe and managery of the whole buinee you hall leave to me: doe you goe and invite him, and tell him, that your intention is to doe the like to me, and then let me heare what he ayes, and you hall know more of my minde hereafter.

Away goes Fanor to Thoron, and acquaints him with his deires. Thoron, glad of this opportunity, tells Fanor, that He could not have done him a greater pleaure, for at this time (aid Thoron) there is a little falling out between me and my Wife, and a third place and trange company will be the onely meanes to take away that trangenee that is between us, where both of us hall be apt to fall into our former familiarity through hame that any notice hould be taken of its being otherwie, let it be a hame unto us both; and where merriment may haply put her into a good humour: but dot thou think thou cant prevaile with her?
Leave that to me, (aid Fanor) on my life he hall goe with you. I pray thee doe, aid Thoron.
Away went Fanor to Armena, and acquainted her with all that had pas'd between her Lord and him.

Armena ininuates her deigne to Fanor's approbation, which thus he put in execution: The time being come when it was time to goe, and Thoron already mounted in his Caroach, word was brought the Lady Armena that my Lord taid for her; he begins her mall revenge with letting him wait a little: yet ever and anon ending him word that he was comming, making her tiring of his patience to act the firt
part of her Comedy; at lat he comes handed by Fanor, and as he drew neare the Caroach, Thoron would faine have poken to her, if he knew how; and angrily, if he durt: Come, come, was all he aid: thoe two words (he thought) bated not one inch of his pirit, and yet he inulted not a little (inwardly) that they were uch words, and o poken, as might very well imply an indignation: but Armena being ready to tep into the Caroach, beheld him with uch a prightly countenance, and piercing eye, that his dull ones (as if two bullets had been fixt in clay) inform'd his timorous oule, that they beheld armed men in womans eyes: whereupon, he bethought himelfe of an honourable retreat (if he hould be charged with any hatinee of peech, or roughnee of language) and how he might afely bring thoe two words off againe (if occaion erv'd) with the afe conducts, of excue, and kindnee. But, Armena fearing to poile the game he was now playing with too much forwardnee, reolv'd, to ue no other catigation for the preent, but her looks: wherefore, without peaking a word unto him, he acends the Caroach. Thoron, that he might, and might not eem to help her up, reaches out his hand, but never o much as touch'd her; he thought he could doe no lee than what he found to be nothing at all. The time which the Caroacheer allow'd himelfe for etting forward eem'd tedious to them both, whilt neither of them knew how to behave themelves to one another, otherwie then in etling themelves; which they were both longer about, then either of them needed, protracting the time with uch antick behaviours, untill the language of the whip, caued the wel-manag'd hores, to make tones, and wheels, upply the place of oratory, until uch time as they came to the place where they were to light; and then they were to eek againe. Thoron firt decends the Caroach, after him, Fanor: whom, when Thoron had epied almot ingag'd in the ervice of leading his Lady by the arme, he made a kinde of offer as if he would (if Fanor had not) have been o kind. Armena eeing the repect he lookt for, approaching a farre off, waves the former; and expects the advance of her Husbands courteie: he o far on in his way, knew not how to recall himelfe, but goes thorow with it, and leads her by the arme, through a Court which (on both ides in the pav'd walks) was fill'd with ome of his acquaintance, but all her friends: who aluted them both at a ditance, and no more, (as he had laid the plot) up taires he leades her, Fanor leaves them both, into a pacious goodly Roome he brought him, no body there, the aying of the cloath, the many trenchers, and napkins, pake many Guets; but his expectation wondred at the olitude, and her ilence, (together with the feare of what he aw without) had put him into uch a perplexity that it made uch a throng of confued thoughts within his breat, that when he trove to give them ayre, they wedg'd themelves o in the dore of utterance, that a word could not come forth.

Now you mut undertand that Armena had o laid the plot that
the Muitians (our of a Muick Roome over head inviible) had Command given them, that as oone as ever the Lady Armena hould peak the word DRAW, that then they were to trike up: and (for the greater Terrour ake) the Leon, which was call'd the BATTAIL; and thereupon a mighty noie and butling was heard at the back Door and Entry that led into the Dining Room; with ome other preparations and performances requiite to the deigne he had in hand. All things thus in a readinee, and his body ufficiently prepar'd for the operation of uch Phyick, he thus begins to act her part:

You know who I am; neither am I ignorant of the uttermot of your Worth and Merit: you know upon what termes you took me, and what you promis'd, and how you have abus'd me, contrary to all Faith and Honety, contrary to all Civility and Man-hood: think you that my Fathers Daughter can put up uch injuries as thee at Thorons hands?

No Sir, you hall now know, that you are in my power, and find that I can ue you according to your demerits. Draw (aid Armena) forthwith the Muick truck up, immediately whereupon there was heard uch a noie of clattering of Armour together, clahing of Swords one againt another; uch duplications, and re-duplications of Blowes: And to compleat all Terrour, a mot fearfull noie of many verberations, and re-verberations of o many tripes (as it were) of Cudgels over the houlders of unarmed Men. Armena in the next roome having placed ten luty Fellowes (at the ame time) to be there beating the dut out of a piece of Hangings; And to make the Fury the more formidable, he had ordained certaine men to dah huge and mighty Earthen Pitchers againt the wall, as if mens Braines were beating out, and the pieces of their Sculs flying about the roome. In which interim (in everall places) high words were at Variance; Vehement language in hot Skirmih; Down with him ayes one; Enter, enter, aith another; Hold, hold, aith a third; We will have him aith a fourth. All this while Thoron tood in a maze, Armena with her Armes a kimbo, laughing in his face all the while; but at lat, when the Terrour had made its approach up to the very Doore, and they all cryed, Fall on, fall on, fall on, (as if the Aainats had got the victory) away runs Thoron down the taires, (the only way from whence appear'd (as yet) no horrour) Armena after him, when behold! he was not half way down the taires, but he beheld men all in Armour, with ported Halberts at his breat: Thoron makes a tand, and by this time the Furious Butle was got into the Dining Roome, as if it threatned an execution into attomes. Armena finding her Husband by this time in a ufficient extaie, cryed to him, My Lord, my Lord, you have no way in the world to ave your Life, but to throw your elfe upon my mercy, and aske me forgivenee.

That joyfull word, and comfortable aying, open'd his Mouth; who, upon his knees, cryes unto her with elevated and wrung hands
together, Dearet Love, good Wife, weet Armena, pare my life but this time, and I will never offend thee more! O peak to them Armena! peak to them good Armena! Lot them not come up, keep them from comming downe; I will deerve your mercy, and you hall have your will for evermore.

Armena having brought her Deigne to full perfection, call'd him to her, aying, Come hither, come hither my Lord, quickly, quickly, quickly. Thoron ries up, and askes her where? Where for the love of God? Here (aid Armena) Lie downe here (placing him in a corner of the Staires, cloe behind her) whilt he beckons with her Hand, (which was the Signe that they hould be gone) who being vanihed by degrees, he bids him get up, and follow her, and fear nothing (being very deirous to make as hort work with him as he could, he melt o trongly of the running dieae) he followes her with his Eyes wandring about, let any part of the Enemy hould lie in Ambuh, and urprize him, before he could call for uccour to Armena; and never thought himelf afe untill he had brought him under Lock and Key, where he read him this Lecture:

You ee how that you are more afraid then hurt, and that there was more Sport then Harme in my Revenge: You ee I can play with you and yet not hurt you; and, if it be not your own fault, you hall find, that I can Jet with you, and Shame you not. For I protet unto you, there is none of all thoe Swah-bucklers, or Halbertiers, that knew the leat particular of my intention; neither have any taken notice of your fear, nor is it posible they hould know that it was any trick of mine, neither was there any intention to doe you the leat hurt. And upon my Honour, Fanor (himelfe) was no more privy to this plot then the Sucking Child: For it was I (that had a mind to be friends with you) who caued him to invite us both unto a Supper; I am at the Charges of the Feat, I ordered the buinee; this was to be but the beginning of a Maque, whereby (as it were) the cene of blutring Mars was open'd, next whereunto Peace is to appear with all her plenty in her Armes, placing her everall Dihes upon the Table. Fanor I ent away on purpoe (upon an Errant) that he hould not take notice of my deigne; now, if you can keep your own councell, and ue me well; that is to ay, let me have my will, for I will have it, you hall never be digrac'd for all this: otherwie I will hew you twenty uch tricks as thee.

Thoron (about to commend her widome, aure her of performance of her deires, and to Embrace her in his Armes) brought uch a cent along with him, that he could not but take notice of it, and offer him her aitance, (as farre as it was fitting) wherefore he told him, (merrily, and miling upon him) My Lord, I know you have bewray'd your elf mot abominably, and there is a necesity in it, that I mut tand your friend, or ele all the wit in both our pericraniums will not be able to keep this a ecret. Therefore I will tell Fanor that you and I intend to lie in his Houe all night, and I'le end home my Woman for clean Linnen,
and o you may hift your elfe; and if you can make your elf clean, I can keep your councell. Thoron confes'd all, and pray'd her to be as good as her word, but epecially in keeping his Councell in every particular, auring Armena that he hould finde him a very good Husband from that time forward: things being performed on her part he ordering the buinee as he promis'd, brought him (though omewhat late) weet and clean, hand in hand, lovingly together, into the Dining Roome amongt all the Company, whoe no notice taking of any uch matter; nor laughing or jeering at any uch thing, (as indeed they had no caue, uch was their ignorance) very much confirm'd and conolated the poor man, who was fully atisfied with this belief, that all had been true that had been aur'd unto him by his Wife: But Armena upon this hold, Raigned as Lady Governee ever after.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: A dicoure between Fanor and Armena, concerning Man and Wife, how either may obtaine the overaignty of each other.

div.p: FAnor (perceiving the uddaine alteration and ubmie behaviour of Thoron towards his Wife Armena, together with ome other circumtances) collected a great many particulars conducing to a perfect knowledge of the meanes, whereby Armena had obtain'd that Soveraignty over her Husband, which as good as known, he as good as acknowledged, which was the occaion of ome dicoure betweene them two, concerning atchievements of that nature. For Armena was of opinion, That there was never a Woman in the world, but might have her will of her Husband, and doe what he would with him, except he were a fool (let him be of what dipoition he could be of.)
How is that (aid Fanor?) That were a Doctrine that would finde many Diciples if you could teach it them.
Truly (aid Armena) I can teach it you.
With all my heart (aid Fanor) I would willingly learn it, that I might teach it to my Mitrie, whereby he might become an excellent Wife.
O (aid Armena) he will never learn it of you, it mut be taught her by one of her own ex, that he may learn it from her.
How is it I beeech you Madam?

A wie Wife (aid Armena) mut prie into the inclination and dipoition of her Husband, oberve his humours, informe her elfe of what temper he is made, otherwie he gives battaile before he knowes how the enemy lyes: many a foolih Woman hath lost the day for want of this forecat: if he perceives him to be of a Noble contitution of mind, and magnanimous pirit, then (whatoever hers is) let her ubmit to him: and then (as a flint is ooner malleable that receives its troakes upon the yeilding
cuhion than upon reiting iron, o the toutet heart, mollifies and relents, upon the oftnee of a dipoition, that hardens, where it meets with oppoition.

Or like a fiddle-tick Madame, (aid Fanor) which though you it upon it with all your weight, upon a hard bench, yet it will not break; but if you lay it on a feather-bed, and o repoe your weight upon it, it will break immediately.

Come, come, you are a wagge (aid Armena) I peak nothing but reaon, Mars his Men, have minds, like Mars his Livery; and are of the ame nature of the Buffe they weare: through which a Straw may ininuate it elfe, when the harpet edge or point can neither cut nor enter; through which the mildnee of a breath can puffe the fierce flame of an incened Taper out, which full-chopt Boreas (with his keenet breath) can never pierce. A noble mind will foter up thoe pleaing ubmisions of a Wife, with uch condecentions, as hall be incouragements to a good ubject: whereas contention between uch high Spirits, is like Brimstone, mingled with Coal and Peter, whereof uch a compoure is oone made, as with the additament of the leat heat, the whole frames, piles, and building, which have been erected upon no lee firme foundation then acred vows, and conjugall affections have been oftentimes blown up, and have return'd no greater benefit to their Parents, then Noie and Terrour.

But if he finds her Husband to be a poor pirited man, then let her put hard (a Gods Name) for no mall hare in the Government. Then let her make her elf (if he can) a Free tate, her husband, but her Duke of Venice. She doth but like thoe Indian Women, who carry their Heads in their Booms: uch a Man wil be glad to do any thing for quietnes ake like dying man, whoe pirits being pent, and weak, ayes I to every thing, to avoid troubleomnee) whereas the want of thee inpections and proecutions, is the occaion of all the combutions that are twixt Man and Wife.
There is no way to make an abject minde become a monster, but by humouring of it; and if you acrifice complacencies to uch a poverty, you make him a Tyrant.
Madame, (aid Fanor) your Ladyhip peaks in extreames, but what would you doe if you had an indifferent Man to your Husband?

Truely Fanor, (aid Armena) I have often pray'd againt uch a one, and have often requeted of the God of Marriage, that he would give me either a wie Man, or a Foole to my Husband; for, I ever thought, that if I had a wie Husband, he knew how to govern me; or, if a Foole, I knew how to order him: but I peake not (Fanor) of greater or leer capacities of wit and understanding, which allow a meane; but of high or vulgar pirits which admit no medium; for, the enquiries (I meane) which we make into the dipoition of a Man, is to know of what mettle he is made, whether of bae, or noble? not of what ingenuity he is of, or how many degrees he hath taken in that excellence; for Noblenee is either higher or lower, according to the everall occaions it hath to worke upon; but till wee are not to conider them as ditinct Species by their everall occurrences, but as one and the ame
kinde, and altogether one noble nature; and the latter (being a contrary quality and bae temper of the blood) we never examine of how inferiour an allay it is, which alo eems to us more or lee, according to the everall accidents it meets withall, yet till we mut totall the particulars under the notion of Ignoblenee; o that in this conideration, there is no place left for Indifference to act her part, and thee two leafes of the ame dore have never a wicket to let a neaking dipoition creep between them; either he mut be a brave Gallant Man, or ele ome faint-hearted cowardly Companion; and if he be but either of thee, I can play my game to my owne advantage.

But all this while Madame, (aid Fanor) you uppoe the widome altogether in the Wife, what if the Husband were a wie Man? may not he tame, rule, or have his Wife at his beck of whatoever pirit he were of?

I have granted you that already aid Armena) my Argument holds good from the leer to the greater; but Mans widome must not be there exercis'd in the obervation of humours, or dicerning of pirits, but in the well management of the power of his dominion: for both Civill and Divine Lawes have given uch a overaignty to men over their Wifes, that they oftentimes loe their Prerogatives by eeking to gaine that by Reaon which is theirs by Authority. He that gives a Woman leave to argue the cae with him, doth but like a foolih Gameter, that lends a needy fellow mony to play againt himelfe. For though the matter be never o jut on her ide concerning which they may contet, yet the caue cannot be but unjut on her part, in regard it is Contetation, which ought not to be. I would have a wie man to admit his wife his Councellour, but not his Opponent: to help him to finde out the truth of things, but not to trive for victory in the Argument, or carry more aile then ballat in her words. That man who eeks to over top his wifes high Spirit with a higher, is but like a King who condecends to receive atisfaction from a Subject, by fighting a ingle duell when he may have his will by his Prerogative. He that anwers the nimblenee of his wifes tongue with the volubility of his owne, doth but jutifie the warre by giving quarter: nothing makes this ubject ooner rebell, then when he ees her Emperour knowes not how to Command. I tell thee Panor, there is not a dieae in Wedlock, but the Husband is a fool, if he be not a Phyitian able enough to cure it.

Fanor, it may be you think I peak againt my elfe, and the priviledge of my Sex, I protet I doe not: I had two Husbands before I had this, and I never received uch contentment in wholly having my will of the one, as I was pleaed in being altogether at the others Command: The gracefulnee of whoe rule and government, made my obedience (alwayes Honourable, whilt the neceitated (yet pleaing) encroachments over the others right, made me (oftentimes) ahamed of the uurpation. Wherefore I alwayes pray'd, that if ever I married againe, I might have a Husband that was either a Fool, or a Wie man, that having a Fool, I might know how to order him; and if a Wie man, he may know how to governe me. But by my troth Fanor, I have (now)
met with a Man that is neither one or other; wherefore I knew not how to deal with his folly, but by playing the Fool; nor how to anwer his hare of widom but by a piece of policy. Hereupon Company came in, and ended the Dipute.

Thus we leave Honoria a Conqueror by the force of Eloquence, Amaria prevalent, by the power of her owne wit, both happy by the hand of Providence, and a third climing the degrees of excellence, up the teps acendent to the throne of ingenuity, and returne back againe to Maximanus; who hearing no newes of his two Womenlayers, nor that any other fleh was to be found in the intended Shambles of the Forret, but the laughtered Carcae of one of his owne Butchers, he began to mitrut that all was not well, which he endeavoured to repaire with the greatet of all Evils, viz. Open Rebellion, in order whereunto, he eizes upon all Forts and Magazines, and converts them to his proper ue; The affrighted Royalits gather themelves into a neceitated Body, where we leave them both like a paire of Cocks pecking at one another, till a third comes in, and o makes two to one, till one makes none of two, and three brings all to nothing.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: Lorenzo is beaten by the Moores. Hortenius and Philoret meet Lorenzo after the dicomfiture, and deliver their Meage. Lorenzo and Bertaldo made friends. The Battaile between Maximanus and Corderius. Lorenzo and Maximanus. Maximanus laine in Battaile.

div.p: LOrenzo fighting without his right hand, Bertaldo, (whom he corn'd to make ue of) was orely Dicomfited by the Moores; in which Battalle he lot Codruball and Hanno, with many others of his prime Commanders, (with 7000. of the Carthaginians) Berontus (of all his Heroes) he came off, making good the Rear, until the Defeated Army had recovered a Pae upon the River Undi, whoe Bridge Berontus caus'd to be broken downe. For Berontus (as the ret) flying with his Keepers (about him) danger and necesity made him theirs, and his confiners ole preerver: For he made good the Bridge with his owne naked body, (like a black Rock tanding in defyance againt an Ocean) untill the Pioniers thinking by degrees to fall the Bridge, behind him, ore-threw the Arch; o that all fell downe at once, whoe propitious tones, favoured Berontus, doing execution upon his enemies, but none upon himelf; from whom he wam afely to his owne bank ide, where he found no lee a Friend to help him up then Lorenzo, who had been more his owne then his Enemy.

Thus the fates ordained, that valour and diater hould agree together, to necesitate a friendhip between thee two, when other meanes could not prevail, to caue them to hake hands with one another. So he ecured the Prince from further proecution, and Lorenzo him, from future mi-conception, where Hortenius and Philoret met the Prince: at whoe firt ight Lorenzo was much divided between the two paions, of Love and Hatred, having een o much Gallantry in the one, and heard of o much Baenee in the other, whom he thought (notwithtanding) o much the better of (as to forbear all expreions of dilike for the preent) becaue he aw him coupled with o known a Worthy.

But when hee had once heard them fully declare themelves (with all the Circumtances atteted under the hands of o many of his truty Friends and Counellours, but epecially when he aw and read the Handkerchief) oh how he was nettled and tung to the quick! oh how he was mad with himelf for what he had done! and knew not which was better for him to beleeve, or not give credit to what they aid: Philoret he could not mi-believe; Hortenius he durt
not, whoe ufferings, and whoe merits, pleaded a better reception; Shame would have forc'd an incredulity upon him, but Honour and Jutice made him doubtfull which of either he hould entertaine with highet Curteie; but nothing troubled him o much as what was become of Honoria and Amaria, and how he hould look Bertaldo in the face, for the wrong wherewith he had proecuted uch a noble Friend, and fear'd he had caus'd already to be executed upon his Siter: This made him quite beides himelfe. He ends for Bertaldo, who entring the preence he thus be-peakes his patience:

I feare me I have undone my elfe, I pray thee doe not make any Reply, let thou prick't a heart that bleeds too fast already: I have a great many things to tell thee, but I cannot peak: And thereupon he lean'd upon Bertaldo's neck, and wept upon his boome, aying, Pity me, and be not angry, I will deerve thou houldt doe both.

Bertaldo (whoe eyes were til upon Philoret, deerv'd by her wihly looks on him) makes him this hort anwer (longing to parle with his lovely Page) Sir, whatoever your perplexities may be, I advie you to make hate to Carthage, that you may prevent the michief, and (if posibly) uperede your Errour.
Oh Bertaldo (aid Lorenzo) thou pouret Oyle into my wounds, and tak't away the mart with that ame word. Let there be orders given to march this night, I'le goe my elfe.

Bertaldo lets him goe, that he might tay and commune with his (unknown) Idolatree; who upon his approach, was o full of joy, that he knew not how to behave himelf; whereof Bertaldo took uch notice, that he anwered his Jollity with asking him twenty Quetions one after another; he, his frolick, with anwering, he knew not what. At lat withdrawing themelves towards a more erious dicoure, after that Bertaldo had heard Philoret (deliberately) relate unto him all that had happened, he clapt his hand upon his breat, and abruptly parted from him. Poor Philoret began to be a little dejected at the manner of it, but Bertaldo (recollecting himelf) made him amends by giving him a double portion of repect, o that pleas'd he was: Hortenius glad that he had truck in with uch a Favourite, all the Courtiers giving them Cap and Knee, (as they went along) as Courtiers ue to doe to thoe whom they ee gratiouly received.

No other noie at Court but of removall, no other newes in the Camp but of a preent March; ix dayes brought them within the ight of Carthage: and the two Armies facing one another, viz. Maximanus and Corderius.

Maximanus his Men (like good tomacks, (having but a proportionable allowance) have not (as yet) their Appetites whetted with feare of having too many Feeders upon o mall a Pittance: But upon the approach of Lorenzo's Forces, they fall too, putting all their hands together in the Dih (liing it away) for fear of the new commers Mouthes. So was Corderius Army oone devour'd by
Maximanus, making uch hate to give him Battell before Lorenzo hould come to his Aitance. Corderius fled with his cattered Troopes to meet Lorenzo, whom Maximanus durt not purue too farre (for fear of being met with (by Lorenzo) out of order) Lorenzo wondred firt to ee two Armies Face, then Fight, and at lat Purue each other. At length atisfied his eeking braine by a full relation of all that had hapned, by Corderius; whoe preence, and Commands, oone rallyed the breathlee Souldiers, whoe panting Royall Hearts left their trepidations like the Needle, whoe point, when it once findes the northerne Pole, moves no more, then doth the Center: o were thee Souldiers calm'd.
Corderius preently applies himelfe to the Prince, and deires that his men might be commanded by Bertaldo's better conduct.

No (aid Lorenzo) they hall be commanded by no other then my elfe, and Bertaldo hall command the Army. Which Bertaldo modetly refued; but Lorenzo told him, that as nothing would encourage thoe new-raid men, and re-inliven them, more then his owne preence; o nothing would be more acceptable to the ouldiery then his Conduct. Berontus he commanded the Forlorne Hope.

Maximanus by this time (oberving the orderly advance of Lorenzo's over-numerous hoat) begins to think his Army all forlorne, but howoever he was ambitious, (though the fates had given him a villanous part to act) to act it well; that he might have a glorious Exit. His followers for the mot part (all deperate and) involv'd in the ame guilt, were reolved to doe o too; o that there was a fierce battaile fought, between courage and deparation.

Berontus beats their Forlorne, up to their main Body: whereupon he receives orders from Bertaldo, to draw off, and joyne with the Prince, fearing that the Prince (if hard beet) might not be o well defended by his new-rais'd men. Lorenzo becaue he would not dicountenance his Confidents, bids him tand as a reerve to his maine Body, which was done accordingly. Maximanus falls on o furiouly, that he followes his thrown darts o cloe, that he comes to handy trokes, fighting under their flying hadowes, but finding that he had mitaken his aime, and that Lorenzo commanded not the party, he gives orders for freh forces to come up, and bids them undertake thoe triplings, telling them, he was deceived, and mut goe and eeke Lorenzo out, and fight with men of valour.

Opinion (which the world is guided by) made them but triplings in their hands, indeed, for a long time, untill Bertaldo's prowee taught them how much they were deceived, whilt Maximanus with his men fall upon Lorenzo's, with reduplicated trengths of madd men, bearing downe all before them, till Berontus checkt their fury, with his well-brought-up reerve, and av'd Lorenzo with the ame hand that fell'd the deperate Maximanus to the ground, thereby, o diheartning all the ret, that they oon betook themelves to flight, Bertaldo having done the like unto his Enemies.

Thus whil't there appeared great erenity in every face, all might behold a Cloud in Lorenzo's countenance; and perceive a war within his breat; occaioned by the lat gaping words, which Lorenzo heard Maximanus utter, with his Breath: for Maximanus (lying bleeding upon the ground) deired that he might peake unto Lorenzo before he hould expire. Whoe words were thee.

Unfortunate Lorenzo! Mater to a more faithlee ervant! had not thy favours been o great, I had not been o wicked. Honoria was innocent of all he was accued, I playd the Knave, and you the Foole: o tretch'd his limbs and dyed.

Lorenzo at firt, would have had him (if poibly) preerv'd; but eeing his hatefull oule had made an ecape, he revenged himelfe upon his encelee body, vexing himelfe, that it had not life, to anwer his indignation with enibility; never was there uch a dying blow given to a Victor: the word Foole, troubled him not o much, as the word Innocent; nor Innocent, o much as the word was, which put him in depaire of her being alive. Never was there uch a ad Conqueror as this Lorenzo, whom the Sun beheld, bringing with him night in his Countenance to Carthage, after that he had won the day.

The men were all disbanded, whil't an Army of unruly thoughts, and cares, mutered within his boome. Bertaldo (who himelfe almot over-et with orrow, yet eeing his o great) beares him up with Comfort, telling him that none can ay (for certaine) what is become either of Honoria or Amaria, none aw them dye: but many eyes have eene one of the intended Executioners, dead in the place of Execution: why might not the Gods protect their Innocence, by unexpected meanes? why hould we not hope they did, eeing they were Innocent; and we heare nothing to the contrary? why may not one of thee Villaines appointed for the laughter (mollifyed into gentlenee, by Honoria's weet behaviour, and overcome by Amaria's prightly Carriage) lay that Brother in evill, and preerve them both himelf? It is but early day, I warrant you, you hall hear more hereafter; come, pluck up a good Courage.

Oh (aid Lorenzo) I thinke (Bertaldo) thou wilt raie me to life, when I am dead; if this hould bee, I will erve the Gods (for ever) with reduplicated adorations; and I will recompence their ufferings with a thouand new-found ways to expiations, whereto, repentance her elf yet never found the way; and hould but one of thoe men, doe as thou Imagin't, I would fill him as full of happinee, as his Capacity could hold; I would 'twere true Bertaldo, on that Condition that I gave thee Carthage for thy prophecies reward.

Come Sir, reply'd Bertaldo, 'tis neither orrow, nor Language, nor wihes, nor woulds, that mut help us: end out everall waies to hearken after them, I'le eek up towards the Mountaines, let Berontus beat about, towards the Sea-coat, if Sea, or Land, can give us any intelligence, wee'le not be ignorant, what is become of them. They both took their everall wayes for earch.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: The fantaticall Wooing, Humourome Wedding, and Platonick love that was between Corderius and Fortunata. Prickette his michance by the way.

div.p: WHilt thee things were in agitation, I hall acquaint you with a pretty paage which hapned between Corderius and Fortunata, Neece, and Woman to a Lady that was call'd Beanca, in his Travailes with Bertaldo, in earch of the Ladyes.

You mut undertand Corderius to have been a Rich Merchant, and an old Batchelour, about the age of Fifty: And one, who for his Widome, and Loyalty, was worthily received into Prince Lorenzo his Counell of State: him, Fortune did begin to frown upon, having lot certaine Ships at Sea of inetimable value, inomuch that he was unwilling to venture any more ubtance upon that hazard: and therefore reolved (to withdraw his hand from o cheating a Lottery, as Fame (the fale Trumpeter of the world) who encouraged o many Adventurers to returne home by Weeping croe (hearkning to her enticement) and yet could never boat ucceefulnee but over a few) and to lead a private life, and to enjoy the remainder of his dayes with uch contentment, and true felicity, as the ret of his great Fortunes (that were not loeable by being at take) would give him leave. The delight was departed from him, wherein he (formerly) repos'd felicity, in making Hundreds, Thouands: and Fifties, Hundreds: by multiplications of maller ummes. He changed his itching deire, that was in the act of getting, for the true contentment that was to be found in making ue of what he had got: And thus he found himelf at lat by beginning to be a loer.

But all the delights of Eden could not make a Paradie (he thought) without a Companion that hould be meet for him. But then he began to think with himelfe, that he had o over-lipt his time, and that he was now grown o Old, that he was carce meet for a Companion; that his Gray haires were no good repoure upon a Green Bed. And that Nature had made him none of her Favourites, and Age had put him further out of Countenance.

Yet he comforted himelf a little (allowing his reolution this Cordiall) that he was not o wondrous Old, as that he needed to depaire of poesing a Mitree, with a conceit of ufficient happinee, in being uch an Old mans darling: And that her Poverty (by the meanes of his Riches) would procure in her breat a dipenation for his Silver haires. And that, if he thus took a poor Gentle-woman upon Almes, (though he could not, as yet, love him, yet) he might be glad to have him, and think
her elf happy (bringing nothing with her but Love) to meet with uch a one, though he have nothing ele but means to maintain it.

As Corderius did (heretofore) beat about the Country to find out a Virgin that hould be thus qualified (being in all his other actions a notable Humorit) viz. Very well borne, Excellently bred, Indifferent Handome, and Mierably poor, but never could find a imilitude to his Fancy that ran upon all (thee) Four, before uch time as (attending upon Bertaldo in this itinerary progreion) he met with uch a Counter-part to his own indenture, that fitted him, as if occaion had taken meaure of his minde. For Corderius and his Hore differing in termes of ability to Advance; the Rider, (through his Mans default) feeding his dumb Porter with a Spur, intead of Provinder, (what with faintnee, and the loe of one of his Shooes) the poor Hackny made a Hault all upon a udden, without taying for the word from his Commander; inomuch that Corderius was by degrees o left behind, that he grew from being out of ight, to be out of hope of overtaking his Companions. Whereupon he et up his ret in a mall Village, at the feet of one of the Fesian Mountaines.

This Cavalliers Caball was unwilling to clime, when he could not goe, with a bare Foot, and an empty Belly. Inomuch that poor Corderius mut be left behind in a poor Inne. High-way accidents mut be borne withall, his bad fortune was better'd with this one comfort: his Landlord was a Good fellow, and cheer'd him up, (who finding his Hot a fit receptacle for dicoure that went no higher then a Merry Tale, or o forth) o he drove away the time with making his Hot believe, That his Travell was to no other end, or purpoe, but what he had a long time ought in vain, viz. uch a Mitree as is before expres'd.

The Good man of the Houe preently anwered his intended Mirth with a profferr'd reality of accomplihing his deires. For (aid he) here within our Neighbour-hood there is one who is thus and thus Vertuous, o and o Poor, thus highly Borne, o excellently Bred, known by the well-boding name of Fortunata; and if it pleae you, you hall have a ight of her, and if you can win her, wear her. Corderius began to think, that this avoury dih was not o ready cook'd to his owne pallat without ome pice of Divine Providence: Wherefore he reolves to make an aay, and though he be cros'd in finding another mans Wife and Mitree, yet he hoped he might be blet by a chance medly, whereby for himelf (in the ame peron he may meet with both. Corderius (waving the proffer'd ervice of his Intelligencer) takes notice of the Name, and Place, with directions of the Way; and pins his intructions upon his Sleeve: And having written a Love-letter, (to the Idea of his minde) he makes himelfe the Bearer; who (having as ufficiently inform'd his Eyes of an apparent truth, as formerly he fill'd his Eares with a true relation) delivers unto Fortunata the mot acceptable preent of an unfeigned Lover, viz. his owne heart, with his owne hands.

Fortunata (peruing the letter, and oberving the contents; and finding no name to it) lookt over her houlder, to ee if there were any that tooke notice of the non-plus he was in, by reaon of uch an exoticke and ononymous way of writing (as he had framed) and there preented to her owne hands: then he lookes him full in the face, as upon ome abuive foot-pot that was hired to play the foole with her, and thus he rates him for it.

Fellow, what hat thou brought me here? a paper full of Noune Adjectives without a Subtantive? and a letter without a name? what doth he thinke that ent thee, that I am good at explaining Riddles? Madam aid Corderius, if you vouchafe me but the honor to take a turn in the Garden, my buinee is not to Uher you into any of it's Cloer walkes: but to uch as are within ight, of all the glae eyes that are in the face of the whole houe: and there if you are good at Quetions, and Commands, you hall finde me ready with Anwers, and Obedience.

Fortunata (perceiving his Language to bepeake a mitake in her) condecended to his requet, and walkt with him into the Garden, where, as oone as he had brought him, he demanded of him the reaon why the letter had no name?

Corderius replyed that it needed not; when his owne hand was to the letter whilt he gave it her. I cannot read your hand aid Fortunata. Be pleaed to read my heart (aid Corderius) in the two folios of my unfeigned lips, which aures you, that I love you, and have loved you long; have travailed a great many Miles, and I have been a uiter to you many Yeares: and though it eems never o trange to you, yet let my words finde credit (for truths ake) and be the happiet Woman in the world.

Thee words (poken with uch a grace, attended with o much gravity, and proceeding from uch a preence) fraught Fortunata not only with wonder, but Confidence; not o much out of the manner, as matter of his dicoure; that there was omething in it, extraordinary, that promied a reality, and good meaning in the man: wherefore he deired to know his name.
Corderius told her, that he that mut be his Wife, mut never know that, untill he be o.
Fortunata deired to know what Countryman he was?

Corderius told her, that that was another ecret which mut not be knowne, and to cut you off from all thoe ordinary demands of Women in your Condition (aid Corderius) Lady you mut know, that that Woman which carryes my Wives eye in her head, mut looke no further then my elf: for if I hould tell you my name, what Countryman I am, who ent me hither, what meanes I have to Maintaine you, &c. It may be you would, or would not have me, for this, or that repect: wherefore Madam I hall never aske you but thee two quetions, Firt, Can you Love? Secondly, Can that Love have any Influence upon my peron? I neither thinke my elfe o amiable, or my Condition o inviting, as to deerve the
complement of an intire affection: but if you can finde in your heart to Marry me, I aske no more, I'le finde caue enough (for ever) to banih all repentance from your heart: o that reaon hall finde no fault in your election. Weigh my words as eriouly as you can, I have no ends upon you but what are Honourable, and Jut: Portion, I aske none; Proportion, and Comelinee, I ee; your Parentage, and Piety, I hear of: And of this you may aure your elfe, had you a Fortune of your owne, able (but) to have bought the Cloathes upon your Back, you could not be my Wife. And one thing more I mut tell you, I mut have your peedy Anwer.

Fortunata thought it not convenient, that her conent hould be obtained upon the firt bluh, yet her Colour (as if it went on Errants to her intellectualls, to know the meaning, of o trange (yet effectuall) manner of Wooing, and returning againe into her Cheekes with o freh a dye, as if it had made hat in it's returne) gave him ome private intelligence, that her faint heart, was ready to yeeld up her Mayden garrion, upon the firt ummons; but that her modety mutinyed againt its higher officer: and would not uffer o regular fortifications to be o oon leighted by uch a loving Enemy: wherefore, he deired longer time to conider of what he had aid, and he would returne him an anwer worthy of his repect.

Corderius told her bluntly, it mut not be; and that he would neither be beholding for a Wife to time, perons, or econd thoughts: and that he was at her owne dipoall to chue a Husband, whoe condition was but ervitude: And that the ignorance of all worldly repects (that mut give him a Wife in Marriage) needed not conideration; and the Poverty that hould bring him a Bed-fellow did not deerve the advice of Friends. This was his humour, and that if he would take him upon thoe termes, Happinee hould be her joynture; Contentment the life he hould lead; and Sufficiency, her contant maintenance. More then that, he that is to be his Wife, hould never know before he were his; and if he were ordain'd his Spoue, he would be atisfied with that aurance.

Fortunata took occaion by the Fore-top, fearing it would be bald behind; and thought it better wiedome to lay hold of an opportunity that might advance her, though to an unknown Etate, then to be contantly wedded to even reckonings at the years end: Wherefore he thus reolv'd upon the quetion.

Sir, whoe Name I know not, whoe Country I mut not know, whoe Etate, is, I know not what, who means to carry me I know not where, I am yours I know not how. And with that word, Corderius opening his Armes to receive her into his Boome, Fortunata falls upon his Breat; and (weeping) clings o cloe unto him, as if a bleeding Vine had been tackt unto ome tately Frontipice, whoe teares Corderius oone wip'd off, (drying her Bedewed cheeks) with this breath of comfort: Lady, if you knew your owne happinee, you hould finde you have no caue for what you doe, except you wept for joy.

Fortunata (having fully conented that Corderius hould break a Bridall Cake over her head) hatens to her Lady-Aunt, and Mitree; and with a clear'd up countenance, tels her, That he is come to take her leave of her.

q.l: Why, whither art thou going? (aid her Mitree.)
I am going to me be Married (aid Fortunata.)
To be Married! (aid her Aunt) I prethee to whom?
Truly Madam I cannot tell you (aid her Neice.)
What is his name? (aid the Lady.)
I doe not know (aid Fortunata.)
How comes that about? (aid the Mitree.)
He would not tell me (aid the Maid.)
Whither doth he mean to carry thee? (aid Beanca.)
He will not tell me (aid Fortunata.)
Art thou in earnet? (aid the Lady.)
Yes forooth (aid the Waiting Gentle-woman.)
Art thou not out of thy wits Girl? (aid Beanca.)

div.p: Madam, I hope not (aid Fortunata) I'le have him, and if it pleae the fates, if there were no more men in the world.

The Girle is bewitcht upon my life (aid Beanca) what hath he done to her? where is this fellow? let me peak with him. Away he flies upon Corderius, and in furious manner begins to expotulate the cae with him, whoe pretty kind of anwers no lee atisfied the Lady, then (with much probability) that her Neece was likely to clime up to ome preferment, through ome fantasticall Stair-cae. Wherefore after many doubts reolved, he gives conent (with this provio) that Favorinus, her own Brother, hould go along with her, (together with a ervant of the Ladies, call'd Prickette, who hould ee them marryed, (for he was reolv'd to carry her away with him preently, he, as reolute to be gon) up he takes her behind him on Hore-back, without any more circumtance. He is a Prince, and his Humour mut be obey'd. Farewell Aunt: God b'y Coen. Look to your Siter (aid Beanca.) I warrant you (aid Corderius) all hall be well enough, take you no care. They hake hands at one another, and cry Da, Da; and this was all the olemnity of their departure.

They had not advanced even miles onward in their journey, but they lot their way: and the night overtaking them, they were bewildred in a Forret; at lat they met with a Forreteer, who brought them to a poore Inne, where they were glad to et up their ret for that night, where there were but two pare Beds for three perons: who all three willingly would have layne by themelves, but Corderius, and Favorinus were contented for one night, to make a hard hift together; but Prickette was to hift for himelf.

When Fortunata (with as much civility as the place would (then) give leave) was attended to her Chamber, (rites being done that were required by the Lawes of Curteie) Corderius and Favorinus, refrehed themelves (after Supper) with better entertainment, then they
imagined the houe had afforded, viz. a Cup of old Briske Corica Wine: which had been tranported out of Italy: Prickette having lickt his lips ufficiently of ome of the Wine, (whilt he attended upon his Maters) when they were gone to Bed, at once he inflames both the reckoning, and himelfe, with too many haires of the old dog; the good woman of the houe (to egge him on to further expences) made him beleeve, that he hould have a Bed, (or ele it hould go hard with her) and rather then he hould be detitute of a lodging, that he and her Husband would it up all night.

Prickette grew from being overcome with kindnee, to be o much overcome with drink, that he could neither goe, nor tand, nor ee, nor peak: wherefore mine Hot, and his Wife (perceiving him to be but a Dumpling, a thick hort chub, or lump of Fleh, not above three Hore-loaves high; and conidering the condition he was in) chang'd their reolution (having found out a new invention for him) up they carryed him to the top of the houe by maine trength, where in the Cock-loft there was a Childs Cradle made of boards; and having made him a Bed therein of a Bolster, and laid on two hort Towels, intead of a paire of Sheetes; and their Daughters Bone-lace Cuhion intead of a Pillow, with two old Petticoates: for a Rug and Blanket; they tript off his cloathes, and laid him in this bed, with a childs Rattle tuck in at one of the ides to keep up the cloathes, which the Hot, (as merrily dipos'd as his Wife) oberv'd, and aid unto her, Nay Wife, if thou tick't up a Rattle on one ide, I'le hang up the Bladder with the three blew Beanes on the other, (etting a Chamberpot very orderly by his Bed ide that was half full already) and there they left him.

Prickette (lying with his Legs crumpting up (for want of roome) not being ued to be abridg'd of his full length) chanc'd (in his leep) to be o enible of his dieae, that he thrut out his Legs halfe way over the edge of the foot boord, and o he lay for the mot part of the night, untill uch time, as (being awaked with the paine, which had got into the mall of his legs, and the cold that had truck into the oales of his feet) he pull'd in his tumps) like a pair of touch'd Snails horns) o that he lay at pretty eae for a while, untill uch time as his over-trech'd, and ful-fill'd Bladder call'd upon him for a remedy by evacuation: Prickette reaches one of his armes over the uppoed bed ide to earch for a Chamber-pot, whilt the Cradle rowles (which, together with the turning of his unetled Brain, caued his fancy to imagine) as if he had been falling down the precipice of ome huge Mountaine; and the motion of the mall Pebles within the Rattle, and the Beanes within the Bladder, caued his imagination to conceive o many looe tones falling out of their places; and his fingers (by reaon of the wag of the Cradle) dahing upon the urface of the lake that was in the unemptied veell, the poor innocent verily believ'd, that he had popt his hand into ome bottomlee River. Prickette endeavouring to recover himelfe up againe, gives
uch a pring, that it was twenty to one, but on the contrary ide, the cradle had come over, and over: but there happened a greater michance then all this, and a more caue of terror: for the Cat, lying aleep upon the ground, on the other ide of the cradle, one of the theorbo's underneath it, preed o hard upon the Cats tayle, that (Prickette having no other meanes to ave himelf from that overthrow but the ue of his other arme) the aperous vermine, ets all the venemous nailes that were upon all four, (together with both rowes of the pointed needles within her jawes) into his trembling fleh: making uch a hideous out-cry, that all the hags and furies, (nimphs to the Stygean lakes) could never have given o fierce an alarum to the poore mans quarters, as that had done.

Prickette all amazed lyes for a long time rocked by Counter-poies; untill experience (at lat) having taught him the art of ordering his maine body in full quietnee; elfe-ecurity, had made him o cautious, that he began to be very wary, of what ide of his mouth he carryed his tongue, for a long time he lay till, (wondering where he was, what he was in, & how he came there) at lat an Ae, a creature (whoe voice (of all others) he never had been accutomed unto) brayed, jut under his window: which hideous noie, he tooke to be no other, then the Divels language: whereat (forgetting all his former terrors) he gave uch a pring (out of the Cradle) as if he had a minde to have leaped out of his Skinne, rather then out of Bed, and came to ground ooner, by forty fathomes falling, then he did expect. Up he gets upon his feet, thinking himelfe well enough yet, but knew not how long it would continue; he orders his teps, with expectations of uch ruggednee, and fear of precipices, that the evennee of the floore, oft-times became his tumbling block; at length he became Mater of his enes, though he knew not how to imploy his Servants: for he had no light, and could hear no noie, only he groaped for undertanding, and found ufficient in the darke, to informe his recollected Spirits, that he was in ome lodging within the Inne; but he verily believed it was an Inchanted Chamber: wherefore he made all the hat out of it, that he could, and pred his fingers upon the Wall ides, as if he had been playing upon the Virginalls; at lat he found the door: which being but latch'd, he eaily opened, and decends the tayres: but whither they led, he knew not: neither did he care, o that they gave way for his removall from the place wherein he was.

At lat he tumbled againt Fortunata her door; bounce goes his head and houlders againt the Waincot: Fortunata (awaked with the noie) wakens all the houe, with Crying Theeves, Theeves: Brother rie: call up the Gentleman: where are you? Knocks with her Bedtaffe upon the boords, and throws it againt the wall.

p.U:
tarts out of his Bed, and calls for Candles: Favorinus flyes from his net, and drawes his word: up comes the good man and Wife, with lights in their hands, all were ore amaz'd, and
Prickette mot of all: whom they all found neaking by the Gentlewomans door. What dot thou here? (aid Corderius) Sirrah, whats the matter? (aid Favorinus) what wouldt thou have? I would have nothing (aid Prickette) but quietnee: quietnee with a pox to you, (aid Corderius) what dot thou doe up at this time of night? Indeed if you would know the truth out (aid Prickette) the Bed was too hort for me, I could not leep. Whereupon they all fell into uch a laughter, (in fancying what kind of bed that mut needs be, that hould be too hort for him) as put the good Gentlewoman, out of the fright he was in: but nothing could moderate the fit of laughter, that the good man and woman of the houe had et up (knowing how they had erved him) back they returned to their Chamber, and put on their cloathes: by which time the day did break upon them: And as oon as Fortunata was up and ready, in they come, and bring Prickette to anwer for himelfe, telling her the manner, and forme, how they found him at her Chamber door; he them, that he knew not what to make of it, but that Prickette intended a forcible entry.

div.p: Prickette declared to the world, that he intended no hurt, neither that he knew whither he was going, onely he had a mind to rie, and come downe the taires, becaue he could not leep in his bed, it was o hort for him.
And what meant you (aid Fortunata) by butling at my door? Did you think my bed would be longer for you?
No Madam (aid Prickette) I tumbled againt the threhold, and hit my head againt the door, that was it that made uch a noie.

For Heavens ake (aid Fortunata) let us goe ee this bed that is o hort for him. The people of the houe were ent for up to hew them this ight, (for Prickette could not tell where it was) when the Landlord, and the Landlady were ent for, and undertood their pleaure, they o fell into their old fits of laughter, that for a long time they could not peak a word, but hold their ides; and as their breath would give them leave, out comes a Cradle, by and by the Rattle, then the Bladder; neither were they more fill'd with Laughter, then Prickette was with Wrath all the while: who having lot all patience, cures them to the pit of Hell, wearing, That he lay in no Cradle; neither did he know what they meant by Rattles, or Bladders: a couple of bae unmannerly people they were, and o they hew'd themelves. The Gentles were prickt forwards (by the two purs of uch extreams) Mirth, and Madnee, to informe themelves of the true caue of both. Up they all went to the Cock-loft, where they found the Cradle, the Rattle, the Bladder, the Bed and Bolter, the heets, the Coverlet and Blanket; the humour was o good that they all fell into uch an univerall fit of laughing, that Prickette (himelfe) was not an exception in that generall rule, who by that time (being as merrily dipos'd as the ret) made up the Story with telling them the conceit of his falling down into a River, the removall of the looe Stones, the diater he received by the Cat (hewing them the cratchings, and
bitings, upon his hand) the fright that the Braying of the Ae had put him into, in manner and forme as is before expres'd, which was Mirth enough for all that day, and the next following; wherewith, (together with divere other Sports, and Patimes, that Prickette made on the way) they thus merrily arriv'd at Carthage.

Whoe walls they had no ooner entred, but Corderius eekes an obcure lodging where he might be leat known; and delivers into Fortunata's hands a pure of Gold, intreating her Brother Favorinus, to accompany his Siter to the Bure, where he might furnih her elfe with uch necearies (of all orts) as were expedient for her ue, and uitable to the occaion, whilt he went and bought materialls for her Wedding Garments; and provided her uch a neceary intrument (to her minde) as hould take meaure of her body, and fit each everall dimenion. Both parties ingage according to their deignes, and Corderius comes back fraught with cloth of Gold and Silver, as the returne of his Adventure. But Fortunata was o paring in exhauting the Well (the liberality of whoe pring he was o ignorant) that (her modety was uch) he would not purchae thoe additaments to grace an Ornament, at a higher rate, then the darknee of her condition, and the obcurity of her lodging would peak as commendable: which, when Corderius did behold, he wrapt them up in a bundle, and betow'd them upon Ribana (her new recommended Chambermaide) aying, He would rigge up his mallet Pinace with farre better tackling; but his Vice-Admirall, Fortunata, her top, deerv'd more Gallantry. And forthwith led her to the place where he might exchange her Money for the Choicet necearies: And there left her to be attended to her Lodging by Favorinus, and her two ervants, Prickette, and Rivana, whilt he takes the nearet way that brought him to the Court, where he preents his ervice to the Prince, and acquaints his highnee with the manner how he lot his Company: But loing them, he partly found what he look'd for, thereby he lighted upon certaine intelligence, that gave him a relation how that Honoria and Amaria were alive; and that by all Circumtances it could be no other but them two, whom report gave out to have taken Shipping at the Bay of Duno; departing there with as favourable a wind, as they had been driven a Ship board, by the tormes of perecutions: And that he would pawne his life that he hould uddenly hear good tydings of them.

Lorenzo was o tranported with joy, and his minde elevated by hope, eeing o much Confidence proceeded from o erious a man, that he vow'd one minute hould not pae, longer then the time required, for drawing up his patent, but that he would igne him one of his Nobles: which was done accordingly. So that back comes Corderius to his Mitree, with a Lordhip on his back, before he had lay'd out any riches upon his clothes: but he mut not know any thing yet. But now the time is come that high fancy mut delight it elfe in the triumph of humility, and that a conjuncture betweene faith and hope
mut be made with charity. Corderius (as glorious as the Sunne) hands Fortunata (ecliping Cinthia in her greatets majety) to the place of Union.

But Fortunata could not but wonder that no friend of his appeared to olemnize their wedding, and not o much as a dinner provided, and that no other (or more) witnees, were prepared, for the ceremony, then the good man of the houe, and his wife, with their children at their heels, and a few meane and homely ervants; he could not but admire that his compleatnee in all other repects, hould want the correpondent of a Chariot; but that her wedding-garment hould be a golden beome, to weep the dut in the treets, untill it aroe in their faces, as if it had a minde to tell them, what they were; but he that had conented to marry him in a humour, was contented with the humour of his Marriage: and comming within the conecrated walls, tanding upon holy ground, thy plighted their trothes to one an other, by the minitration of the acred hands of him, whom holy Order had et apart (as cleane) to the performance of thoe Rites and Ceremonies: Thus (tyed in a true loves knot) hand in hand they tooke their leaves of the holy man, and the place of holinee: and were no ooner entred the Porch, but they might behold the mot magnificent Charriot that could be carried upon wheels, and the bravet hores, that ere were fatned to a pole; with a Charioteer, and footmen, belonging thereunto, all in the ame livery, which promied Majetie, rather then nobility to be in the owner, Corderius took occaioned to tand and gaze a while upon o faire an object: at lat, he asked his bride how he liked that Chariot? who having run diviion upon the everall Sumptuoities belonging thereunto, and praied the goodlinee that he had (worthily) pied in the hores, and commended the Colour, and trimming of the livery: he warranted that they belonged to ome great man, and wondred whoe they were. Corderius told her that he hould know that preently, and asking the Charioteer (who had his leon given him) whoe Chariot that was? he made anwer (with much reverence) that it was the Lady Fortunata her Chariot, Wife to the Lord Corderius. Madam (aid Corderius) I cry you mercy, it is your Charriot, I pray will you acend it, and take me with you. Fortunata hung back and bluhed, like the rednee of the morn, that betokened a more properous winde, then what hould need, to fill her ayles: but all this would not help her no otherwie then ooner up, where he might take poeion of her owne; where he its not o much elated in her owne minde, as depreed under the burthen of her oppreion of the great danger that is in over-merit.

The well-manag'd hores pride it along the treets, with the newmade-happy payre, untill they reted at the doore of Corderius his proud building: whereat were tanding all his friends and kindred, to welcome the bride to the well-furnihed habitation which he was bid to call her owne; and all within it, hers: feating and muick,
and dancing, had no ooner begun to outweare the day, but Corderius commanded foure other Hores that wore the ame naturall coloured livery on their backs, to be added to the former paire; and invited his Fortunata to take the ayre, and notice of a Country-houe, that had a Bed to bid her welcome to, and a Tenant to be her Bedfellow.

p.U: igh'd, and aid unto Corderius, Sir, you know in what a poore condition you found me, and I ee, into what an ocean of felicity you have lanch'd o meane, and weake a veell, as my elfe: pare your proecution of me with further favours, till I have digested thee; for, one may be as well overwhelm'd with too much joy, as blinded with too much light.

div.p: But Corderius (like thoe Women who will never be married to any Man till they have een him once in Drinke) was reolved, never to let her ret from receiving expreions upon expreions of Affection, till he aw her thoroughly intoxicated with kindnee, that he might ee what humour he was in; wherefore a whole row of Coaches attended the Bride and Bridegroome to Mount-pleaant, which was the name of his Country-houe: where he had no ooner lighted, and entred the Houe, but he caued the Lawyers to produce the Writings, where (in the preence of Favorinus and many other ubtantial Witnees) he made that Houe (with ten thouand Crownes per annum thereunto belonging, by ealing and ubcribing thereunto) her Joynture, and delivered the Deed unto Favorinus, her Brother, to be kept to her ue.

Fortunata was atonihed with admiration, and o overcome with kindnee, that he could not peake one word. This dumb oratory pleas'd his fanie beyond the expreion of any eloquence; and which of the two were ravih'd with greater delight (he to ee his deigne take o well; or he, to finde her hopes o farre out-gone by realities) is hard to imagine.
At length he invites them all into his Garden (the delightful't of any that ever he had een) and askt her, how he lik'd it?

Who anwered him, how could a poore Woman be otherwie than pleas'd, to be taken out of an Almes-houe, and made the Mitree of a Palace, and Lady of uch a Manour? And with thoe words, he began to water the Garden, with her teares: and drew him aide into the next Arbour, where her (minde by the benefit of that little vent) powred forth a reentment of her ad condition through want of merit, anwerable to his benignity.
