Which being perform'd with o much weetnee, and ingenuity, he removes the weight that lay o heavy on her heart, with this aurance, that there was that thing, within her power, to grant, that if he could be but o happy as to obtaine it at her hands (and it was but what was jut and honourable) it would (in equall ballance) outweigh all his benefits.
Then Sir (aid Fortunata) be ure it hall be granted; and you happy: what is it, good my Lord?
You hall know (aid Corderius) in due time, in the interim I make it part of my requet unto you, that you will ret atisfied till you hear further.

In fine, time hath out-gone the day, and the well-pent-time of night calls upon the new-married Couple to hate to Bed:in Bed they are, the Bride-chamber clear'd; which was no ooner perform'd, but Corderius conjures her by all the Love he thought was due to him, to tell him, whether or no he thought her elf happy at that instant?

Fortunata, (after ome paue) told him, That he thought her elf the happiet woman in the world, if he had where withall (in her elf) to anwer that felicity. For he thought there could be no true happinee where permutation of deert was wanting.
Why then (aid Corderius) Fortunata, know, that thou art mierable, but thou mayt be happy; and both thee contrary qualities lie within thy power to owre or weeten thy whole life withall.
Let me know it quickly then (aid Fortunata) and I hall not be long a chuing.
Then thus it is (reply'd Corderius.)

When I was a young man, and firt went out to Sea, as an Adventurer, we uffered Ship wrack: all but my elfe were drown'd, and I preerv'd by a miraculous accident; all but the very top of the main Mat were wallowed up in the Quick-ands, and devouring Seas; up to which top I got, and eeing no hopes of life, but a terrour pread before mine eyes, as broad as the Horion, I vow'd unto the Gods, that if they would manifet their power in my preervation, I would anwer the mercy of their deliverance, with the mot Holinee of life, and Integrity of living, that lay in the utmot endeavours of a Mortall creature: In order whereunto, I vow'd Virginity for ever. I carce had ended my Prayers and Fowes to the Almighty, but through the alt water of mine eyes, I could behold (riding upon the Maine) afaire and stately Ship making towards me, which (approaching nearer and nearer to me) at lat tooke me up: And I have kept my promie hitherto, and mut keep it to my grave: I have done all the good that lay in my power; I have been a Father to the Fatherlee, a Husband to many a Widow: I have helped many to their Right, that uffered Wrong; the Divine providence hath made me an Instrument in doing many good Offices; but especially, I glory in being a meanes whereby the chate Honoria, and deerving Amaria, were not by the Tyrant brought to Triall; and by which meanes (I hope) he is preerved; yet I aw no reaon why I might not Marry, if I could meet with one that would be partner with me in my Vow: I aw no reaon why two might not enjoy the freedomes and familiarities that are between Man and Wife, onely as they are divine and rationall Creatures: that is, to contemplate the Deity, and goodnee of the Gods; to joy in one anothers company, to dicoure together, to embrace, to eal to uch payres of indentures, as the Cockles hall not be more jut in their rejoyndure, to make uch impresions on thoe depreed upplements, which the Bee's-wax for oft, or weetnee, or the red for colour, is not comparable;
to fall aleep by uch a vetall fire, that nere goes out, and never burnes; to recover our elves (o often) from being o many times the images of Death, and finde o many lives renu'd, by loves aurance of its immortality; leaving that other conideration to thoe Senitives that have not undertanding: thy conent to this, O Fortunata, would caue me no lee to adore thee as divine, than keep me (till) in favour with the Gods: all thoe teps of honour to which I have advanc'd thee o many degrees above thy elfe, were but engagements to thy complacence herein. Now am I to expect my doome, or uch a returne of my adventures, that uncovered rocks of Diamonds, or the meeraick and big wolne veines of the earths golden oare, wide opened, could not afford me more contentment or requitall for all my obligations.
Fortunata (having heard him all the while with an attentive eare) whoe conentig heart (as if its pantings had kept time to the muick that he made) anwered:

My ever honoured Lord, more to be eteem'd for this, than all the merit that lies within the power of Man to proecute an ingagement: Now (and never till this time, doe I find my elf in a (posibility of being happy or) way of anwering, all thoe accumulations of benignities, with a power of recompence: you have my full conent herein, and could you read my heart, you'ld finde it all compo'd with nothing ele but o many Amens to every word you have aid: why did you make o great a doubt of my Conentment? what can more reemble the coeletiall fires than when flames doe meet, without the mutty contagion of bituminous materialls? that love, that's et on fire, by combutibilities, which fowle the hands of their owne Makers, have no other flames but burning moake, which vaniheth with the death of its owne parents; whilt the love that Corderius talks of, and is here confirm'd, by me by an act of participation to thy vowes for ever (o pleaing to the gods) eems to be o immortall, as if (Promethean like) we had tolne fire from heaven to burne an everlating acrifice; No, Corderius ret atisfied (if this be all) that the worlds variety could never have fitted your humour o well as Fortunata hall.
Then (aid Corderius) I am happy indeed.
Both cry'd, Both of us are blet in one another. Both lept in one anothers armes, whilt Aminda's Genius (for Honoria her ake) betowes this SONG upon them:

lg.l: THus the flower of love twixt Man
And Woman's ifted from the bran:
Thus fine garden-beds are made;
When aide, the rubih's laid:

l.hi: Thus

lg.l: Unpluckt, looke freher; and are ours,
And as much at our command,
As if they wither'd in our hand:
Where love in chate-preerves is met,
Flowers, in water-pots are et:
And live, and have as weet a breath,
As if, they rooted, in the earth:
Thus (as in Limbecks) p'rits of love
Acend, to decend, from above:
And fill two continents from thence,
With a mot pleaing quinteence:
And where the bodies of uch oules doe meet,

l.hi: They well may
l.U: weeten, but ne'r foule the heet.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: Prickette falls in love with Rivana. They agree upon the time of their Marriage; but have not the patience to tay till the time appointed. They are prevented in their deigne; and the manner how.

div.p: PRickette having been an earnet Suiter to Rivana for her good-will: at lat he obtain'd his deires, to Marry her; but, before the time appointed, they had agreed to be anticipatious in the buinee, and too too forward in giving one another benevolences, before they were due: for the effecting whereof, time and place were appointed: Rivana was the firt Champion that appeared in the field. Prickette met with ome good Fellowes by the way, that forelow'd his march, and retarded his appearance to the Court of Venus.

Rivana and her Hotee (having given him over for a lot man) were once reolv'd to wait his leiure no longer; but Rivana (omething more confident of his performance than the other) was willing to pinne out a little more time, and buies her elf in making a Sack-poet againt his comming: the Poet was made, but no Prickette; patience was quite worne out, and expectation began to be out of eaon: wherefore Rivana takes the Sack-poet, and ets it upon the cubberds head, and covers it with a trencher and napkin, and ets the candle by it, takes her leave of her Hotee, and prepares her elfe for bed, putting the dore onely too, for feare her Sweet-heart hould finde any difficulty in his approach, if he hould happen to come late, or he, diturb'd to let him in, if it hould be lockt, or bolted: late brought all to bed, that were in the Houe.

Now you mut undertand, that in the evening, before this hapned, that a Bearward had brought three luty Beares to towne, and had taken up quarters for them in the ame Inne, lodging them in a little Stable that happened to be jut underneath the Chamber where Prickette and Rivana had intended to be very uperlative in the degrees of happinee.

But it hapned that Rivana was no ooner got into her bed, but one of the great Beares, enting the teame of the Poet, broke looe, and hapned to pull downe a whole pane in the wall, that opened at the foot of the tair-cae, that led up to Rivana's lodgings: up taires climbs the Beare; Rivana, hearing omebody comming up, was in good hope it had been her Sweet-heart, though he thought the party came up omewhat heavily, and trode (though not more gently, yet) more oftly then Prickette was wont to doe; which he conjectured to be, becaue (it may be) he was in the darke, and had no body to light him up the tayres: and it would be otherwie as oone as he
hould come into the light. [ENTER BEARE.—] Rivana (perceiving o ugly a creature comming in upon all four, winding with his Noe, and twinckling with his Eyes) he inkes down into her Bed, and falls a praying, but durt not cry out, for fear he hould give the Devouring creature notice of her being there: But Teares, which had o little way to fall, and fell o oftly, and trembling, that could make no noie upon a bed of Down, he makes ue of ufficiently, to expree the wofulnee of her condition, and the greatnee of her feare; which was preently augmented and multiplied upon her, like numbers in Arithmetick: for the Bear, (enting the poet) ries up an-end, and with his fore pawes, rets upon the Cubberd, and nuzzles the trencher that covered the Poet off of the Goblet; and thruting his nout into the hot-kept-liquour, he o burnt his noe, that he made a mot fearfull noie; and endeavouring to leap downe, his Nailes o tuck in the Cubberd-cloath, that down comes the Sack Poet about his Ears, the Candle into his Eyes; which the melted tallow, (together with the hot Liquor) had o got into, and made them o mart, that it caus'd him to Roar, as if all the Devills in Hell had been in the roome: All this while the Bears Clawes were not di-ingaged from the Cubberd-cloath, nor the Cloath from what it covered; o that at lat (with the Beares triving) downes comes the great Canopied-cubberd, and all upon the Bear, o that the Bear began to be wore afraid, and more hurt, then the terrified Rivana, who labouring to di-ingage himelfe from the weight that was upon him, (the Candle all this while lying upon the ground, till blazing) the Bear (at lat) intch'd and intch'd o near unto the flame, that it et all the haire upon the Beares back on Fire; whereat the Beare et out a wider throat then all the Baitings that ever he had, could force him to: Rivana (hearing a great deal of noie beides what the Bear made, and received no hurt as yet) thought that ome body had come in unto her recue, as was ordering the Bear, and that the Bear Roar'd o by reaon of ome correction; wherefore he took the boldnee to peep out of the Bed, to ee whether it was o, or not: but when he perceived a thing all on Fire, and another thing over it, tirring up and downe the roome, he began to be afraid of the Devill wore than of the Bear: wherefore he flings the Cloathes over her head again, and falls to making Vowes, That if ever he were delivered from that jut Judgement, that was upon her for that unlawfull Aembly, he would never violate the old Lawes and Cutomes of her devout Ancetors by uch deeds of Anticipation. Whereupon the Beare (di-ingag'd of his Toyle) left Roaring; the Candle and the Hair went out, all was quiet; the Bear fell to licking up his Poet all about the roome; but there hapned to be o much Sack in the Poet, (to which the Bear had not been accutomed) that his Braines were intoxicated; who (wanting a place to repoe his giddy brain) skip-frogs up upon the Bed, and layes him elfe downe halfe on, and halfe off the mierable Rivana. The Bearward (hearing the noie) was riing
out of his bed, to know the caue of their unrulinee; but perceiving them to be quiet, went to bed againe.

By this time Prickette knocks at the dore; the old Woman aketh, Who's there? Prickette cryes, 'tis I. Who are you? (aid the Hotee) 'tis I, Prickette, don't you know my voice? you know my buinee well enough. 'Tis you? (aid the Hotee) is this a time anight? well, I come: he lips an old Petticoate over her houlders, and comes to the dore, and lets him in, telling him, that he was a fine man (indeed) to have a Sweet-heart! if he were as he, he would make him tay the good houre, and if there were a yeare to the end out.

Well, well, (aid Prickette) get you to bed, trouble not your elfe: where is he? is he in the Chamber I bepoke? I, I, he's there (aid the Hotee) can you find the way in the darke? there is a light in the Chamber, and a Sack-poet provided for you: O! you are a weet Youth y-faith, y-faith, he is but too good for you.
Good night, good night old Woman, (aid Prickette) you prate you know not what; too good for me! who is too good for me?

Up the taires comes Prickette, and finds the dore open; but eeing no light in the Chamber, he askes her, What are you in darknee? he had not advanced three teps into the roome, but what with the lipperinee of the boords, by reaon of the Sack-poet, and the licking of the Beares tongue, downe comes Prickette all along; up againe he gets upon his leggs, but had not made one tep nearer the bed, but over the cubberd comes poore Prickette, hurts his hands, and breaks his elbowes; lyes till awhile, and askes, Where am I? what have we here? what's here to doe?

Rivana heard a Man's voice, but was afraid there had been another Beare: at lat he gets up, and was reolv'd to order his teps more warily; at length he layes hold upon one of the Bed-pots, then he thought himelfe afe enough, and that he had her ure; when behold! opening his armes to imbrace his beloved, and his mouth, to betow this pleaing language upon her, viz: Ah my Sweet-heart! I hope thou wilt not be angry with me for taying o long; in troth I could not help it: and therewith falling downe upon the Bed, to take his Mitree in his armes, he imbraced the Beare; who being awaked with his kindnee, roar'd him forth uch a Curtaine-lecture, as I thinke never any uch Delinquent was o mierably erv'd before. Prickette recoiles, foraking his tation with uch violence as the rocks and tones doe ue to make when they are moved out of their places, when hell finds out a new mouth, by ome eruption, out of the earth: o that (forgetting his tumbling block, that lay in his way) he breaks his hins againt the cubberd, and over and over he tumbles, being mot mierably tormented; in which agony (knowing not what he did) mitaking his way in the darke at the bottome of the taires, in tead of going out at the dore, he runs into the broken place in the wall that the Beare had made, and o tumbles upon the other two: [BA-A] cryes one of the Beares: [BA-A, BA-A] cryes the other two. Prickette (imagining no
lee but that flying from one, he had falne into hell, amongt all the Devils, crambles (he knew not how) from between them, and o got looe from both, and recovers his feet, but durt not make any other ue of them than tanding upon them: o unfortunate had his motion been unto him of late, that till he ran into further michief, till at lat the Beares unrulinee made him venture farther off the danger; o that he got cloe to the manger, then he knew where he was; up he gets into it, and (for his greater ecurity ake) climbs up into the rack. The Bearward (hearing a econd alarum, rieth) out of his bed, and came to ee what was the matter, where he oone epied one of his Beares miing, and the wall broke downe, where he had got out, preently he raies the houe, aying, He was undone, one of his Beares was broken looe, and was got away. Up they all rie, unchaine the Doggs, earch for the Beare, enter the Stable, ee where the Beare broke out; which whilt they were viewing they could heare a voice from the rack-ide, aying, Doe you heare, doe you heare, I know where your Beare is with a pox to you: They look'd up, and pied Prickette amongt the rack taves: They askt him, Where? where I pray now? Where (aies Prickette) I know where well enough, but looke that your Beares be afe and I'le come downe and hew you. They ecuring him from all danger, he decends from his palliadoes, and directs them up into his Mitree's Chamber, giving the Bearward, and the Dogs leave to goe before him; who find the Beare fat aleep in Prickette his place; o that with much convenience, they got the tring into the ring, and pull'd the Beare from off the Bed. Prickette turning down the bed to ee what was become of his Sweetheart, there acended uch a wreake of bak'd, and boyl'd, and tew'd, and roat-meat, that his tomach was quite turn'd; o that he had no appetite to his former dainties. She cryes out to him, Prickette, begone; get thee hence, thou comet not neer me: I will have nothing to doe with thee, e'ne tay the time. So they both concluded to wait the leiure when unlawfulnee hould be lee attended with o heavy judgments, and Prickette departed with the Beare, Dogs, and Bearward out of the roome to eeke another lodging.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Lorenzo his ad condition at Court. Berontus meets with Navigius; by whom he informes himelfe of all the buinee concerning Honoria. He carryes the glad tidings to Lorenzo. Bertaldo and Berontus ent to the Ladyes. A Storme at Sea.

div.p: NOw we mut returne to Lorenzo, who all this while remain'd (you will ay) in a very ad condition, when a Prince in his owne Court hall hunt for favourable looks from his owne Subjects, and finde ne'r a one; for, all the Courtiers beheld him, with uch ullen apects, as if Saturne at that time, had animated the Court, with one urly Genius; o great power had the force of jutice over the intruments of iniquity, whom we mut alo leave (as oone as we have lookt upon) in his melancholly dumps to bring back the fortunate Berontus in his happy adventures; for, he had carce reacht within three leagues of the Sea-hore, but he met with Navigius the Sea-man, who had been the Preerver of both the Ladyes, who (having not wit enough to believe that the urpluage of his merit, exceeded the offenivenee of his default) upon the approach of o Courtly Gallants (hearing the Rumours that had pread about the Countrey concerning Lorenzo's Conquet, and Maximanus's Death) was afraid of every Butterflies being a Courtier, making inquiition for Honoria and Amaria, or after any one that had but a hand in that Delinquency; for which reaons he thought himelfe no mall Foole, and that (he thought) he knew not how to anwer the ale of uch Commodities; o that he lookt o gatly, hooke o fearfully, and tood o amaz'd in every repect, that Berontus could not but take peciall notice of him: Wherefore he askt him, What ayl't thou Fellow? and finding him peechlee, he thought ome extraordinary matter, to be the occaion, of that extaie; and conidering the buinee he went about, he thought it worthy of his farther inquiry: wherefore, he caued one of his Attendants, to take him up behind him, and bring him along with him to the next reting place: The Fellow, (thinking, that he had been carried all this while to hanging, (till meauring the 'depth of their cience by the guilt of his owne concience) as oone as ever he was brought to Examination, he cry'd out, Oh Mater! ave but my life, and I will tell you all.
Berontus reply'd, anwer me but to one Question and thou halt not die, Is Honoria living? or cant thou tell what is become of her?
Navigius anwered, he is alive, and well.
And Amaria too? reply'd Berontus.
She's well, and lusty, (aid Navigius.)
What is become of them? (aid Berontus.)
Navigius told him all the Paages of the whole tory as was before related.

Whereat Berontus was o overjoy'd that he hugg'd him in his armes, bidding him not to be afraid of any thing, ince they were living; telling him, that his merit, in their preervation, was o great, that mall faults would not be lookt upon: Both (overjoy'd) made hate to Carthage, where the night before thee glad tidings were brought to Court: Lorenzo (not thinking himelfe worthy of the Attendance that pull'd off his Shooes as he went to bed) was no ooner in bed, but he was aluted with Amynda's Genius with thee glad tidings:

l.hi: Now thou't uffer'd for thy folly,

q.l: Ceae further to be Melancholly:
Thy repentance is accepted,
And thy pray'rs no more rejected:
Honoria he is afe, and ound,

l.hi: Better o, than under ground:

q.l: Amaria' as well as he,

l.hi: Ev'n as well, as well may be:
To morrow when you find it thus,

q.l: Forget Amynda, hey for us!

l.hi: But if you doe, then find you hall,
A worer evill will befall.

p.U: tarts upright in his bed, and cryes out, Oh Amynda! tay awhile; tay I pray thee good Amynda, be not inexorable: what wouldt thou have me to peake? and I vow Obedience to thy Commands; I will not werve a tittle from thy precepts, give me Honoria and command my life.

div.p: Amynda being overcome with his remore, and full intentions of amendment, anwers his deires.

l.hi: Then all that I would have you doe,

q.l: Love Honoria; and be true:
(And Amaria, for her ake)

l.hi: Love you'd better give then take:
Now lye downe and ben't perplext,
Oberve what I hall tell you next.

div.p: Lorenzo falls into a weet leep, untill the morning-watch awak'd him with their anwerings to Berontus his importunities of opening the Gates; who was o tranported with his fraught, that he thought it much, that wood, and iron, hould make his lading dance attendance.

Lorenzo thus awakt, and remembring the good tidings overnight, he thought they were o good, that he began to be afraid they were
too good to be true. Thus the Devill, after we have overcome all his temptations, throwes his lat Dart, and eekes to poyon us with infidelity, like the Ship that hath ecaped o great Enemies, and o many Shipwracks, at lat perihes in the Harbour.

But whilt he was in this great danger, by reaon of o many Rocks and Shelves: Berontus (like a good Pilot, comes to guide him afely into the Harbour) at whoe firt ight, Lorenzo reades comfort in his lookes; and askes him if he has heard of his Honoria, (anticipating his relation with his confidence) in thee words:

p.hi: I know, that if thou hadst not brought good Newes, thou woult not have return'd o oone.

div.p: Berontus taking Nagivius by the hand, from point to point, tells him the full relation of the whole, as hath been before expres'd: Which, when Lorenzo had heard throughout, he knew not whether he hould acknowledg himelf more beholding to the Hand, or to the Intrument, that made uch muick to his Eares: he howr'd down obligations upon Berontus, as upon a Favourite that was capable of receiving thoe acts of Grace: But when he came to expree his affection to Navigius, he found him o unuceptable, that he could not love him otherwie, then with the Love wherewith fond Ladies ue to be in love with their Lap-dogs, whoe over-gladnee at mall favours, make their Mitrees orry that they are not rationall creatures, whereby they may be more capable of further benefits. Both in their kind were fully atisfied, the one with princely language; the other with pitting a few acknowledgments in his mouth, which the one received with due reverence, and good behaviour; the other with o many crapes of his feet, and wagging of his tail.

All the Palace did ring of this good newes; nothing but acclamations of joy and gladnee was heard amongt the People, every body ran to ee Navigius: Berontus was no body amongt the Vulgar, like to like enjoy'd their liking; the poor man was well help'd up, from a peck of troubles, to uch a meaure of admiration, and benignity. Bertaldo was ent for in Pot-hate, (who returning as uddenly.) The next thoughts that were in election, was how thee two Ladyes were to be ent for, and who hould be employ'd in that Affair. It was determined, that Bertaldo and Berontus hould be dipatch'd upon this Embasie; Berontus to the Iland of Majorca, to attend upon Honoria; and Bertaldo to Minorca, to waite upon Amaria. And this for two Reaons, to which I might adde a third.
The firt was, becaue Berontus had been o Fortunate to bring the Good-newes, it was thought fitting that he hould have the Honour of the Employment.
The econd was, That Bertaldo thought it more convenient ervice to wait upon his Mitree, than his Siter.

And the third was, That Lorenzo knew Honoria would be atified ufficiently to hear of her Brothers welfare at any hand, but he could not reward Berontus's ervices with lee repect. Two Ships
were peedily prepar'd, the one for Bertaldo, the other for Berontus: But all had been like to be poil'd, for the Prince taking great affection to Philoret, had gain'd Bertaldo his conent, that Philoret hould tay behind to keep him Company; but there ate uch a cloud on Philoret his Countenance, as made them all fear they hould have no Faire weather after them, if he were left behind; wherefore the Prince willingly releas'd him of his grant.

They were all fairly Shipp'd; but behold, they were carce out of ight of the Maine-land, but their tately Ships were forc'd to trike Saile to angry Neptune: who, with his awfull Trident, muster'd his Turbulent waves, whilt the innumerous Tacklings erv'd for o many Whitles to the winde, to call on danger to her Execution, whilt the Boyling Ocean lifted up her Waves o high, that the Mats of both the Ships charg'd their tops through the proud Heads of the inulting Billowes; till others (as if they had been their Friends) lifted the Victors upon their houlders to uch a height, as their main Mats were in danger to have fallen foul with the Celetiall Sphears; raking from their retlee bottomes, o much Sand, as not onely dicoloured the green Ocean, but alo threatned a diolution of the whole Earth into o many Attomes in the Sea: So that no marvaile, that they had quite lot one another, whilt they were both thus likely to be lot. So that it hapned (by reaon of this Storme) that Bertaldo, who was bound for Minorca, was (by the fortune of the Windes) blown upon the Iland of Majorca; and Berontus (who was bound for Majorca) was thrown upon the leer Iland: The mitake was not o great, whilt their Commiions were both the ame.

Berontus was no ooner arrived there, but the newes was brought to Catriots houe, That there was come from the Maine, the Gallantet Gentleman that ever eyes beheld; and his buinee was, to enquire after a certaine Carthaginian Lady that was forc'd away from her owne Country, and brought hither by Violent hands.

Amaria, at the firt hear-ay, conjectur'd it to be him who was intended, Bertaldo, though it fell out to be him, that hould be there, Berontus, though not by order of Humane, but Divine Affaires. Amaria aves Berontus the labour of Enquiry, and ends him her Name, with directions where to come, if that he knew it, or had any thing to ay to her: He hatens to the place of her abode with uch a longing deire, as good Newes carryes alwayes with it, when it knowes it hall affect the hearer with delight. When Amaria heard that the ame Cavalier was arriv'd at the Gate, he prepares her elfe for uch information, as her owne eyes hould give her, through the Glae, whether it were the ame of whom her hopes had given her ome aurance: But as oone as Berontus began to enter the Court, her hopes began to retire; but eeing him uch another goodly Peronage, and having uch a Manly gate, he thought the Glae might be no true Mediator: Wherefore, deiring to be better inform'd, he onely opens the Caement, o farre as might erve her
Eye-ight to ally out; which was o met withall by his, that it was beaten in againe without receiving the leat intelligence, hutting that Sally-port with uch diligence, as if an Enemy were ready to make his Entry in at the window, whilt the door was open to let in the bet of Friends.

In comes Berontus, who having aluted her, makes her amends for the mitake of the Peron, by bringing her Bertaldo in his Mouth, whoe ervice (as knowing it to be mot acceptable) he preented in the firt place, acquainting the Lady by what accident it hapned, that he was not there himelfe, being deigned purpoely to waite on her, as his was to have attended upon the Princee, Honoria: Amaria was well enough pleas'd to hear of his Welfare, and could have found in her heart to have expreed her feares of his being cat away at Sea; but he mothered her affections for the preent, and fell to asking how Lorenzo did? Scarce had they made an end of all that he had, and he to ay, which took up no mall proportion of time and dicoure, but that a Meenger came to Amaria from Honoria and Bertaldo, to acquaint her, that Bertaldo was there, how they mis'd Berontus, who was deign'd for the place where he now was, acquainting her with the happy newes of all the late Occurrences. Berontus and Amaria being both more at hearts-eae then when they met firt. Amaria, who delighted in nothing more then in hearing relations of deeds of Chivalry: and lov'd men for nothing more then their Prowee; and no Gallantry like that which was hewed againt her deadly Enemy Maximanus: And perceiving how paringly Berontus had touch'd upon that tring, and how his modety had more commended himelfe, then delighted her. She deires him to tell her the manner how, the place where, the time when, with all other particulars concerning the killing of that Wild-Boar, wherein he profeeth he could never be ufficiently atisfied. Whereupon Berontus related unto her the whole ubtance of the Story, with all the circumtances belonging thereunto, in uch orderly manner, and obervance to her commands, that all the Predicaments in Logick were but ervants to his Method, and ubjects to her Reaon: She was o much taken with his Gallantry, giving him many thankes for his Relation; but withall told him, That he was mot of all beholding to her elf: For the bet part of his decription had been left out (if he had not wreted it fro¯ him by degrees) through his modety, that was o wary in letting any thing lip from him to his own advantage that concern'd himelf. Then he fell to the buinee in Mauritania: and when Berontus had but touch'd upon that particular of preerving Lorenzo by his mot happy conduct, he did o conjure him not to mince the matter, but to tell her punctually how it was (uppoing himelf a third peron) upon whoe entreaty he declared more at large. But when he came to peak of that particular ervice at the Bridge, and how fortunate a man had been to the whole Army; and asking him who it was, and could have no other anwer from him but bluhes
and tranciions into other matters, Oh how Amaria was taken with him! he could have leapt into his mouth, and hot the Gulph to come at that faire Harbour where there rid o brave a Man of War. But then he recalls her elfe, and faces about, to the remembrance of the brave Bertaldo, and checks her forward paion for loving a man o much, o oon, whilt all the Berontus'es in Affrica could not exceed Bertaldo, for what he had both heard, and een: But falling into dicoure concerning his partaking with Bertaldo, in the differences which were between him and the Prince, he falls to loving him againe; and hearing Berontus relate how toutly Bertaldo behaved himelfe, in Honoria's and her behalfe, her love runs back againe, and catches at Bertaldo: nor is he wavering all this while, but contant to the true caue of love, worth, and true Nobility: he is not o much in love with either of their Perons, as both their valours; Berontus had laine the Gyant, preerv'd Lorenzo, and Bertaldo both; Bertaldo had done as brave things as thee, had poeion of her heart before; at lat he ditinguihes betwixt loving her houe, and riding on the top of it, he reolves to love him as a wel-deerving Friend, but Bertaldo as a deare Husband; yet notwithtanding her carriage was o full of freedome and repect, that Berontus conceived that in his mind that his honour would not nourih, o they parted for that night.

The next day the wind erv'd faire for Majorca, and they were reolv'd to neglect no opportunity to be together, where they might re-imbark themelves for Carthage, and with a faire wind they joyfully landed, and were as Sumptuouly entertained by Thoron and Armena, as they were gladly received by Bertaldo & Honoria; unexpreible was the joy that was between Honoria and Amaria, the love that was between Amaria and Bertaldo, Bertaldo and Honoria; both joyne hands in etting forth the praies and high Gallantry of Berontus. Berontus joynes iue with Bertaldo, and Honoria, in giving the due Encomiums that were belonging to Philoret; who preently becomes Amaria's chief Favourite, as the Preerver of her life, the life of her beloved, the Honour of Lorenzo, the Glory of the Carthaginians. Amaria would have been in love with Philoret, but what love invited, faith forbade; Berontus would have been in love with Amaria, but that honour tood between: Honoria would have been in love with Lorenzo, but knew not how to come at him: Bertaldo had been in love with Philoret, had he knowne but what he had beene: and Philoret might have been beloved by Bertaldo, had he but had the confidence: if ever there was love in a maze, here it danc'd the round: you might heare of a True-lovers-knot, but never knew of uch a knot (as here was) of True Lovers. In this loving humour they all tooke hipping, and were underaile for Carthage.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: Lorenzo found the Letter by Pippea's means. He heares of their Arrivall: goes to meet them. The Marriage between Bertaldo and Amaria is urg'd amaine: Philoret falls into a Trance upon it: Berontus is love-ick with Amaria. Amaria and Bertaldo are found to be Brother and Siter. Philoret is found to be the Duke of Medina-Coeli his Daughter. Bertaldo and Berontus are ent into Spaine and Italy, to finde out the truth thereof, as the price of both their Loves.

div.p: PIppea by this time is become a pretty Maide, having the confidence to peake unto the Prince; he tells his Highnee what he did, and that Honoria writ a Letter, and how he conveig'd it, and where he layd it.

Lorenzo preently goes and earches the Cabinet, finds it there, and reading it fell into a trembling, with thinking what a wound it would have been unto his injur'd oule, if Honoria had micarried, and afterwards he had ound that Letter; all this Pippea did by the perwaion of Hortenius. The Prince marvelouly commended Pippea for her piety to Honoria, promiing her the chief place of Honour about her.
The newes was brought to Court, of the landing of Honoria, and the ret.

The Prince was ahamed to looke his owne happinee in the face, and to ee, that, which he mot deired, yet he truted to two friends to beare him out, Honoria's goodnee, and his owne acknowledgment: he goes out to meet her, and finds her in a mot conventent place for gratulation; where, decending his Charriot as he hers, he ayes thus unto her; Honoria, if I hould quetion thy pardon, I hould tax thy goodnee; Mercy is Lady and Empree of all the bet of Attributes, I have a great deale to ay, more to confee, mot of all to acknowledge; if thou wilt give me time, I will take no lee then all my life, to betow in repentance and atisfaction—
And as he was peaking further, he cuts him off with this prevention,

p.hi: My Lord, I pray ay no more; he's dead that was the caue of this, and in his grave, let the memoriall of all thee things be buried, I am afraid you have been too evere a Puniher of your elf already, I am glad I was preerv'd for no other caue—

div.p:
And as Honoria was going on in her dicoure, Bertaldo tops the current of her peech (till the treame well'd o high, that her heart floated in compaion of Lorenzo's orrow for her ufferings) aying, You two hall take another time, and place, when you are by your elves, then and there you can bet charme one another into beliefs, which none
can quetion whilt you are one anothers Judges, and by none attonements ooner wrought then when you are each others Advocates: Lorenzo, be but you her Votary, and I'le undertake he hall be your Confeour, mall pittance hall erve for abolution. As Honoria would not heare Lorenzo; nor Bertaldo, Honoria; o all the Company cry'd downe Bertaldo, perceiving that no better accommodation might be made, then what hould proceed from the goodnee of their owne dipoitions, when tongues hould be as farre from interpoing as eares from giving audience; all was huh'd, Lorenzo takes Honoria into his Charriot; Bertaldo, Amaria, into his; both Berontus: all three (the generally o much beloved) Philoret, Lorenzo & Honoria had little dicoure, much handing, more kies, many ighes; Bertaldo, and Amaria, Berontus, and Philoret, were all Chatt; thus they made the way hort to Carthage, where the People fill'd the Streets with Voices, and the Ayre with Acclamations of Joy, and Gladnee, for that happy meeting; in a word, the whole buinee was o weetly compo'd between Lorenzo and Honoria, as if his heart had been a Jubile, and hers a plenary indulgence.

Thus tated, as at firt, they began to entertaine thoughts, how they might drive a trade of happinee between Bertaldo and Amaria, whilt Berontus was love-ick for Amaria, and Philoret deadly in love with Bertaldo, yet neither of them durt expree the caues of their dicontents; the one through a uppoed unworthinee in himelf, the other let he hould hew any defect in worth towards o brave a friend.

Bertaldo and Amaria both hearken to the muick that Lorenzo and Honoria caus'd for to ound in both their eares; at which, Berontus made as oure a face, as Philoret lent them a deafe eare; at lat Philoret ingling out his Mater, pake unto him in this manner:

Sir, You know with what a pasionate affection I ever lov'd you, you know what preferments I ever waved to enjoy this relation; I perceive there is an overture of Marriage between you and Amaria; you have oftentimes bid me aske what I would: I never askt you any thing, but now I hall.
My deare heart (aid Bertaldo) aske what thou wilt, and I will grant it thee.
Then (aid Philoret) I onely aske, that you would not Marry; I doe not aske, you would not Marry her: for, of all Women living, he's worthiet to be had.
Thy reaon, good Philoret? (reply'd Bertaldo.)
Becaue I love you, (aid Philoret.)
Why hould thy love (aid Bertaldo) prompt thee to uch a prohibition?

Becaue (aid Philoret) it is not good to part with that deare priviledge of being wholly a mans elfe, to be the halfe of another; beides, all the pleaure I have in this world is in your love; all my ambition is to deerve it, and all my tudy is how I may improve that happinee. Now when you have a Wife, your love will be et on her, and I hall but gleane
in the ame field where I formerly reapt a full Crop of Blie: and therewith fell into a mot udden paion and extreame weeping.

Whereat Bertaldo taking him in his armes, intended him this atifaction, My deare Philoret, I will Marry her, but on this condition, that he hall double, not mitigate the love I beare to thee: Sweet Boy, had I as many Wives as Carthage Women, they all hould not be able to eclipe the leat parke of the true affection which I beare to thee, and to thy merit. Jut as he had poken that word, there came a Servant from the Prince, deiring his company; he clapping Philoret on both his cheeks, with both his hands, bid him be confident that all the Wives in the world, hould not draw away his affection from him, and o left him weeping.

In which poture Berontus found him, and enquiring into the caue, and by Philoret's anwer, finding it to be grounded upon his dilike of the Marriage, he imbraces both him and his dicontent, fotering it up to a full growth, as agreeable to his humour; but all in vaine: for, the Match was made, the Parties agreed, the Time et; onely Bertaldo told his Mitree, with what reluctancy Philoret reented it, and upon what grounds, deiring her to ue her utmot indeavour to dispoee him of that conceit.

Amaria undertakes it, and ends for Philoret: who being come, Amaria takes him aide, and thus intreats him: Sweet-heart, I undertand thy love to be uch to thy Mater, that thou think't it will be lee, when he has me; I have ent for thee to aure thee, that it will be double; when we two are one, you mut ditinguih between love, and love; it is one thing to love a Wife, and another thing to love a Friend, or Favourite; the love of the one, no way leens the obligations and ties of friendhips that are between the other, but rather incloes them in bounds and fences, whereby they are not violable. Truely, Philoret, I know thy love to be uch to thy Mater, and thy merits to be o great in every eye, that were I not engag'd unto Bertaldo by promie, and oblig'd by honour, of all the Men that carry heads upon their houlders, I hould love Philoret, and therefore never feare that his love hould be lee to thee. Amaria (perceiving Philoret his colour to be quite gone, and a Civill warre begun already upon his cheekes, between the white Roe and the Red) leaves off peaking, (as men leave wounding when they think the party almot dead) when poor Philoret had fallen to ground, had not Amaria catcht him falling, who (like ome young Phyitian) eeing his Potion begin to work by contraries, feares he had mitaken the right Glae, and precrib'd his Patient Poyons intead of Cordialls: o affrighted was Amaria in applying remedies where he was o ignorant of the dieae. Philoret comes to himelf, whom Amaria leaves, as Doctors doe their Patients, when they begin to be dangerous, carrying that ad newes of irrecovery to Bertaldo, who flies to his beloved Page, catching him up in his Armes, asking him what he ayl'd? And what he would have? Bidding him declare his mind fully, what he would, before he Marryed: or whether Honour,
Preferment, Land, Riches, Money mot affected him, it hould be granted; and if he doubted his Marriage would be an Obtacle to any of thee, he would never Marry untill he had atisfied him in any of the particulars.
Philoret anwered him, I ask nothing, but that you would not Marry; all thee things I have foraken already for your ake, and if you Marry I mut forake you, and die.
Bertaldo told him, that it was but the Exuberance of his affection, which in time may eaily be remedied: telling him, That fondnee mut give way to Princes Edicts.
It was decreed by Lorenzo's Command, that to morrow mut be the day that Amaria and he mut hake hands in Holy Wedlocke.
Then (aid Philoret) I may lie at your feet this night.

Philoret (aid Bertaldo) thou halt lie for ever at my heart, as my bet friend for ever. Come, I'le call thee Page no more, thou halt be my elfe; and afterwards I hall let thee know, that thy fears are needlee, and that thy dicontents tand upon no ground.

Thus pat the night away, when in the morning there was nothing to be eene, but preparations for the Wedding; time drawing on, the accutomed preparations for the Solemnity, newes was brought, that Berontus was very ick, and could not attend the Ceremony; Philoret had fallen into everall ditempers, and fits of oundings, (trange Preludiums to uch Solemnities) Berontus his condition was not much weigh'd, becaue not any knew the caue of his ditemper; but Philoret, his cae was much reented by thoe who were not ignorant either of the Malady, or the Remedy. Amongt whom Bertaldo was the forwardet (as the mot expert) Phyitian in feeling of his Pule: Who comming to Philoret, aid, Thou (young man) that astonihet all men with thy Miracles, and me with thy Love, why dost thou expire o often? There mut be omething to hinder every man from the perfection of a Deity. Why wilt thou ullie all thy former actions with uch fondnes? more befitting ome female weaknes, than relating to uch prowee as is alwaies reident in thy manly breast; why art thou uch a jarre to all our muick, rain't thy teares upon our joyfull harvet? Come, I ne'r Chid thee before in all my life, nor ever thought I hould; and why hould I Chide thee, ince it is rather the errour of love, than love of errour? thou committ't the fault, and I'le give atifaction; aske and have what thou wilt of me; for, by all that's good, wert thou capable of a nearer relation than that of Friendhip, even of that I'm going about and hould'st aske me, Amaria hould not tand between thee and thy Contentment. Heavens! what confuion that word cat into his thoughts! what changeablenee into his countenance! what rain bows were tied in True lovers knots upon his cheeks! he gave his eyes free leave to peake his minde, whil't he deny'd his heart the benefit of it's own Advocate; he lets illy and unexperienc'd wihes, allie out of that trong-hold, whilt effective words & language were kept in like conquerable
Lyons within their Grates; at lat, (conidering the confuion that would follow his dicovery, but mot of all fearing the deniall that his uppos'd diparity would oone give check to uch a Mate) his mind gave him rather to break his Heart, than break his Mind; and choe rather to die a acrifice to humility, than to embroile uch Lovers in dicontents, to atisfie his own deires, by uch preumption; giving Bertaldo this anwer, ent up by the wellings of his Heart, no riing of any Lungs.
Bertaldo, I am contented that you hall Marry Amaria, and enjoy her, upon one condition, that you will onely give me leave to mourn this day, and I hall never trouble you with any more Petitions.

Bertaldo admiring at his uite, yet being us'd to uch exotick fondnee, cutome took away the trangenee of it; whereupon he gave him leave (not thinking that he had meant any other kind of mourning, then not rejoycing with the ret) whereat Philoret eem'd to be much pleas'd, and Bertaldo, glad that he had any way contented him) repaires to Amaria, whom he confounds with the relation, in thinking with what trange predominance his love bare way; however he reolves to humour him likewie for the future, and by her loving carriage towards him to let him ee his Errour. But when the time drew near, that hand in hand hould joyne two hearts in one; Behold Lorenzo, he falls uddenly ick, whoe indipoednee to attend the Ceremony, bequeathes the gift of Amaria into Holy Hands, to be delivered to Bertaldo, to the performance of the brave Berontus: who being ick with Love, was deadly afraid he hould thereby be acceary to his owne detruction; how avere oever his minde was to the Princes deputation, yet neceity laid uch trong hold upon him, together with Bertaldo his Entreaties, and Amaria's Courthip, that it eem'd no otherwie to him, then as if he had been compell'd to act that part with uch an impulion, as wherewith the evill detinies drive men to be their own Executioners.

Thus all was out of order, whilt ignorance is about to joyne hands with Devotion, to act unlawfull things under the pretenion of Holy Rites: on they ruh, as well as they may, they think no hurt, they doe no good: Montrum horrendum informe ingens cui lumen ademptum. They enter the Holy Place, the Priet is preent, the Parties ready, the People by, the Ceremonies begun, Berontus is call'd upon to doe his Office; he goes about what he had rather let alone, unwillingly willing he takes Amaria by the hand; and when he hould deliver her to the Priet, he holds her fat, and would not let her goe; and when he hould peak certaine words, he declares by an uncertaine kind of peech, which had no other articulates but the weight of language, I mean his tears; that what he did, came not from his heart, whereby eeming to erve for no other ue, then as a dumb and enlee Statue; her hand was taken out of his, and given to another, who gave it to the Priet to be delivered to Bertaldo, who were then, and there, publiquely Married in the fight of all the
world. Never till this time, when it eem'd too late, did Amaria perceive that Berontus was in love with her, whoe pitty of his condition made her orry that he had not known it ooner; and that orrow caued Bertaldo to perceive a kind of reluctancy in Amaria's countenance, as if he had not been well pleas'd with what he had done, which made him not o well pleas'd with his Bargaine as otherwie he would have been: But behold a ad ight adminitred a greater occaion of dilike, than was the former; for Philoret, overet with Melancholly of the Blacket hue, tudies a way how to improve it to the highet. Wherefore when he perceiv'd them all gone to the Wedding, he puts on a Mourning Habit, and all alone goes into the roome prepar'd for the Dinner, where olemnity had plac'd two Chaires of State for the Bride, and Bridegroome, to enthrone themelves in Majety; Thus accoutr'd, Philoret eates himelfe in the Brides Chair; and throwing his upper Garment over his houlder, he ettles his minde to as deep a Melancholly, as either his outward Habit, or his Poture, hung out ignes: Thus under the hadow of depaire its Philoret, like a condemned Victim preed to death, whoe inability to indure the preent paine, makes him cry more weight; untill oppresion made him enlee, falling into a charitable lumber, that put him into uch a pleaing dreame, as in a manner was able to quit cot to all his anxieties: He dream't, how, that after death, he was found to be a Virgin; and that Bertaldo lov'd him better dead, than when he was alive, and that he wept over him; and that his Teares were uch an Embalmement, that he hould never Rot, nor Stink; he dream't the looe Earth over his Grave to be tranparent; o that he could ee Bertaldo, and Amaria, trewing Herbes and Flowers over his Grave, and from their wolne eyes, to pour uch virtuall howers upon that Covering, that the Flowers rooted, and were everlating: whilt the bordering Willowes round his Semitary, with lifting up their armes by a jut wind, refus'd their Boughes to hands, that were too forward for to pluck Materialls where withall to make him Garlands. In which interim, in comes Bertaldo, with Amaria in his hand, with all their Concommitants to that half olemnity, where finding Philoret aleep in uch a Poture, uch a Seat, uch Habit, and at uch a time, it truck them into uch a dumpe, that Raine in Harvet was never o unwelcome to the greedy Husband-man, as this ight was caue of dicontent to the two Triumphants; they all tood about him, and pitied both his leep and waking; all fell a wondring why aleep, why in Mourning, why in her Chaire, why at that time jut, when others were in Celebration of o great Solemnity!

Lorenzo ick, Berontus he not well, Philoret o ignificant in his perplexity, never was there a Wedding o like a Funerall, whil't the two ubjects of that mirth and jollity that was expected, were the chiefe Mourners to o many unexpected caues of adverity: thus he remain'd, and thus the ad Spectators all continued, untill uch time as
the Prince his Sewer uher'd in the Dihes to the Bridall boord; when the mell of o many everall meats (like an enemy to his repoe) gave an alarum to his five enes to repaire to their everall posts.

Philoret (as yet a tranger to himelfe) could not behold o great a lutre, as the glory of that day preented to his eyes; o that he was forc'd to call in his Scouts before they had enabled him with the leat intelligence.

Amaria preing forwards to receive an account of his well or evill fare, (Bertaldo tanding behind her) Philoret thought himelfe in an eclipe (perceiving the Moone to be between him and his Sunne) yet in that darknee, he findes the way to o much weetnee, and civility, as that he tooke Amaria by the hand, and eated her in her Throne; which having done, he inks downe dead at her very feet.

Bertaldo catches him up againe, ues all the meanes to recall him to himelfe, but all in vaine: he remaines breathlee, no pules beat, nor igne of life at all: All give him for dead; he makes hate by degrees, till he becomes as cold as earth; he is delivered into proper hands for laying of him forth: Bertaldo weeps, whil't all were o full of orrow, that there were no Comforters, none ate downe to eate, whil't the meat, as ympathizing with the accident, cool'd as if it dyed, loing their artificiall, as he his naturall heat; who can imagine the orow that in generall fill'd every particular breat? but to conceive the vat load that lay upon Bertaldo, who acknowledged him elfe guilty of the murder, by giving o deafe an eare to Philoret's often inculcations, that he hould not Marry, and that if he did he hould urely dye: which had he but believ'd, all the world hould not have perwaded him to have haken hands with any Creature living.

Amaria began to conider with her elfe, how happy it had been if Bertaldo had oberv'd the Injunctions of his Darling; and he had knowne that Berontus had been o in love with her, whom he alwaies lik'd and honour'd; but durt not hew it by reaon of her Ingagement, nor he declare his mind initing upon tearmes of Honour, whom miing, all upon a udden (as fearing that that two Tragedies might be acted in one day) he cries, What is become of Berontus? when behold, in comes the Meengers of the mot ditracting newes that ever reached eares; for, the Women who came from laying forth the body of poore Philoret, pake amazement by their lookes, before they us'd a tongue, whoe eye-auditors (as if they had receiv'd ome trange intelligence) ask'd, What's the matter? and how? to they knew not what.
Whil't Bertaldo impatient to be tormented long with ilent Monters, bid them peake their minds, and tell him what it was that made them looke o gatly?
Oh! Sir, (aid one of them) if you would needs know, Philoret was a pure Virgin, and no Man.

At which word, Bertaldo tore his hayre, rent his wedding garments, rav'd & roar'd about the roome, not caring what was mi becomming
either a tout heart or a manly courage, and gives himelfe wholly over to be way'd by Paion.

p.U: he runs forth to view the Corps, brings word to Bertaldo, that it was o indeed.

div.p: Whereupon, Bertaldo could not endure the ight of Amaria, that was the caue of this; nor himelf, that had o much doted upon her: blames the dead, then takes all the blame upon himelfe, that he was uch a Block-head as not to conceive o much before, perceiving o many Symptomes of love that could not be but Foeminine by its violence, proteting before all the Gods, that had he but opened her mouth in the leat intimation concerning any uch matter, he would have had her whatoever he were, before any Woman living: then troubles himelfe with imaginations, who it hould be, what might be her name, perwading himelfe it mut be one of more than ordinary ranke and quality: Then mads himelfe that he had not knowne it, excuing her with attributes of modety, and humility; with thee ditractions, frenzies, and generall condolements, they pas'd the day, whil't the night invited, not their maladies, to eeke remedies by repoe; thoughts of Coffins, dead Bodies, and Graves, interdicted the Ceremony of the Bed; all was neglected, and what was tranget of all, the married Couple was not onely carelee of themelves, but of one another: and how could Bertaldo delight in her, when he delighted in nothing ele, but thinking how he might have been anothers? and how could Amaria joy in him, when he thought of nothing more, but how he might have been any way happier, than in the condition he was in; whil't orrow for what they had done made them acceptable, repentance makes way for Amynda her redemption; for, the time of her promied comforts, and aitant graces was at hand, wherein he viiteth the ick Lorenzo, and brings him tidings of the recovery both of his health and undertanding.

q.l: Arie Lorenzo, inne no more;

l.hi: Thou'rt perfect, as thou wert before;

q.l: Bertaldo 'nd Amaria, hu'd

l.hi: They marry, blood would touch with bloud;
One man begot, the ame Wombe bare
Them both; o near akin they are:

q.l: Whom Philoret you deeme to be,
She's Periia, even he,

l.hi: Whom you hall ee alive hereafter,

q.l: The Duke Medina Coelies Daughter;

l.hi: Touch and Wipe the eyes that weep,

q.l: She is not dead, but falne aleep;
Let her have her oules delight:

l.hi: Diolve the Married Couple quite:

q.l: Let Berontus freely have,
His Amaria: grief, a grave.

div.p: Lorenzo, like a refreh'd Gyant, rouzes up himelf, and muters his Diconolates, acquainting them with the trange newes that was reveal'd unto him, whoe misbelief he oone rectified by telling them, that they hould all know this to be true by Periia her being not dead, but in a trance, inviting them all as Witnees to her reurrection, whom they all follow through o many degrees of love: Confidence fill'd the Roome, whilt Hope attended the touch, that rais'd her up to life. Periia comes to her elfe, both in name and nature, and admires to heare Lorenzo call her Periia; wonders to heare Bertaldo ay, Ah my Periia! why would't thou conceale this from thy beloved, whoe oule and thine were ever Man and Wife? wonders to heare Amaria ay, dearet Periia, you hall freely enjoy what you deire, I must not tand between you and that Happinee. Wonders to heare Bertaldo ay, that Amaria was his owne Siter, and that the Weddingknot mut be diolv'd, and fatned betweene them two, (meaning Bertaldo and her elfe) but chiefly wonders at Honoria her calling upon Lorenzo, to give her an account how that he was ole Daughter and Heire to the Duke of Maedina Coeli.

Like a Man that has layen long in ome darke Dungeon, and is uddenly brought into uch a light, whoe rayes (from that replendent unne) make uch a glory round about him, that his weake eyes are not able to comprehend o great a lutre: In uch a pleaing Confuion was Periia, o tifled was her orrow in the throng of o many preing happinees.

Like a knot of True-lovers of one another, yet all in miery, and in want, and ready to be hunger-tarv'd, epying the relief of ome large and bountifull portion of meat to be brought to ome one of them, all rejoyce alike, knowing they hall all participate of that bounty: o did this joyfull newes which was brought unto Periia, fill with ioy, and ravih with delight, all thee Companions in miery; knowing, that this viand, would be food to all their appetites; for, (aith Berontus) if this be o, then Bertaldo hall have Periia, and Amaria he's free for me: then thought Amaria, if this Knot be diolv'd, I am not o ty'd, but that I may enquire into the caues of Berontus his distemper, and if occaion erve, apply fit remedies.

Each everall application of thee joyfull tidings to their owne particulars (for the preent) hindred that univerall Conflux which (otherwie) would have been amongt them, till at lat the everall pecies contributed all their interet to make up one generall gladnee and Jubile of delight, like a maine River that being divided into everall petty Channels, runnes not with uch a large treame as when it was united, but meeting all into one Current again, the everall diimboguements reduce it to its former greatnee.

Thus re-intated, the everall intruments and voices make one harmony, whil't the diverities of Wel-wihers lent their eares according to their everall engagements; ome wih'd well unto Berontus, others were glad of Periia her good fortune, not a few were overjoy'd
at Amaria's freedome, all were tranported with a ravihing delight to ee Fortunes-wheele turne o merrily: the Parties themelves thought their conditions o good, that upon the udden they were unwilling to owne them; one was modet, and could not; another was bahfull, and durt not; a third thought her elfe bound, and might not; a fourth thought himelfe freed, and would: This begot a liberty in the Correllative, which example begot no lee confidence in the bahfull, then encouragement in the mot modet oule; all act their parts accordingly: Bertaldo lights his Amaria, and Courts the new rai'd Periia, to life, hope, name, and fortune: Amaria takes it not amie, and entertains the free embraces of Berontus: Lorenzo and Honoria rejoyce to ee thee promis'd miracles take effect, and their wonders come to uch maturity. Bertaldo prees aurances upon Periia; he holds off, looks trangely upon him, in her mayden habit, and protraction drawes a heavie load of inupportable impatience after it: he lookes no babies in his eyes, he ues not to be turn'd away, he upplicates for no protration at his feet, he carries all things high, (til giving him a repect that in tate becomes a Princee, of her degree, unto a Peron of uch Ranke and quality) he gives her all the obervance that her Majety requir'd, kneel'd and kis'd her hand, made peeches upon his knee, prayes her to be mercifull, and forgive his ignorance.
She takes all to her elf, and after many upplications and prayers, he ayes unto him, Tell me truely, Bertaldo, dot thou believe that I am the Duke of Medina Coeli's Daughter?
To whom Bertaldo reply'd, I am confident you are, & believe it verily. From whence aries o trong faith? (aid Periia.)

Bertaldo reply'd, Shall I not believe Amynda's Ghot? hall I not give credit to Lorenzo's relation? beides, none could doe the things which thou hat done, but Coeli's off-pring, wherfore I cannot tagger.

This is not enough Bertaldo (aid Periia) you must doe omething more for me, I enjoyne you to repaire forthwith unto my owne Countrey, and my Fathers houe, and there inquire if they mie not a Daughter, that hath thee ignes upon her arme, the Sunne and Moone (hewing them unto Bertaldo in the ight of all the Standers by) and aying, if thou cant by thy endeavours finde out uch a one, there's uch a one for thee.
Bertaldo kis'd her hand, preently tooke his leave, aying, he would not neglect a minutes time, and hoped to returne hortly, and give her atisfaction to her demands: o departed.

Berontus finding all the clouds dipell'd that were between him and his heaven, lifts up his eyes to Amaria; he taking Periia for her leading Starre, takes the ame coure he did, and propoes to Berontus her injunction, as a patterne for her imitation, aying unto him, Goe to Rome and learne how it was that I am Honoria's Sister, and I am your Wife: So they were both dipatch'd upon their Knight's Errantries, whil't the two task-Mitrees, like innocent Children, who pend
their time in the delightfull recreation of making Babies, acting Weddings, and Lyings in; o did thee two pretty pieces of innocence, delight themelves with making a Mock-wedding between Pippea and Hortenius, delighting themelves with a happinee, which they were contented hould be really their owne, o that it might be but repreentatively theirs. And thus it was occaioned.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: Pippea is in love with Hortenius. She exprees it to his Picture. Honoria and Amaria oberve it. Hortenius takes her in the manner. Honoria, and Amaria, acquaint Lorenzo with it; who perwades them to incourage the two Lovers in their affections.

div.p: PIppea being o highly preferr'd as to be Honoria her Chiefet Maide of Honour, and Hortenius likewie a Man in no mall requet with Prince Lorenzo; Pippea being firt in Honour, Hortenius durt not break his mind unto her, before uch time as he lighted upon this encouragement; Lorenzo to gratifie Hortenius his merits, and ufferings, (which acts of contrition and ignes of repentance, he dayly exerci'd in expiation of his crime, and complacence with his Honoria) caued his Statua to be et over the Garden-dore, with this incription underneath in Capitall & Golden Letters, viz:

q.p: THIS IS THE PORTRAICTURE OF HORTENSJUS THE PRINCES GARDENER, A FAITHFUL SERVANT AND CONSTANT SVFFERER IN HONORJA AND AMARJSSA'S CAVSE, VVHOM NO TORMENTS COVLD FORCE TO BE OTHER VVISE, NO THREATS COVLD PREVAILE VPON, AND NO ENTICEMENTS COVLD SHAKE HIS RESOLVTION.

div.p: It hapned (at undry times) when Honoria and Amaria went to recreate themelves in the Garden, (with their uuall Attendants) that they evermore oberv'd Pippea to tay behind at the door gazing upon Hortenius his Picture, which Amaria one time amongt the ret taking peciall notice of, he thus pake unto Honoria:
Upon my life your Maid Pippea is in Love with Hortenius, for I have oberv'd her alwayes when he comes by that Picture, he cannot enter the Garden without a great deal of contemplation upon it.
Honoria, loving her the better for being o much an admirer of her Martyr, reply'd, I pray lets goe and oberve her a little.

All agreed, and found out a mot convenient place for obervation, where they aw Pippea laying her hand upon her Heart, and at lat wiping her Eyes; and having cleared that skie from thoe bottl'd clouds, he look'd o wihly upon that Type, untill the thing typified came behind her, catcht her in his Armes, and ask'd her what he was looking upon? Pippea finding her elf urpris'd) was ahamed to look him in the Face; who would have been much more out of Countenance, had he but known who were Spectatours of thoe amorous paions of hers upon a imilitude. This was not all the Sport that the Ladyes had, for they might hear Hortenius asking her the quetion why he look'd o much upon the Figure, and o little upon the Subtance?

And Pippea anwering him, I mut goe to my Mitree. Hortenius praying her not to be o hard hearted, as altogether to turne her face to a Stone, and not at all to rejoyce the Man it repreented, with one copy of her Countenance. And he anwering him againe, I mut be gone, the Princee will wonder what is become of me, pray let me goe. Hortenius aying, I will not let you goe before I have a Kie of you. Pippea anwering, I pray don't you tay me. Hortenius urging, don't you tay your elfe, let you hould be mis'd. Pippea replying, why doe not you let me goe then? Hortenius telling her, becaue you will not give me my due. Your due (aid Pippea) what's that? A kie (aid Hortenius.) How comes that to be your due? (aid Pippea.) Kies are Loves tribute (aid Hortenius) and if you can find in your heart to ay you doe not love me, I will have none. Why (aid Pippea) doe Maides ue to Kie, or to be Kis'd? Hortenius rectified his errour with kiing her over and over againe, and o let her goe. When he was got out of his reach, he turn'd about againe, and told him, That if it had not beene for the hates ake he made to come to her Mitree, he hould not have had it; and with that runs into the Garden. Hortenius tayed behind, let their familiarity hould be taken notice of, whilt the eyes that applauded his affection were in love with his Policy, and reolv'd to advance his humility a degree higher.

Pippea made uch hate, for fear of offending, that they were all very well pleaed, that he had not dicovered them to be uch Eaves-Droppers, as they had made themelves. Pippea running towards the
upper end of the Garden, they advance from their Station. Pippea not finding them in any of the upper ends of the Garden, upon her return (at the firt) was glad to ee them between her and the door, as banihing that fear which he had conceived of her loytering behind; but when he perceived them all to fall a Laughing, which could not be interdicted, (though the Princee had given peciall Command that not any hould take the leat notice of what they had eene) he was amaz'd; and her Bluhes came o thick into her Face, that the Bloud began to grow dark in her Cheeks; which Honoria perceiving, (and willing to deliver her from that fear) told her, Pippea, we laugh to ee that thou couldt not finde us: but indeed, we play'd the wags with thee, and hid our elves from place to place.
Pippea glad it was no otherwie, dimis'd the Bloudy enignes out of o fair a Field, and rufled up the Colours in her Cheeks: o there was no more of that for that time.

But it hapned not long after, Honoria and Amaria to have ome private dicoure, both perceiving Hortenius and Pippea to be deeply in love with one another, (themelves being enible of the mart of Love) and that neither of them durt hew, or effect the thing they mot deired: Thee two mercifull Ladyes were reolv'd to be charitable, and went, and made the Prince acquainted therewith, who was not onely glad of opportunities, whereby he might gratifie his Honoria, but was exceedingly glad to act any thing that might be pleaing to o great intruments of uch univerall happinee: Preently bids them forward what they had taken uch notice of to be begun, and encourage the parties to proceed in their Commencement, to give their hopes ome aire, and to help their love to wings; and that they hould be both Honourably provided for.

Honoria having received thee intructions, ends for Pippea, and quetions her in private concerning the Love that was between her, and Hortenius; but perceiving her Maid begin to Bluh, he anticipates her Crime, by her preventing Grace, and Favours towards her, with telling her how he knew it, and what he had oberv'd with her owne Eyes, beides what he heard: This aved her from the inne of telling an untruth (which was upon the termes of breaking its prion) and gave her leave to turne a flat deniall into a laudable excue, aying:

p.hi: Truly Madam, I confee I love him, o mut all that love you, amongst whom I have a little more reaon then the ret, becaue we were fellow-Agents in the work of your Deliverance. Truly Madam, I could not chue but behold his Picture; and when I look upon it, I can but envy his happinee.

div.p: Why didt thou mite thy breat, and weep when thou look't upon it? (aid Honoria.)

I wept (aid Pippea) to think upon the miery you were in; and I truck my breat for orrow, that I was not abler to have done you more ervice
then I did, that I might have uch another et up for me, to which I think no Glory or Honour comparable.

Honoria forthwith proteted, that he had deerv'd no lee than he; and that he did more for her Capacity, than he for his; and that he would erect the like Memoriall for her, and place it at the very entrance into her Chamber, as Lorenzo had done for his Hortenius at the entrance into his Garden: and perform'd the thing he promied. Which was no ooner done, but Hortenius could never be from Honoria's Chamber Door, nor Pippea from the Garden Frontipice, where they dayly acrifice Hecatombes of the bet wihes to one anothers Shrines.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

argument.p: Corderius wiheth Favorinus to a rich Widow. She cornes all younger Brothers. How Favorinus got her good will at lat.

div.p: COrderius and Fortunata, (whoe Dayes were Holy, and whoe Nights were Sanctuaries, whoe mindes gave them to reduce their Piety, to Practice) contented not themelves with a bare notion of Speculative Divinity, Orall Piety, or Auricular Devotion; but they mut be doing Good, and acting deeds of Charity: for indeed, Religion is Gods Plough, whereby he Tills the Field of his Church, whereby that Field is made a fit receptacle to receive the Seed of the Word. This Plough goes not forward (onely) by looking before us, but by putting hands unto it alo; and bending the everall parts of the body in a Devout poture to fungifie their everall Offices, leaving the two maine Props, and Supporters of the whole, not to goe before the hands, but to thrut them forwards. Thus Religiouly-minded were thoe Purer ones; not to wear the palmes without the Crown of vertue; Charity: and not to uffer Charity to begin in a wrong place, but where it hould begin, at home: Wherefore (being themelves advanced to Wealth and Honour) they entertained thoughts how they might preferre their poore Brother Favorinus to ome good Fortune.

Corderius cating about which way he might effect his longing deires; at lat, he bethought himelfe of a young rich Widow, who had a bountifull Etate; and to boot, too good an opinion of her elf, who was a Beautifull, but withall, a Scornfull Lady, who contantly wore upon her leeve a Nettle: And if you ask'd her the reaon why he grac'd that regardlee Weed o much? he would anwer you, That he wore it not for a grace, but to digrace and ting away Younger brothers. This Lady, what for her Riches ake, and what for her Beauties fame, was Courted by mot men of Fortune, Comelinee,
great Parts and Excellence in all thoe parts, but no man was good enough for her, (o well he thought of her elfe.)

Here was little hopes (you will ay) for Favorinus, who was not onely a Tounger brother, but one, whoe Prodigall Father, had made a Tounger brother, of his Eldet Child: But Corderius from time to time oberving a vivacity and prightlinee to be (prodigiouly) predominant in the well-temper'd nature and dipoition of Favorinus his Brother-In-law, (whom he lov'd o dearly, both for his owne, and Siters ake) that he thought him a fit intrument, either to make this Widow his own, or ele to let her know her elfe: he acquaints Favorinus with the buinee, and dipoition of the Lady; giving him thee encouragements withall, That if he would but put the bet Leg forward, it hould not want Shooes nor Stockings anwerable to the occaion, nor Friends to back him; and if need required, what further might be requiite.
Favorinus reply'd, He that cannot wim to a Widowes Bed ide thus held up by the Chin, it is pity but that he hould ink for ever, and never be eene 'mongt men any more.

Favorinus forthwith accoutres himelf with all the necearies requiite for a Compleat Suitor; and ends the Widow word, that at uch a time he intended to wait upon her about uch a buinee, deiring her not to be abroad.

Bialta, for o was the Widow nam'd, (having Non-uited many a brave Gallant in her time, (who thought themelves no mall fools) and wondring to receive uch a confident Meage from a Man, over whoe Name Fame had never blown her Trumpet in her eares) didain'd the Propoition: yet was reolv'd to tay at home, though to no other purpoe, but to give him an Affront; and let her Triumph hould want Spectators, he ends for ome of her Neighbours to be there at the ame time, as witnees to the Repule he meant to give him. Favorinus (as confident as his own naturall and acquir'd abilities would give him leave) repaires to her dwelling-place at the time appointed, (alwayes holding this for a Maxime in Loves chool, That there is never a Woman in the world, but he is to be won one way or other, if a man could hit upon the right) and having heard, and read the many papers of Veres, and Acroticks upon her Name (as o many Encomiums of her beauty, and perfections; as alo what Honymouth'd Orators he had banihed out of the dominion of her Beauty with Vinegar faces) he reolv'd to teer another coure, and (like skilfull Seamen) to lavere, and fetch compaes of winding policies to his wihed point.

To the houe he comes, but findes no preparations for his comming; no Neatnee extraordinary in any part thereof; he was faine to knock twice or thrice at the Hall door before any body would come at him: at lat one came, and ask'd him, What he would have? who anwered the Fellow (as urly) That he would have the Widow.
If you can have her good will (aid the Servant) with all my heart.
I pray thee let me have thine (aid Favorinus) to peake with her.

You hall Sir, (aid the Serving-man:) there was Favorinus faine to walke twenty turnes in the Hall, before the Meenger came back with invitations of him into the Parlour: where he was no ooner entred, but he could ee the Widow in a carelee habit, and as flight a poture, playing at Cards with ome of her Country-Neighbours; yet upon his approach he ries from the boords-end, and meets him as little a way as he could (glad to ee the Man in o fine cloathes whom he meant o finely to abue.)

Favorinus (with o gracefull a Congie, as no education could finde fault withall) almot upon her lips, recovers himelf by degrees, (giving her uch a cornfull looke as could have no other language, but, how neare was I unto the touch of o great deformity! is this the beauty that is o much talk'd of? a very Dowdie! an arrant Pue! all this did he peake without a word, and more than this did he conceive by that one looke) and (dividing a few jeering miles amongt her Goips) departs her preence, in the greatet didaine that can be imagined.
One of her Gammers cries, What is this a Showter?
Another cries, Out upon him.

A third cries, The Gods forefend, that I may never have to doe with any uch Showters, what? not kie her, when he was o neare to her? if I were as you ha hud never have a kie on me though a wod never o faine.

But Bialta (eeing her elfe o highly contemn'd before o many Witnees, which was no mall aggravation to her discontent) well'd (like a toad, tung in the fore-head, by ome pider, whoe poyon is of a hotter nature than his owne) untill (not onely) the laces of her Bodize burt in under, but her big-wolne heart cry'd roome, as if thoe bounds of nature had not been ribs ufficient, for o weake a veel. She vowes (within her elfe) to be reveng'd, and to make him ee his errour, though the price of her experiment be no lee than her elfe and all her fortunes; he thinks if he doth not make this Man recant, he doth nothing; and propoes the gaining of this Mans love as a worke anwerable to her magnanimity, but he knowes not his name, nor when he hall ee him againe, whether ever or never; he tells her Neighbours that he will bring them to the Gate, her meaning was, to ee whether he could lay eyes upon him againe, and find ome opportunity to peake to him, or happily come to the peech of ome of his Attendants, that he might know his name: but he came out time enough to ee him take Hore, which was brought unto him by a Lacquoy, richly habited; having two Pages tanding bare to him in umptuous apparell; the one having a Hawke upon his fit, the other uncoupling his Spaniels.

Favorinus layes his hand upon the pummil, and vaults up into the addle with uch a grace & cleane activity, itting his Hore (whilt he curvetted) in uch a comely poture, as if Hore and Man had been but one body.

Bialta by this time was come downe to the place, which he mut needs pae by, and o by her; who (when he came neer unto her) as if he had dopd and curchied o much unto him, that he could not doe otherwie, betowed this regardlee language upon her:

p.hi: Widow, if my Game lead me this way againe, I will make bold to call for a Cup of Drinke.

p.U: pread its coulours in her face, he makes more than ordinary obeyance, and aures him more than ordinarily, that he hould be welcome.

div.p: He lighting her extraordinarily, turnes away from her, and calls upon his Men to come away.
She calls upon one of them to tay a little, and tell her, who his Mater was?

The Page (with his Hat upon his head, as if he had been good enough for her) anwered the Lady, that his Maters Name was Favorinus, Sonne to Favorinus, Knight of uch an Order, and Brother to Fortunata, Wife to the Lord Corderius; and o made hate after his Mater without any more expotulation.
