She tooke udden leave of her Neighbours, and preently returnes to her owne houe, and within her elfe, and there begins to commune with her owne thoughts, what it might be, that was the caue of his o great dilike in her? he preently ran to her glae, (fearing that her face might be mutted, or that that dree might not be o pleaing, or that her head was not well dres'd; he calls up her Maid, commanding her to bring her uch a Head-dree, to dree her head o and o, to bring her uch and uch Garments for her wearing; every hayre of her head is et in print, and he makes twenty faces in the glae one after another forty times over that he might ee which of them was mot becomming; one he found out which plea'd her better than all the ret, and that he was reolv'd to keep till he came back; then he was afraid he would not come back at all; then he ends her Servants one this way, another that way, ome to hearken if they could heare the crie of any Hounds, or quet of Spaniels; others whether they could heare any Hawkes bells, or lurings after the Hawke; her Maydes he imployes in pulling the coverings off of the tooles and chayres, the caes off the Couch and Hand-irons, ome in rubbing the boords with weet and green herbs, otherome in fetching downe the bet Cubberd and Table-cloathes: the Woman was tarke wild for the Man: at lat he its her elfe downe, and thinks with her elfe what a gallant Man he was, a Knights Sonne, a Lords Brother-in-law, a Lord that is mot in favour with the Prince; Fortunata's Brother, (who is cry'd up for uch a beauty) and he waranted her elf that he was a Man of ome great power and etate by his retinue, Oh that this Man would come (thought he) and like me! I would not have uch a lur put upon me to be mislik'd for the world, this was the firt man that e're mislik'd me ince I was worth the having, and this hall be the firt Man that hall have me if he likes me.
She had no ooner et her minde and houe in order, but one comes (running in) and tells her, The Gentleman is at the dore, but will not light.
She runnes out as fat, and prayes him, that he would be pleas'd to alight from off his Hore, and ret himelfe awhile, he hould be very welcome.

Favorinus tels her, he cares not and if he doth: alights off his Hore, ne're alutes her; walks in by her, gives her never a word: by that time he was come into the Parlour, he perceives both Houe and Houewife trim'd up to bid him welcome; he calls for a Glae of her cooler Wine.
She intreats him to it downe, and eats her elfe over againt him, to her bet advantage, and the lights haddowings.

Favorinus perceiving all, and looking a long time very tedfastly upon her, at lat he told her, that now he had lookt more warily upon her phyiogmony, he was an indifferent handome Woman, but wih'd her, not to be too proud, for that was all: even handome enough to make a Wife, and that was all that could be aid of her.

She (more glad of that under-word from him, than of all the Hyperbole's that had been given her by his Betters, aid, deiring to improve his good opinion of her, by taking that as a courteie from him which would have been an injury from another) gives him this anwer, You are pleaed to attribute a perfection to me above my merit; for, that is the highet degree of naturall endowments, if there be ufficiency thereof inherent in any Woman to preferre her to that tate and condition, with what greater priviledge can Nature adorne her chiefet Favourites, than with capacity to attaine to that which is the end of their Creation; but, as I like you in that you have not trod in the beaten-road of common Flatterers, o I must tell you, you have trod beide the path which leads to verity; for, I fall hort of thoe demerits which you peake of, witnee your owne judgment.
Favorinus looks into the Garden, and askes her, if that Window were not a Dore that opened into thoe Walks?

p.U: aid, Yes: and opened it immediately, which gave them both leave (a breat) to change the cloer for the open ayre.

div.p: Favorinus meauring the Gravel-walke with his paces awhile, at lat he makes a tand, and with his Cane in his hand makes a Circle upon the ground, incloing himelfe as a tittle in that round [] where he thus peaks unto his Widow, Madame, thus it is in hort, now I am to be had; but if ever I tep one tep out of this Circle, if there were no more Men in the world, no Woman alive hould have me.
And as he was going to tep out of the round, he bids him, Hold; asking him, Sir, hall I not peake in vaine? will you not refue your elfe my Husband, if I hould now ay, I am your Wife?
Favorinus engages his Honour, that he hould not, if without any delayes he gave her full conent, and tooke him whilt he was in the humour.
Then (aid Bialta) Sir, I am yours, and all my Fortunes as much at your dipoall as my elfe.
Agreed (aid Favorinus.)

And pull'd her within the line of Communication, where they plighted their Troths to one another, calling their Servants to tand by as Witnees, and the Gods to it in preence; where we mut leave them for a while, to trace the Succees of Bertaldo and Berontus in their Adventures.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

argument.p: Bertaldo arrives at Spaine. He is entertained by the Duke of Medina Caeli. His Valarous behaviour in the Battell againt the Moores: the Duke acknowledges Periia to be his Daughter, and betowes her upon Bertaldo. He heads the Alpian Bandits, and helps Berontus to overthrow the remainder of the Goths. Amaria found to be the Siter of Bertaldo.

div.p: AS to the firt, Bertaldo had no ooner arrived at Porto Sancta Maria, and acquir'd convenience for his comportment to Cogolludo, the Duke of Medina Coeli his Manion houe, in the Kingdome of Toledo, but he could hear how that all Spaine was up in Armes; and then upon the generall deigne of Expuling the Moores. It rejoyced Bertaldo exceedingly, that occaion was given him, of meriting the acquaintance of that truth, the invention whereof was his ole imployment. Wherefore, without any other expotulations with him (for the preent) he tells him who he was, and that he came to offer his Service in this Expedition: and withall, let him not be ignorant how it had been his Trade: And (as modetly as he could) told him, with what Succees his good Fortune had beene Crown'd in former Victories againt that Nation.

Coeli makes it known unto him how much he acknowledged himelfe Honour'd with that tendure; and although the Ancient Family of the Cerda's acknowledg'd him to be the Chief, and his Bloud no lee Royall, than the Potent Kings of Catile have acknowledg'd his decent; yet he mut ubmit to him that writ himelf Newphew to the Emperour of the World; and that he hould not onely Command him, but bepeak his own Commands.

I here intend no decription of Battailes, or to peak, [COMME UN CLERC DES ARMES] it hall uffice, that Bertaldo had uch a Command as deerv'd his Conduct, and fitted his mind; wherewith he behav'd himelfe o Gallantly (in that Bloudy and lat day of Battaile, that ever was fought betweene the daring Spaniards, and the mot Barbarous and Bloudy Moores) that he not onely got
immortall Honour (epecially in that dayes Service) to the amazement of thoe Gallant oules, (I mean the Spaniards) who are never paring in giving Worth (the jut reward of prayes) in what Countryman oever the deert is found, and as wary in putting Palmes into their owne natives Hands where they are claimed, but with the leat doubt of merit) having once recued their King from eminent danger, twice thrut his Launce through the maine body of the Tawny Monter; and at lat, when Coeli's Son had lot his life in the Caue, and by his death had gained his Friends the Victory. Bertaldo would not uffer the acrifice to be of none effect; but gave the Moores (quickly) to undertand, that his Bloud was Poyon to their hopes, Gaul and Vineger to their Thirt; and every drop, Periods to their Succees.
Thus Spaine formerly lot by Lut, and entred by thee Moores, in at the ides of a lacivious raviher, was Re-intated by means of a Chat Virgin.

Bertaldo having acted his part o well, Coeli was not backward to Honour him with the highet repects that could be imagined, among the ret he expres'd upon occaion a great deal of willingnee to erve his merits.
Bertaldo reply'd, That it lay in his power to doe him that Curteie, that would be the mot acceptable favour of any thing that lay in his power to grant, or his, to ask.
Coeli asked him what it was, and told him it hould be granted?
I ask you nothing (aid Bertaldo) but that you would give me truth.
Coeli bid him onely aske and have, find and take.

Then I ask you upon your Honour: Had you not a Daughter who was called Periia, mark't with the Sun and Moon upon her Arme? Have you not put this Daughter from you? was he not carried into a trange Country? and will you not re-call her back againe? or how long doe you intend he hall be foraken?

Coeli admires the perpicuity of that Mytery, and tells him, That for truth ake he would not dececeive him, and for his promie ake he would not utterly relinquih her; telling him moreover, he did it but to humble the Mother that bare her, and to lead his Child through adverity, that he might attaine to that perfection of humility, of which he hop'd by this time he was mitree of: auring him, that though he eem'd to be out of his ight, and he might eeme to hide his face from her, yet his providence was never wanting in the upply of uch necearies as were expedient for her, though he knew not whence they came, and that now the time was come for her recallment; her only Brother being dead, and he all the Children he had living.
But Bertaldo (aid the Duke) how came you to undertand all this?
Onely by hearing, eeing, and believing (aid Bertaldo) by hearkning to Adminda's voice; by eeing the Signes and Wonders upon her Armes, and by believing both.
Coeli ask'd him, Have you not brought a Petition with you, as well as a Narration?

p.U: aid I have, and it is oone aid. I deire your Daughter.

div.p: Coeli reply'd, and it is as oone granted: She is yours, and all that Coeli has to give; but you mut have her upon this one condition.
I will performe it what ever it be, if it be posible (aid Bertaldo.)
To which Coeli made no other reply but this: Thus posible it is, you mut loe no time in the accomplihment of your owne deires.

That I may not (aid Bertaldo) I take my leave to be obedient to your Commands: o departed: and finding that Prince of the Ayre to blow contrary winds in the full face of his deigne, he feared it would be contrued negligence to attend that favour: wherefore he cros'd the Perenean and Alpian Mountaines to overcome a difficulty, and the better to croe that Mediterranean, that deny'd him paage all along; where behold this faithfull diligence made him fortunate in an exploit beyond his expectation; for, Berontus having arrived at Rome, about the time that the fatall houre of the Gothes detruction was drawing on, being entertain'd under the Emperour Honorius, and having conditions anwering his dignity, he hapned to be an intrument whereunto the glory of that day owned its chief acknowledgment; o that the Emperialits having twice beaten the Gothes in two everall Combates; at lat, the Eagle with her large-pread-wings made thee Tramantanean birds fall upon the Italian earth, and lie full low at the feet of her owne Alpes; Alarick perceiving himelfe thrice worted, and at lat neceitated to eek unto the Streights mouthes to be received into their protections; the Alpian Bandites (together with all the Inhabitants of the White Region, and Travellers in that Galaxie or Milky-way of Heaven-treaders under their feet, thoe cloud-over-topping, sky-threatning, and heaven-apiring parcels of earth) hearing of this newes, (like o many black Ravens, Kites, and Crowes, aembled themelves in expectation of the fall of ome ick and dying beat) were thus prepared to watch their opportunities, how they might make a prey of the remainder of this bleeding Army; but their Tumults wanted policy and good conduct, which could not be wanting aoone as Bertaldo was come amongt them; who hearing the newes, offered his ervice. They knowing the Man, were more glad than willing to be commanded by him: he dipoes of them in uch a manner, as they prov'd uch a Remora to the Ship of their proceedings, that it was oone overtaken by the puruing Enemy, who being van'd and rear'd with Enemies alike, flankt on both ides with invincible Rocks and Mountaines, they were all there laine, taken Prioners, and made a prey to thoe, who were not enough to reap the benefit of o great a harvet.

Berontus wondred who it hould be, that hould top o fierce a torrent, and give battaile to depaire. Bertaldo wondred who it hould be that hould fall on with uch a maine: and who hould thee two be, but the two devoted Servants to true Piety and Virtue, able at any time to conquer more than Men, and to be more than Conquerours.

They aluted one another, having time enough upon their march
between that and Rome, to recite all their everall paages to one another, who were both confident, that their endeavours derived their uccees from the prayers of Innocents.

Both of them reolving upon the way to begge that boone of the Emperour, upon their firt arrivall, to know of Honorius how Amaria was his Neece, and Bertaldo's Siter? but their thoughts were more reolv'd than their reolution was requiite; for, the whole buinee concerning Amaria was generally knowne amongt the Romanes, before Berontus his returne to Rome: and thus it came about. Flaccus, Brother to the Emperour Honorius, had a pretty Daughter who was bewitched, being a Childe at Nure, into extreame deformity, who fearing the perpetuity of that Enchantment (which was but for a time) he forthwith made his Brother the Emperour acquainted with the diater; who unwilling that uch an ey-ore hould be viible upon o unblemiht a race of humane kinde, as he uppoed his owne to be, advis'd his Brother to end her away into ome foraine Countrey, and to give uch a umme of Money with her, as ome elected one for the ame purpoe would be glad of; who thereby might thinke themelves ufficiently engag'd, as well for ecreie, as maintenance. Accordingly Flaccus found out a fit intrument to worke upon, one Galeas, a needy Sea-man, belonging to Cheru a poore fihing-towne upon the coats of Affrica, within ix leagues of Carthage, where Amaria was fotred up under the wel-enabled and vigilant care of Galeas Wife even yeares; at the end of which tearme, the Spell having lot its virtue, Amaria came to her former feature, and her Princely countenance received its proper lineaments of majetie, which together with the pregnant wit wherewith he was more than liberally endowed by the gifts of nature, o wrought upon her Nure, that he was more tender of her than of any of her owne Children; o tender that he never reveal'd that ecret unto her, as her being not her owne: and riper yeares making her more capable of further knowledge, and enabling her with more cunning to get out more, her Nure at lat confet unto her, that he was ome great Mans Childe, but he could not tell her whoe, in regard that her Husband was cat away at ea, before he had got the ret out of him, withall hewing her the Mantle wherein he was delivered unto her Husband; whoe no lee antiquity than richnee with its curious wrought (yet worn out) Enigns of majety, pake it a cat Ornament out of ome Princes Wardrobe; this was all the Card, wherein he could poibly read her Pedegraee, this was all the Records whereby he could come to the knowledge of her Ancetors: the drie Nure had nothing more to ay, but that he knew no more, and wih'd he could doe her any ervice, whereby he might attaine to the knowledge of her owne Parents.

Amaria climbing up apace to the yeares of dicretion, this tender Sapling at the firt bearing, yeilded thee fruits of Policy, grafted upon the tock of her owne invention; For, (aid he) unto her Nure-Mother (for o he alwaies call'd her) I have heard you often
ay, that your Husband had receiv'd me at the hands of a Romane Matron; more than that, either he could not ay, or would not tell you; it will not avail us (now) to be inquiitive after that matter, ince he is dead who onely could decide the buinee; but this I would faine upplicate to your indulgent care and love that's alwaies exercis'd in my behalfe a Croe the Seas, goe to Rome, carry the Mantle with you, and ee who will owne it, know whoe Armes they be, what the ignification of thoe Hieroglyphicks are: and when you have inform'd your elfe as much as you can, or can thereby come to the knowledge of whoe it was, tell them how that Mantle wrapt a little Childe that was enchanted by ome Sorcery or Magick Spell, whoe craft has now let working the Cat-away is Fourteen years of age, and hath her growth, limbs, and lineaments, with features which they may behold without regret, if they would be pleaed to owne their Childe.

Gan • la (for o the Nure was call'd) was mervailouly taken with the Exploit, infinitly commending her widome and advice, but commends her mot of all by putting it in execution: Beyond-ea he goes, he and her Mantle; to Rome he comes, up and down the treet he trapes, hewing it to this body and to that; at lat he was taken upon upition of Felonie, clapt up in Prion, brought to her Triall, where Flaccus himelfe itting upon the Bench, heard her relate (in her owne defence) all the particulars as is before expret, tands her Friend, and tickles o much in her behalf, that her Tale was credited; but he would not owne the Mantle, which he caued to be taken from her, nor the Child he would not end for; o great a power has hame over delinquency, rather (againt the bonds of nature) to run into a twofold Errour, than acknowledge one: yet nature wrought this effect in him, he ends for the Woman privately, and communes with her, at a ditance, concerning Amaria; atisfies him elfe fully in the buinee, commends her for her good will and care, rewards her highly, tells her nothing, but advies her to counel her foterChild to be contented with her condition untill uch time as opportunity hould erve, and it eaon give her information whoe he was: For his owne part he was a Friend, that would not let her want o long as he could be ilent, ending her uch a umme of money as he cared not who tooke notice of; but withall, incloing within a Cabinet ealed up, and boorded about, wherein was encloed jewells of inetimable value, with this Letter in it:

body.p: you mut not know from whence this comes, nor who it is that ends it you; upon this Condition you hall never be without continuall upplies: want not Patience, and you hall never want; be obedient to Necesity for a while, and Contentment hall crowne your deires hereafter with the knowledge of what you are, and who it is that writes o like

div.p: This Letter was thus upercrib'd, For the forlorne, yet acceptable AMARISSA.

With thee Intructions and atisfactions Ganzala return'd to Affrica, delivers Amaria her mind together with the Money he was entruted with, who thought he had delivered all, together with the Cabinet, which he tooke to be no more than an ordinary Box; which when Amaria had opened (all alone) having oberv'd that policy tampt upon the Seals, he found no lee treaure (of inetimable value) in the Cabinet, than a Cabinet in the Letter, beyond all etimation both for ecrefie and counell, whoe private boxes he was not able to finde out. Thus farre atisfied (as it was enough at once) he rets contented, rather pleaing her elfe with preent hopes of future revelation (in its due time) then tormenting her elfe with prepoterous crutinie into the eldome-olid grounds of anticipation, he went as farre as reaon would give her leave, and commands what common ence witneeth to be within her power, he gave her elfe what Education money would purchae, and wore as good cloathes as price could reach, when both had made her a Companion for the bet, he thought her elf beholding to thoe for her acceptance who were beneath her equalls, by valuing others Jewels he came to know the price of her owne, at lat (having more than ordinary parts) there was more than ordinary notice taken of her perfection, inomuch, that he was preented (as a peciall rarity) to the old Princee, who dying, Prince Lorenzo entertain'd as the greatet beauty, till Honoria her over matching and comely feature let him know, that there was a beauty urpaing that, which could not be excell'd but by her owne fleh and blood, where having brought her off and on Lorenzo's love, in and out of Bertaldo's armes, we will make her amends in making hate to place her in Berontus's boome, and agree all Parties, after that we have brought Bertaldo and Berontus home from Rome.

After three yeares time had made Honorius's condition no lee deperate than his whole Empire haken by that terrible invaion of the Gothes, it fortuned that Flaccus (having received his deaths-wound & in the Enemies cutody) deired the priviledge of his barbarous Enemy, that he might be permitted to write a Letter to his Brother the Emperour? which being granted unto him, his dying-hand et pen to paper that writ this Letter to Honorius:

body.p:
I Acknowledge a judgement of non-properity befalne me, ever ince I took • your counell of abandoning my owne Childe in her affliction, whom I hould have rather cherih'd than foraken, and now punihment hath overtaken my offence, I feare me the like hath befalne you for your adviing me thereunto, I doubt it will never be happy dayes with you, untill you have rectified this Errour. Amaria he's well, he lives in Cheru, within ix leagues of Carthage, the Womans name is Ganzala with whom he lives, the Mantle wherein I ent her away is in my houe; the Lord Chief Jutice of the Bench will relate unto you the whole tory
when you hew him the Mantle, tell him of the Affrican Woman that was questioned before him for a Felon, and hew him my Letter: I can write no more, but find my elfe dipos'd more and more to bid you farewell,

div.p: Flaccus dying almot with the pen in his hand, the Gothih King perceiving the contents of the Letter, and nothing deirous to contribute the leat aitance to the removall of any judgments from over his head, whoe detruction was his deign, conceal'd the Letter: uch fallings hort are men incident to meet withall, who procratinate their amendments, and leave their good Deeds to be performed by their Executors.

But Berontus, Amynda's Favourite, Fortune's Minion, Fortitudes Piller, and Heire to Jutice, mut bring all thee things to light; for, in the firt Battaile that ever he truck with the Emperour againt the Gothes, he eiz'd the Gothih Kings Pavilion, wherein amongt other Papers, after that Berontus had received Orders to proecute the Gothes, the Emperour (at leiure) found this Letter, ent for the Jutice, hewed him the Letter, view'd the Mantle, wherein were carce (ditinctly) perceiv'd the Emperours Armes, the black-pread-Eagle, who had lot its colour, very little of whoe body could be perceiv'd, onely the head and part of both the wings might be dicern'd, the border round about it quite worne out, onely the titulary Letters were plaine and legible: In a word, by that time Bertaldo and Berontus were return'd to Rome, being received as triumphantly by the Emperour, as joyfully by the People, they were entertain'd with revelations, for all things were made ready to their hands, there needed but little examinations where confeions were o plaine, records o evident, and witnees o palpable in their demontrations: but to make hate to Carthage.

div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: Bertaldo and Berontus returne to Carthage with joyfull Tydings. Bertaldo is Married to Periia. Berontus to Amaria. Favorinus to Bialta. Hortenius to Pippea. Prickette to Rivana. Lorenzo and Honoria, Corderius and Fortunata, Thoron and Armena Solemnize the Wedding.

div.p: BErtaldo and Berontus, the one having received many Favours from his Royall Uncle; the other Acknowledgements that he was his Nephew, like two skales equally poiz'd by the hand of Jutice, (one fill'd with Weight, the other with Value) both returne to Carthage, where we imagine them unloading themelves (of the glad Tydings that were uch Burthens to them) till they had thrown them off their retentive faculty into their Mitrees eares.

Have you eene, or can you imagine, how an Uurer welcomes full Bags of Gold (in their telling) when they are paid unto him (with all their interet) out of ome deperate Debt? So atisfi'd were the expectations of thee Votaries, with the Relation that they made, and the good Account that they had given them in every particular.
Never before this time were all the Blockers knockt out of the way for the well-delivered Bowle (fairly) to take its coure, Court and Kie its Milree, ent from the never-erring hand of Providence.

Bertaldo takes Periia by the Hand, and thus peakes unto her: Periia, the Blesing of Heaven, the Joy of the whole Earth, the Fruit of Paradie, natures Excellency; the Ornament of Humility, the Mirrour of Chatity, the Ne plus ultra, to the degrees of Love; whoe Merrit is above my Recompence! contancy denyes an imitation, whoe value hath no Price! whoe elf o good, that Flatteries can neither hurt, nor Hyperboles reach! How happy am I in anwering thy o well-contrived affections with a compleat furniture for o fair a roome! here let me take a Chamber for eternity, and let no time out me from poeion of this Happinee!
Periia anwers this Speech with admiration, and lookes anwers 'fore he peakes; at lat he findes the doore of utterance.

Bertaldo (aid Periia) how happy hath my uppoed unworthinee made this equality between us! how great a friend hath my depaire been to this our Union! None can rejoyce at the comfortablenee of Fire, but he that comes out of the Cold; none can be glad of Meat, but he that is a Hungry; and none can lack his Thirt, but he that was a-dry: Colours cannot be better commended than by their contraries; nor Miracles more taken notice of, than by impoibilities. Wherefore
the wie Creator in manifeting his omnipotence, rais'd a glorious Light from Darknee; drew Method from Confuion; Order from the Chaos: and at lat, compos'd a Firmament of the weaket of all elements. Such a patterne hath Bertaldo followed; now he hath rais'd his Periia from uch weak hopes, to o firme a confidence, whilt he was in o dark a condition, to hine with o bright a Lutre in his Eyes; and through impoibilities to cut out, and plaine away for my accesion to this Throne: Wherefore, ever let my chiefet care to pleae you be my Crown; and all my Paions, my Subjects.

Whilt Bertaldo and Periia were courting one another, and both congratulating their good Fortune; miling upon the Starres that howr'd downe their choicet influence upon their Heads: Berontus and Amaria thus all the while betowed themelves in their behaviour and language. Berontus tooke his Amaria by the hand, whoe prightly behaviour anwered the tacture, with like affection, as when good conceits meet with quaintet wits; whereby it becomes a hard matter to dicerne whether of both are better pleas'd, the giver, or receiver. Both thee make one patime, thee both one happinee, and thus he peakes unto her:

p.hi: Amaria, the maine engine from whom the wheel of Fortune borrowes its motion; the Ball whom Envie toes above its owne head by purning at it; the Vine that gives it elfe its education, and can exhale nourihment out of its owne body without the uuall, and outward bark of Parents: how pleaing are the remembrances of thoe things which were o hard to uffer? how contentfull are the atchievements which break their way through difficulties? was ever Love unfetter'd o as mine hath been? were ever Hearts unchain'd as ours? was there ever o fat a Knot untyed before? did ever any Act pae o farre beyond all hope?

div.p: Amaria, there is a Joy that may be expres'd, there is a Joyfulnee that can hardly be uttered; but the gladnee that affects me in having you, hath no Language: wherefore all mut now lie at the mercy of your belief; believe but half of that that is, and your belief urpaes all imagination. To which Amaria reply'd,

Berontus, in anwer to your Metaphors and Compellations, I could call you Heire to Jutice; Amynda's Favourite, Fortitudes right Hand, Fortunes Minion, the Peoples Darling: But I conceive more felicity in aying, My Berontus, which includes all that can be aid: And for your doubt of my belief, Alas! I have an Inmate in my breat, that leads my Faith by the hand, like a Child, and hewes me all the ecrets of your Heart: No Berontus, thou hat met with roome enough to hoard up all thy tore of Merit, if thou thinket the place worthy of it.

Whilt Bertaldo and Periia, Berontus and Amaria were geminating Hearts and Soules, Hortenius and Pippea tanding at a ditance, ape one another into their imilitude and likenee; Hortenius takes Pippea by the Hand, who receives his Curteie with uch a kind of Laughter, as Country Laes cannot chue but make when they firt ride in Chariots, which hath not its proceedence from ridiculounee,
but from a mixture of joy and bahfulnee, to ee themelves o highly grac'd above their merits, and thus he pake unto her:

Pippea, Why may there not be as much incerity and affection expres'd by ticking a Cowlip or a Gilliflower within thy breat, as there can be either in the choicet Tulip, or the mot fragrant Roe? as they are not altogether o beautiful and delightfull to ome of the ences, o they offend none; whereas the high-priz'd Tulip has no avour, and the weet Roe growes upon uch Prickles as oftentimes offends the touch, often cauing the ame fingers to bleed oarly that pluckt them from their talks.

Why talks my Hortenius thus to me? (aid Pippea) there are Ladyesgloves, Silver-haire, and Marigolds to be found in the Common-fields, which are not in Ladyes gardens; let them plume the corners of their beds with gilded-feathers, whilt we border ours with dayies and everlating.

Whilt thee three paire of Lovers were courting one another, Lorenzo and Honoria could not ue any language for hearkning to what they had aid, nor other behaviour for oberving theirs: both were exceeding glad to ee the corne o fluter upon the ground that was owed by their hands, and come to uch maturity as required their ickle to be thrut into their harvet, that hould cut downe the looe eares that were open to further dicoure, that they might be bound up in the band of unity: wherefore Lorenzo and Honoria appoint the time of Marriage, and that, no longer then the day that followed; they end for the Heraulds, and asked their advice about the manner of the olemnity, charging them, that it might be performed with the greatet tate and magnificence that lay within the power of art and cot to et it forth.

The Heraulds anwered, that all things were in a readinee, that preparation it elf could et in order; but there was one thing requiite, which if it could be effected, nothing could more conduce to make it olemne, viz: that thee olemnities might have their hadowes, and thee paires their econds; which (they aid) might be eaily done if they intended Marriages betweene Favorinus and Bialta, Hortenius and Pippea might have uch accelerations as they might all meet in parallels upon the ame day.

The propoition pleaed the Princes well, and the Ladyes mot of all; it was o order'd by Lorenzo, whoe commands plain'd all difficulties, and cut off all delayes: The Parties were ent for; ent for, came; no ooner there, but all agreed: Corderius made a motion to all the Company, that to his knowledge there were a Couple to be Married, and the time appointed was but the day after the morrow whereon thee olemnities were to be performed, he aw no reaon but that they hould take them alo into the number that the Temple might be full: They all conented, and were earnet to know who they were? and being told them, who hould it be, but poor Prickette and Rivana;
joy, and mirth, and willingnee, were expreed all at once for his reception: A Herauld at Armes was ent to Prickette to ummon him to the Wedding, and to command him to be ready on the morrow with his Sweet-heart, to be Married with the ret.

The Heraulds having ended their debatements concerning the particular Ceremonies, it was concluded, that Bertaldo and Berontus hould have Banners carried before them, wherein were curiouly repreented all the famous deeds of Chivalry that had been perform'd by thoe Heroes, when they mot quench'd their thirting after fame, and o they were to make a mot olemne proceion up to the Temple of Virtue; and through it, to the Temple of Honour; where uch unions were to be made as divided themelves into halves to be wholly one anothers: But, as for Favorinus and Bialta, Hortenius and Pippea, whoe utmot merits aym'd at no higher perfection than morallity, their acendent was to be no higher than to the Temple of Virtue, and there to conummate their Vowes, where the totall umme of all their merits would not arie in their particulars to any tearmes of Honour: But, Prickette and Rivana they were to goe no farther than to the portch of the Temple, there to content themelves with compatible olemnities.

This Concluion, was no mall occaion of much ditraction; for, Bialta (a Woman of a high pirit) was not a little dipleas'd that he hould wed her elfe to a Man of no atchievements, and to one that could not lead her up the teps of Honour, o that at lat he began to well bigger with corne than when he corn'd her firt: and thus he openly expret her dicontents before all the Company, Mut I betow my elfe, and mile a fortune upon a Man that can anwer my deerts with no higher advance to than et me downe at Virtue's feet? whoe Temple as it is a thorow-fare to Honours, I like full-well; but as it is a confine, I like the Seat no more than if he had ate me upon the Stoole of ad Repentance. I thought (when I aw him firt (active as lightning) get up upon his flying Hore) he had been able to have pluckt bright Honour from the pale-fac'd Moone; but now, I ee, that Hares and Partridges, were the Trophees of his greatet Victories: he could be no more contented with that beggarly glory, than Eagles could make it their repat to catch at Flies.

Nor was this all, for Pippea takes her Sweet-heart Hortenius aide, and tells him, Hortenius, thou art an honet man, but that is all: what a fine thing it would have been if thou hadt done ome famous act whereby we two might have been Married in the Temple of Honour with Bertaldo and Periia, Berontus and Amaria? I love thee well already, but if thou hadt been a martiall Man, Oh how happy hould I have been!
Why (aid Hortenius) what is that to love? why hould Women be o much in love with bloody hands?

Oh (aid Pippea) they are not bloody except they be tain'd with unlawfull blood! he that knowes how to conquer Men, knowes how to defend
a Womans honour: who would Marry a Milk-op? Hortenius, cant thou not doe one gallant exploit or other, and let Marrying alone for awhile? I would faine be Married in the Temple of Honour, I will promie thee that I will love thee twice as much, and doe any thing for thee that thou wilt have me doe.

Hortenius (put off and on two uch buinees as neither lik'd him) was not a little troubled: yet he was contented enough to make a virtue of necesity, and climbe to Honour through that acent, but he wanted an opportunity, which was preently offer'd him, for behold, Whil't thee affaires were in agitation, there came a hot and tinging alarum to the Court, that young Towolin, Emperour of the Abisines, had invaded the Dominion, and entred farre into the Countrey with a mighty Army, in puruance of his Fathers Quarrell; this udden newes lock'd up the Temple gates, and tooke their reolutions off the hinges: for, neither of thoe two Worthies thought it gallantry to creep to happinee between a paire of heets, whil't the Enemy had colours flying in the field that invited them to honour and afety: and Periia perceiving how Planet-trucken Favorinus and Hortenius were through want of merit, (to anwer the expectations of their envious Mitrees) he encourages them to reolutions that hould wret the wreath of Bayes out of the hand of fame, and with as much eae as if he had been a Childe had held it in her hand. Favorinus and Hortenius, fir'd with hope, and fill'd with confidence, knowing, that a better School Mitree could not direct them in that dicipline, were reolv'd to follow her intructions whatoever they were, verily believing, that nothing could be found imposible or difficult that he call'd eaie; wherefore they deir'd her to lay her commands upon them, and to acquaint them with the deigne, and he hould ee that the fault hould not lye in them, but (if any were) in her who was never faulty. She declares it to them, (which we will forbeare to expree till the act howes) they like it well, all was in a readinee; the Army is drawne out and face each other: who but Favorinus, and Hortenius! all the common Souldiers, and inferiour Officers, admire to ee them ent to; and running in and out o often to and from the Councell of Warre; ome jearingly ask'd one another, If Favorinus had e're a Hawke to flie? Others aid, If there were but a Hare in his way, how bravely would he charge the Enemy, with a cry of Doggs? Others jear'd Hortenius, and ask'd, What have we to doe with this Gardener here? what? is he ent for to the Councell of Warre? Others anwering, that ure he was ent for to line the hedges: Others aying, If all yonder Regiments were but o many private Buhes, how bravely would he top their heads with his Garden hears! Thus idle Courtiers, and uptart Favourites, mut be contented to be jeer'd when they are out of their clement, the courted, till they have made themelves famous by ome exploits, and then they top the mouthes of their Adveraries.

But to the buinee it elfe, Favorinus and Hortenius, according
to Periia her directions, black their hands and faces with an unguent which he had given them, and o under a two-fold darknee of night and hue, repaire to the Enemies Camp, and never left moving from place to place untill they came to the Emperours Tent; where watching their opportunity (when the Emperour was leat attended) they entred the Pavilion, where Favorinus, layes the Emperour; and Hortenius, the Standard-bearer; together with the Emperour's Page; which were all the heads, that the Tent ore-covered at that intant: the chief whereof Favorinus cuts from the body, and Hortenius takes the Standard in his hand, as Favorinus did the head, wherewith they both mounted on Horeback, exhorting the Souldiers to tand to their Armes, crying out, the Enemy is upon us! the Officers and Souldiers (taking them to be ome of the chief Commanders, but could not informe themelves in the darke, they tanding not till to give information) take the alarum: Trumpets ound to Hore, the Drums beat. Lorenzo, by this diorder, knew that the worke was done; and (according as they had layd the deigne) fell upon the Moores; who running to their Emperour to receive Orders, found him without a head; by reaon of which confuion, the Carthaginians oone devour'd that headlee Monter, as if o many hounds had eiz'd upon a new-falne tagge: thus was that great Army oone diolv'd by the two contant Followers of Periia her direction; who returning from the Warres, Favorinus being poeticall given, traines his Genius that way to frame thee Veres in honour of his Directree:

l.hi: The floating
l.U: hip, is govern'd by the card;

lg.l: The Architect, mut have his quare at hand;
The glittering buckler, doth the Souldier ward,
(Although aaulted by a mighty band)
Whilt breathing I remaine, Periia, he
A Card, Square, Buckler, and a Shield hall be.
A card, which me directs, to heavens coat;

l.hi: A
l.U: quare, to governe all my actions by;

lg.l: A buckler, to defend me from an hoat:
Then hall I Devill, world, and fleh, defie:

l.hi: And though to them (at firt) I eeme to pray,
Yet doubt I not, but I hall win the day.

div.p:
Now the Marrriages run on wheels, and the compleat Armour mut give way to wedding Garments; Gantlets mut be throwne aide to put on wedding Gloves, and plumes of feathers bend whilt head-pieces doe vail to bonnets tuck with bridal-favors. Now all mut into the Temple of Honour; Favorinus mut have the black head of the darke Emperour, carried before him: Hortenius the Standard that he tooke; all was ayre, and light, and fire, and unnes, and moones, and tarres:
onely Prickette and Rivana they were dull, and earth, and heavy; having no merit to lay claime to Virtue or Honour, they were (likely) to loe their hares in the glory of the day.

Wherefore, Rivana told her Sweet-heart (plainly) that She would not be Married in a Portch, he aw no reaon but that he was as good a Man as Hortenius, and if he was not, it was his owne fault, he might have been if he would: why did he not goe into the Warres, and doe as he did? for her part, he hated a Man that was good for nothing: and if he would needs Marry in a Portch let him get one that would, for he would not be made a laughing-tock for the bet of them all. Oh that he were a Man he would have been Married in the Temple of Honour, or ele he would have been wedded to her grave!
This Speech made Prickette oarly lament and repent that he had been o negligent in laying hold of opportunities (when they were offered him) to have done ome glorious act whereby he might be famous.

He coniders with himelf, and repaires unto the Herauld, and layes before him the miery of his condition, offering him a large umme of money, if he could finde out ome way, or plead his cae o, that he might be Married in the Temple of Honour, or ele he was ure to loe his Mitree for ever.

The Herauld told him, that there was no way except he could fight a Duell with ome knowne Worthy, and o come off with honour, and in uch a cae he had a private conveyance where he could hew him how he might convey his Mitree into the Temple, and there when he was once got in, it was the manner of the place, that none hould be excluded; and he would plead the priviledge of the Temple in his behalf if need required.

Prickette did not like the Propoition very well, yet that was all he could get of the Herauld: away he goes, telling him, that he would ee what he could doe, reolving to be quarrelome with any living oule that hould give him (but) the leat occaion; for, he was reolv'd not to endure that life whatoever came of it: up and downe he goes eeking occaion, where at lat under the walls of Carthage he lights into a grot, where one Hamon (a notable Kill-cow and noted Dueller, and one who had formerly put an afront upon him) was drinking and making merry with ome others of his Companions: Prickette comes in, and tells them, he was dipos'd to be merry.
The Company anwered him, that they were dipos'd to bid him welcome.
But Hamon look'd omething urly upon Prickette, and he upon Hamon.
At lat when wine had begun to ripen both their humours, Prickette begins to vapour.
Hamon tells him, that leer ayle would erve his veell.
Prickette anwered him, That if that dipleas'd him he would et up more, and yet not over-et, for any big wind his words could make.
Hamon perceiving him to grow o fat upon him, asked him, if he remembred uch a time, when he put uch an Affront upon him?
Prickette told him, That he remembed it very well, and therefore he took this opportunity to quetion him for it.
Hamon told him, he took a very ill time to quetion him, when it was Night; and that he doubted he would not be o valiant in the Morning.

Prickette told him, That if he thought o, he would fight with him preently, it was as dark for the one as tother, happy man be his Dole. But the Company would not uffer them: and Prickette found many friends, becaue he was a Courtier, and one that might be made ome ue of; wherefore Prickette pretended a willingnee to be reconcil'd, that he might enjoy his opportunity to whiper Hamon in his Ear; who had his deire, and privately challenged Hamon to come out, and fight with him; telling him, That he would take an occaion to goe out, as if he meant to turne his face to the Wall, and then he hould come after him, and they would have a Crah. Hamon conented to it, out goes Prickette, and climes up to the top of a Rock, whereon the foundation of the City-wall was laid; after him comes Hamon (no man upecting any uch matter) and drawes his Sword, and askes Where art thou? Now Prickette had him between him and the light, o that he could eaily dicerne him; but Hamon (newly come out of the light, and having it behind him) could not ee before him: So that he till cry'd, Where art thou? Where is this Fellow? Prickette till cry'd, Here: Why don't you come on? Untill uch time as he had got him jut under him, and then he leaps upon his Neck and Shoulders, and beares him to the ground; puts his Shoulder out of joynt, Diarmes him; cryes aloud, Call for mercy (thou Villaine) or I will be the death of thee.

The Company hearing a noie, all run out with Candles in their hands, and there they find Prickette upon the Gyant: They all take him off of him. Hamon cryes, O I am oarly bruis'd, and my Bones are out of joynt! Sirrah, had it been in the day thou houldt never have done this: I protet I aw him not, but he came upon me all of the uddaine, I knew not how, nor which way. O my Arme! my Shoulder is out of Jont, my Neck is Bruis'd, my Head is Broken! Who would have thought there had been o much trength in uch a little Urchin!
Prickette told him, That if he thought the Night had been any diadvantage to him, he hould doe well to take the advantage of the Day, he would anwer him.
No (aid Hamon) I think you have given me enough for all the dayes of my life.

All began to admire Prickette, every body thought Prickette a Gallant Man; who but Prickette was cry'd up for a daring fellow. Prickette repaires to the Herauld, brings his witnees, tells him what he had done: The Herauld bids him leave the management of the ret to him, and bring his Rivana along with him, much about the time of
the Solemnity, and he would conveigh them a way where they hould not need to go through the Temple of Vertue, but pae through the Prerogative, into the Temple of Honour.

Now becaue I will not end my tory with relations of Wedding Garments, or uffer my pen to be o neare of kinne to feathers in a bed as to write their happinees upon its Sheets, I hall onely bring thee Worthies into the acred Temple, and there leave them in a place of glory & honour, into a place that was all light & had no windows, uch a light as receiv'd its lutre from the flames of hearts and melting oules burning in the fire of love, which were upon & under the Altar, whoe Quire was pav'd with precious Stones, where Diamonds were et in Characters, whereby Letters of Light were o compos'd that every foot that gave a tep made impreion upon Eternity. In the midt of which Temple there was a ea of blie, and Angels moving upon the face of the water, whoe oares were wings and boates ubiquities, and every troake that plah'd upon thoe waters of life gave both life and muick: all the Temple was covered over with repreentations of the Triple Deity (by whom Ovid wore) curiouly done in Moaick worke with the bright and hining cales of Fihes taken out of that ea, all three upporting the ame Looking-glae with their right hands, wherein were to be een pleaures, and round about it written the word FOR EVERMORE. Into this glorious Temple the Heraulds lead thee loving Paires, and placed them in their everall eates of rotten, but now hining wood; upon one ide whereof was written Mortallity; and upon the other, Corruption upon armes whoe hands laid hold upon the eates, as if they were ready to teare them in under. After that the high Priet had made an end of offering, and perform'd the holy Rites, there decended from above a Commiion and a Pen which an Angel received and delivered it into the high Priets hands, who preented both to Periia; which Commiion was that that Pen hould write, I'm before Mortallity, and In before Corruption: o the ame power made the ame hands as tayes to ecure their bleed tate, which formerly had been the caues of their diolutions: And thus we end our Hitory with the heavenly Choriters, inging this Antheme:

l.hi: THus at lat the lot Sheep's found,

lg.l: Thus humility is crown'd;
Thus the patience of three
Hath got a three-fold victorie;
Thus pure chatity can ay,
Jt triumphs in the latter day;
Thus true fortitude is blet,
B' aurance of eternall ret;
Thus tain'd innocence has right,
The black falls off, he's all in white;
He that of merit wants a tock,

l.hi: Conquers (thus) climbing up the rock;
Be ever happy in this pleaure,

lg.l: Time hath throwne away his meaure.
Who a good concience wou'n't keep fat,
To be rewarded, thus, at lat!
